fields.heading: Two Jailed on Burglary Charges
fields.content:
Two men were being held Monday morning on burglary of a habitation charges after they reportedly kicked in a front door of a Venus home Oct. 24 and surprised a 41-year-old woman inside. She screamed and the intruders ran from the scene, Johnson County Sheriff Bob Alford said.

The men, Justin Wayne Cook, 17, of Alvarado, and Billy Dean Amurgey, 20, of Euless, were arrested a short time later at a house next door, Alford said. Cook and Amurgey were being held at the Johnson County Corrections Center on $5,000 bail each.

Alford said deputies and sheriff's investigators responded to the burglary in progress call on Delta Drive near Venus along with three Venus police officers. Deputy Steve Brownlow remembered that someone with a history of burglary lived on the same street, and he drove to that house, Alford said.

“Brownlow soon learned from a witness that several men had been seen outside a house next door to the residence that had been burglarized. Another witness reported seeing two young men flee from the residence,” Alford said.

Brownlow then went to the home next door to the burglarized residence and found several young men. The homeowners arrived and told deputies that four of the young men were strangers and did not have permission to be in their home. All four were given criminal trespass warnings, the sheriff said.

Meanwhile, Detectives Cody Norman and Jay Kniffen had arrived to process the burglary scene and tied evidence from that scene to two of the men Brownlow had detained.

Lt. Mike Gilbert told Brownlow a computer check revealed that all the young men had previous charges. Rob Fraser can be reached at 817-645-2441, ext. 2336, or rfraser@trcle.com

Source: Rob Fraser/Staff Writer, Cleburne Times Review, Cleburne, TX.

fields.heading: Home invaders can be identified using cat fur
fields.content:
If a person's home has been broken into, there's new evidence that owning a cat can help catch the criminal.

Research from the University of California-Davis has shown that cat fur can be used as evidence in identifying a burglar, according to PetPeoplePlace.com. Using this furry feline to catch criminals came from one researcher' love of television crime dramas.

UC Davis' Dr. Leslie Lyons told PetPeoplePlace.com that "because cats incessantly groom, cat fur may have nucleated cells, not only in the hair bulb, but also as epithelial cells on the hair shaft deposited during the grooming process, thereby generally providing material for DNA profiling." In other words: Criminals beware of homes with cats because this is one robbery detail they cannot control.

There has already been once instance where a cat's fur helped convict a criminal. Pet owners are encouraged to keep their cat's DNA on file, in the event their home is broken into, PetPeoplePlace.com said.

While this is a major breakthrough, consumers may want to consider investing in burglar alarms as a preventative measure.
fields.summary: If a person's home has been broken into, there's new evidence that owning a cat can help catch the criminal.

fields.heading: Securing a new home
fields.content:
Buying a new home is an exciting time for consumers. While most people may be more focused on their new hardwood floors, Energy Star appliances and heated pool, they should also be concerned about how they are going to secure their new investment.

Deadbolts in standard doors often aren't much of a deterrent for burglars looking to break in to a home, according to the Wetaskiwin Times. If homeowners really want to protect their residence, family and possessions, they should seriously consider installing high-security deadbolts.

These deadbolts have "protective spin collars to prevent an intruder from twisting the lock off the door," the Wetaskiwin Times reported. They also "come with a frame reinforcement piece called a strike box – this is installed on the frame side of the lock and accepts the bolt once in the extended position."

Homeowners should also consider using door reinforcers and glass protection for windows, the Wetaskiwin Times suggested. Installing webcams and security software would also allow for personal home monitoring from a remote location.

There are a variety of security cameras that a homeowner can choose from to incorporate as part of their security system.
fields.summary: Buying a new home is an exciting time for consumers. While most people may be more focused on their new hardwood floors, Energy Star appliances and heated pool, they should also be concerned about how they are going to secure their new investment.

fields.heading: Home burglaries rise in Texas
fields.content:
A recent report has found Texas homes are increasingly being burglarized.

Allstate Insurance found the amount of home burglary claims it received in 2009 was 9 percent higher than the previous year. The areas with the biggest increases of home theft were the Rio Grande Valley (55 percent) and Austin (47 percent). El Paso actually saw a decrease of 16 percent.

Texas police departments told the insurance company the items most often stolen from homes included flat screen televisions, laptops, jewelry, and cash. Criminals will often have "shopping lists" of items to take from people's homes.

Allstate agent David Christopher said that "not only do these home burglaries disrupt homeowners' lives because their valuables are stolen, but they create a potentially dangerous situation if the theft is interrupted. That's why it's so important for homeowners to take precautions because these thefts can happen anywhere."

Homeowners can protect their property by always locking up when leaving home, not publicizing their plans on a social networking site and storing their possessions in a safe, Allstate said. One of the best deterrents for a home invasion is to invest in an alarm system.

There are a number of different alarm systems to suit every homeowner's security needs.
fields.summary: A recent report has found Texas homes are increasingly being burglarized.

fields.heading: Safe off-campus living
fields.content:
Being able to live off-campus while attending college is something that most students eagerly look forward to. When they move from dorm life to apartment living, certain precautions must be taken.

With close to 2,400 non-campus burglaries reported by U.S. colleges during 2008, it's important that students take their safety seriously. One of the most important tips is for people to always be aware of their surroundings, All Home Security advised. Walking in well-lit areas will help with this. If an apartment complex lacks sufficient lighting, the property manager should be notified.

Students should always tell a friend or roommate of their plans in the event that something goes awry, All Home Security said. Valuables also shouldn't be in plain sight to those outside of the apartment. Curtains and blinds should be used to block people from seeing inside a living space, and electronics such as laptops and MP3 players should be kept in a locked bedroom when not at home.

If a home security system isn't installed in the apartment, students should encourage their property managers to purchase one, All Home Security said.

Other off-campus safety tips include traveling in groups when possible and not to listening to music while running outdoors.
fields.summary: Being able to live off-campus while attending college is something that most students eagerly look forward to. When they move from dorm life to apartment living, certain precautions must be taken.

fields.heading: Burglars reveal their tricks
fields.content:
If people really want to know what burglars look for when robbing a home, all they need to do is ask. That's what one insurance company did.

By interviewing ex-burglars, insurance company MORE TH>N was able to compile the types of things people most often do that unintentionally invite an invader into their home. One-third of these criminals will target residences that are detached houses or bungalows because they are easiest to steal from. Leaving packaging from pricey purchases out with the trash also acts as signal.

If people think their neighbors will act as a deterrent, they should think again. These criminals told MORE TH>N that neighbors are more likely to "to pretend not to notice rather than 'make a fuss' and call the police."

Former burglar Richard Taylor said that "homeowners should sit up and take note of these results, the importance of home security cannot be overlooked, yet surprisingly many homeowners fail to take even the simplest precautions to protect themselves."

Consumers may want to consider investing a home security system. Not only will it deter burglars, but it will likely lower homeowners or renters insurance costs.
fields.summary: If people really want to know what burglars look for when robbing a home, all they need to do is ask. That's what one insurance company did.

fields.heading: Clever ways to protect possessions not always the most effective
fields.content:
When protecting a person's residence and possessions from a possible home invasion, there are number of options available. Some people are taking a unique approach to hide their belongings from burglars.

Some people have resorted to using decoy doors, burying their valuables in the garden and even sewing jewelery into the curtains, financial website Every Investor said. However, these clever attempts at fooling burglars often backfire.

Hiscox senior risk and valuation adviser Andrew Cheney told the financial website that "homeowners can be quite creative in their attempts at securing their valuables. However, many of their inventive hiding places are quite obvious to most thieves, and there's also the danger of forgetting them."

Instead of hiding valuables, Cheney advises consumers to try and keep burglars from being able to get into the home to begin with. Trees and shrubbery, along with fences and walls are the first line of defense for a home, Hiscox reported. Doors should have deadlocks; valuables need to be locked in a safe; and timer-operated lights make others think a person is home when they are out.

Consumers may also want to consider investing in a home security system to ward off potential home invasions.
fields.summary: When protecting a person's residence and possessions from a possible home invasion, there are number of options available. Some people are taking a unique approach to hide their belongings from burglars.

fields.heading: Daytime break-ins not uncommon
fields.content:
Consumers may be under the impression that home invaders only attack when it gets dark. However, recent reports from across the country prove that daytime break-ins are becoming more common.

Reports have been coming in from Vermont, North Carolina and Mississippi about how daytime home invasions have been increasing recently. Police in all areas have been issuing warnings to its residents to take extra precautions in safeguarding their homes.

"They're climbing through windows, removing air conditioners to get in," community policing coordinator Tim Tuttle told Vermont's Rutland Herald. "Believe it or not, in some cases people just leave their doors unlocked and they walk in," he added.

Even residents with locked doors aren't completely safe. Burglars have successfully broken into Mississippi apartments that were locked, the Madison County Journal reported. No sign of forced entry was seen.

In Greenville, North Carolina, CBS news affiliate WNTC 9 reported that 50 percent of all home invasions in the area take place during the day.

If homeowners would like to take extra precautions to protect their belongings, they should consider investing in home security systems. Apartment renters should encourage property owners to install these alarm systems as well.
fields.summary: Consumers may be under the impression that home invaders only attack when it gets dark. However, recent reports from across the country prove that daytime break-ins are becoming more common.

fields.heading: Ensuring home safety while on vacation
fields.content:
It's normal for people to worry about the safety of their home while they are away on vacation. That's why one Oregon police force has started patrolling properties of residents that are out of town.

The Beaverton Police Department began a new service this month for local residents who will be out of town for anywhere between one and three weeks. The Vacation Check Program is free and ensures that police officers will check on a home while the occupants are away.

"Home security is a basic component of crime prevention and the police department would like to help make your vacation time worry free," a statement from the Beaverton Police Department said. "When citizens are on vacation, their homes can become a target for burglars."

This home security service is offered by police departments all over the country. Consumers should check with their local force about whether a similar program is offered.

Vacationers may want to consider taking further precautions against possible home invasions. Burglar alarms are an effective tool against preventing break-ins.
fields.summary: It's normal for people to worry about the safety of their home while they are away on vacation. That's why one Oregon police force has started patrolling properties of residents that are out of town.

fields.heading: Neighbors banding together against home invaders
fields.content:
One Alabama neighborhood has been targeted by home invaders, and its residents are growing tired of being the victims.

One section of a Huntsville neighborhood has been hit with a rash of home burglaries lately, according to NBC news affiliate WAFF 48 News. Two houses had their windows knocked out by burglars, and a number of others have experienced break-ins as well.

Huntsville resident Jeanetta Maddox told the news station that "we are fed up with what is going on in our neighborhood. We got strong neighbors looking out for each other, and if you are going to break into someone's house, we are going to catch you just like the police are going to catch you."

While these Alabama neighbors may be banding together to fight crime, a recent report found that just the opposite is likely to be true. Ex-burglars told interviewers that neighbors are more likely to turn a blind eye when witnessing another person's home invasion rather than report it to the police.

To prevent windows from being smashed in, consumers should consider using glass protection. They may also want to consider installing home security systems as an added buffer.
fields.summary: One Alabama neighborhood has been targeted by home invaders, and its residents are growing tired of being the victims.

fields.heading: Evaluating home alarm systems
fields.content:
Measuring the effectiveness of burglar alarms can sometimes be tricky. However, new researchers from the University of North Carolina - Charlotte believe they have uncovered the best way how.

The purpose of the study was find to out how to best reduce police dispatches to burglar alarms. Using an approach called the "alarm factor," researchers were able to determine how many times police officers were sent to a home for a false alarm. Tracking this factor helps communities by letting them compare their rates to other cities and figuring out what the best ways are to improve the system, the Alarm Industry Research and Education Foundation said.

Key author of the report and assistant professor in the Department of Criminal Justice and Criminology Kristie Blevins said that "alarm systems are a proven method of protecting life and property. One of the advantages of this method is that a jurisdiction can accurately track its false alarm factor over time to see if the number of false alarms per registered user has changed."

While investing in a security system is a proven way to deter home invasions, the decision about what type to install should be made only after careful research and consultation of a professional.
fields.summary: Measuring the effectiveness of burglar alarms can sometimes be tricky. However, new researchers from the University of North Carolina - Charlotte believe they have uncovered the best way how.

fields.heading: NBA star's home burglarized
fields.content:
Last week, Charlotte Bobcats team member Stephen Jackson's home was broken into.

Not only was the NBA star's home invaded, but there was also an armed robbery with reports of three masked gunman. Jackson was not home, but his wife was. She wasn't hurt, but she was forced into a bathroom while a number of items were stolen.

ESPN columnist Jemele Hill later tweeted that this is an example of why athletes carry guns, which sparked a bit of a controversy on BleacherReport.com. Michael Schottey, a writer for the website, insisted that investing in a home security system is better than resort to using a gun for protection against a home invasion.

"Feeling safe with a gun in the home is a false sense of security that is so ignorant, so dangerous, words hardly describe it," Schottey wrote on BleacherReport.com. "A home security system with a loud, active alarm system that is also connected to a monitoring center can stop an intruder in his tracks." Schottey believes that a burglar is less likely to face off with a police officer than they would with a gun-wielding home resident.

Security systems are a worthwhile investment and are equipped to protect everyone from NBA stars to middle-class consumers.
fields.summary: Last week, Charlotte Bobcats team member Stephen Jackson's home was broken into.

fields.heading: Keeping pets safe during a fire
fields.content:
A home fire can be devastating, and losing a loved pet during one can only exacerbate the matter.

There are a number of things that people can do to keep themselves and their pets safe in the event of a home fire. The most important of which is having a monitored smoke detector that is connected to a monitoring system, the Ridgewood News reported. This provides "an added layer of protection beyond battery-operated smoke alarms."

There are also some preventative measures that people can do in order to protect their pets. A pet should never be left alone near an open flame, the Ridgewood News said. Homes should also be pet-proofed so that fires aren't accidentally started by someone's cat or dog.

When away from home, pet owners should also make sure their animals don't have access to things that are potential fire-starting hazards, according to the Ridgewood News. An escape route should also be in place and practiced with a pet in the event that a fire does occur.

When purchasing home alarm systems, consumers should check with the product developers about whether a fire protection system is included.
fields.summary: A home fire can be devastating, and losing a loved pet during one can only exacerbate the matter.

fields.heading: How to handle a home security door-to-door salesperson
fields.content:
While door-to-door sales pitches aren't as common as they used to be, they do still occasionally occur.

Now is peak season for home security systems, which means it's likely door-to-door salespeople will be knocking on many consumers' doors. Although some recent news reports have found some companies are using pushy tactics, consumers should use their best judgement when dealing with salespeople.

If approached by one of these salespeople, consumers should always ask about licensing and to get a thorough explanation of how the alarm system works, police Sargent Dean Jantzen told BCLocalNews.com. "If it's an alarm company, they have to produce their government license, company identification and their business licence," he added. "And if the salesman doesn't leave your home when you ask, call the police."

Asking for time to consider the purchase is also a smart move. This way, research can be done to find out if this product is something worth spending money on.

Whether someone buys a home security system from a door-to-door salesperson, online or from a retail store, it's always a good idea to compare safety features and pricing with other products.
fields.summary: While door-to-door sales pitches aren't as common as they used to be, they do still occasionally occur.

fields.heading: Does warmer weather equal more crime?
fields.content:
Some people believe that crimes, such as home invasions, are much more likely to occur during warmer weather months. But exactly how true can that be?

The Wall Street Journal recently analyzed New York police department crime data and came to the conclusion that the popular warm-weather, higher-crime rate correlation isn't exactly accurate. The most popular month for criminal activity was September, followed by August, October, July, and then December.

Indiana's Ball State University associate professor of criminology Jerome McKean told the Journal that an increase in temperature and crime are definitely linked to one another. "The peak months for most forms of crime are July and August, especially for property crimes." The reason for this is because most of the burglars, whose average age is 16, are out of school for the summer while a larger number of people are away on vacation.

If consumers want to protect their home while away on vacation during the summer months, they may want to consider investing in home security systems. They'll need one with a loud alarm and that is monitored by a security service.
fields.summary: Some people believe that crimes, such as home invasions, are much more likely to occur during warmer weather months. But exactly how true can that be?

fields.heading: Adding outdoor lighting for home security
fields.content:
When considering the variety of options for home security, one thing that most consumers might overlook is the benefit of having sufficient outdoor lighting.

When shopping for an alarm system, a person should also seriously consider having outdoor lighting installed. Some experts believe that the chance of a home being robbed is reduced by 50 to 70 percent with the addition of outdoor lighting, the Asheville Citizen-Times reported.

Whether someone installs outdoor lighting themselves or hires a professional to do it, this may be one investment that all homeowners should consider. Heinzman Lights at Night owner Mark Heinzman told the Citizen-Times that "landscape lighting has grown so much in the last 10 years that what people used to feel was only a rich-person's game has now gotten to the point that it can fit anybody's budget. My jobs have ranged anywhere from $500 to $120,000."

Those who do install an outdoor lighting system may also be concerned about how environmentally friendly it is. They can save money and energy by using LED bulbs, the Citizen-Times said.

If considering outdoor lighting for their home, consumers should always compare systems and prices for the best value and quality.
fields.summary: When considering the variety of options for home security, one thing that most consumers might overlook is the benefit of having sufficient outdoor lighting.

fields.heading: Participate in a night out against crime
fields.content:
Next week, on Tuesday, August 3rd, people all over the country will be participating in America's Night Out Against Crime - an annual event running in its 27th year.

Over 36 million people from 15,000 communities are expected participate in this event against crime, according to the National Association of Town Watch. There will also be people from Canada, U.S. territories and military bases from all over the world taking part in the affair.

Event creator and national project coordinator Matt Peskin said that "this is a night for neighborhoods nationwide to come out and stand united against crime. National Night Out offers an extraordinary opportunity for citizens, community groups, law enforcement and local officials to get out, meet, greet and discuss local safety issues."

The national event will include front porch vigils, the traditional "lights on", visits from local sheriff and police departments and crime prevention block parties, the National Association of Town Watch said. There will also be flashlight walks, essay and poster contests and safety fairs.

Home security is a valid concern for consumers. While attending one of the Night Out events, they may want to get information about alarm systems for their homes.
fields.summary: Next week, on Tuesday, August 3rd, people all over the country will be participating in America's Night Out Against Crime - an annual event running in its 27th year.

fields.heading: Poor economy drives up sales of home security systems
fields.content:
A poor economy doesn't always equal bad business for everyone. With rising crime rates, the sale of home security systems has gone up.

One Hawaii-based home security installation company owner said his business has grown by 20 percent in the last year, the Pacific Business News reported. The island state is known for its property crime history, which constituted 93 percent of all incidents in 2008.

Steve Van Ness, another home security company owner told the Business News that "business is fueled by two things: new growth - when the economy is doing well, people are building new homes - and crime. When the economy is bad, people will do whatever it takes to survive."

New trends in the home security business include video surveillance, the Business News said. However, most systems should have motion detectors and an alarm. People can expect to pay anywhere between $1,400 and $5,000.

Summer is also popular for daytime home invasions. This is because most burglars, whose average age is 16, don't have to school to attend to during the day.
fields.summary: A poor economy doesn't always equal bad business for everyone. With rising crime rates, the sale of home security systems has gone up.

fields.heading: Home alarm systems prevent and alert residents to fires
fields.content:
Having a home security monitoring system can mean the difference between life and death.

There have been recent reports of home alarm systems either alerting residents to fires or preventing the blazes entirely. The safety of a person's home and their family could rely upon whether they have one of these installed in their residence.

In the case of one Shafter, California resident, the person was alerted to fire blazing in their residence by their home security company, BakersfieldNow.com reported. The resident of the home was able to escape uninjured thanks to the monitoring service.

A fire was prevented entirely in a London home thanks to a monitored alarm system, Direct Response Security said. An un-extinguished cigarette was about to cause a fire when the home's owner received a call from her security company about smoke being detected on her property.

Direct Response Security managing director David Price said "this incident once again underlines the importance of a monitored alarm system. A monitored security system provides 24-hour protection, regardless of whether someone is at home or not."

It's important to discuss all home security options available with an expert when deciding what system is best suited for a person's home.
fields.summary: Having a home security monitoring system can mean the difference between life and death.

fields.heading: Local sheriff and police departments educating residents about crime
fields.content:
Being educated about crime is one of many steps that a consumer should take in order to further prevent their home from being invaded.

Communities across the country are taking an extra step to make sure their residents know what precautionary measures to take by having their local sheriff and police departments educate the public.

In Washington County Oregon, the local sheriff's department is sending out its crime prevention team to give "presentations on personal safety, home security, identity theft and Neighborhood Watch programs," the Oregonian reported. They are also visiting safety events and setting up crime prevention booths to offer information to residents about how to keep their homes and their families safe.

In Lincoln, Maine, the local police department created a citizens police academy to teach residents how to "form block watches and community patrols to prevent crime," the Bangor Daily News said. There has been a rash of burglaries in the area since the beginning of June, and law enforcement hopes these efforts will make people more aware of what to look out for.

Consumers may also want to consider investing in a home security system for their residence as an added layer of protection against robberies.
fields.summary: Being educated about crime is one of many steps that a consumer should take in order to further prevent their home from being invaded.

fields.heading: Home security tips for apartment renters
fields.content:
Apartment dwellers may be leaving signs to welcome burglars and not even know it.

Those renting a place are actually 85 percent more likely to experience a home invasion than those who own one, SimpliSafe said citing National Crime Prevention Council data. There are certain signs that those living in an apartment should be aware attract burglars.

The first is if a mailbox name tag only has one resident listed, SimpliSafe said. This lets burglars know who's home alone at night. Mail piling up also lets invaders know when a person is out of town.

Not having a peephole on the front door gives criminals an extra license to misrepresent themselves when people ask who's at their door. Dark windows are also a calling sign for someone who isn't home, SimpliSafe said. Apartments that have windows with fire escapes also attract burglars. They are usually unlocked and offer an easy escape route.

If a person's apartment doesn't have a home security system, they should ask the property manager about installing one. If this isn't something they're willing to pay for, tenants may want to consider taking on the expense themselves.
fields.summary: Apartment dwellers may be leaving signs to welcome burglars and not even know it.

fields.heading: Home security plans necessary for all families
fields.content:
Ensuring the safety of a person's family and their home can seem like a daunting task, but it doesn't have to be.

There are a myriad of home security options available for people living in every income bracket. But no matter what, every family should have a home security plan, expert Robert Siciliano recently wrote for the Huffington Post.

He offered a number of different suggestions, but the one that seemed most applicable to families was to never let children open the door in a home. Siciliano insisted that adults should be the only people to do that. He also advised to never talk to strangers through a screen, to always do so from behind a locked door.

Siciliano also suggested having a trained German Shepherd and having a safe, or panic, room in the home. This is a bullet proof area that has wireless communication devices so help can be contacted. One of the most important tips offered is to invest in a home alarm system and to install security cameras.

Before investing in home security devices, consumers should perform thorough research on the company they are purchasing them from.
fields.summary: Ensuring the safety of a person's family and their home can seem like a daunting task, but it doesn't have to be.

fields.heading: How to keep a home safe while on vacation
fields.content:
While countless people are spending the summer vacationing, they may not know that their homes are being burglarized. This is high season for home invasions, and people need to take certain steps to protect their property.

Washington, D.C. Police Chief Cathy Lanier told the Washington Post that residents need to "reduce the opportunity. People don't just walk down the street and decide 'I'm going to hit your home today.' They do some casing."

When going away on vacation, residents should leave a car parked in their driveway so it looks as if someone is home, the newspaper reported. They should also stop mail and newspaper delivery. A pileup of these materials is tell-tale sign that someone is on vacation. If gone for an extended period of time, people should ask a neighbor to mow their lawn. An unkempt yard is an invitation for a home invasion. Homeowners or renters should also never forget to lock all of their windows and doors.

Some police departments offer a vacation check-in service for vacationing residents. This is an extra step of protection that shouldn't be overlooked.
fields.summary: While countless people are spending the summer vacationing, they may not know that their homes are being burglarized. This is high season for home invasions, and people need to take certain steps to protect their property.

fields.heading: Senior citizens can prevent a home invasion
fields.content:
When it comes to making sure a burglar doesn't break into a person's home, some of those who may feel the most vulnerable are senior citizens. However, there are some things they can do to protect themselves and their property.

Senior citizens may be a particular target for criminals looking to steal prescription medications, the Area Agency on Aging District 7 said. To prevent this, they should lock all medicine away and keep them out of sight. It may also be wise to ask their doctor if their prescriptions have any "street value."

They should also never leave spare house keys hidden under doormats or in planters and mailboxes, AAA7 advised. Those delivering items to senior citizen's homes should always be asked to provide proper identification.

For added protection against burglars, senior citizens may want to consider installing home security systems. There are a wide variety and can be easily researched online. They may also want to have an expert visit their home and advise them on which type of service would be most beneficial to them.
fields.summary: When it comes to making sure a burglar doesn't break into a person's home, some of those who may feel the most vulnerable are senior citizens. However, there are some things they can do to protect themselves and their property.

fields.heading: Economic downturn results in increased home security system sales
fields.content:
Down economic periods appear to result in more people purchasing home security systems to protect both themselves and their property.

Crime rates go up during periods of economic difficulty, especially when it comes to home invasions, according to InstantSpy.net. Some experts see this correlation as interesting information since consumers are less likely to spend during hard financial times. However, protecting against a home invasion is seen by many as essential area of investment.

InstantSpy.net's managing director said that "I believe that in times of hardship, people are much more likely to commit crimes, poverty increases and so do the chances of suffering a home invasion. People are willing to invest on an alarm system or surveillance system simply because they feel the need for protection at the moment."

Home security systems have come a long way since they were first developed, InstantSpy.net said. They are much more user-friendly and easier to install than they were in the past.

If a person isn't quite sure if they want to invest in a burglar alarm, they should contact their local police department and ask about crime rates in their neighborhood.
fields.summary: Down economic periods appear to result in more people purchasing home security systems to protect both themselves and their property.

fields.heading: Security risks abound for vacant homes
fields.content:
When someone moves out of one home for another, they usually sold the first residence before leaving. However, in some circumstances - such as a hard-to-sell house - residences are left vacant, which can be a security risk for properties.

If a vacant home is not kept up to look as if someone is living in it, burglars are much more likely to strike. Signs such an overgrown lawn, a dark house and an overflowing mailbox serve as welcome mats for criminals, the National Association of Insurance Commissioners said.

If an unforeseen disaster such as fire occurs in a vacant home, there also isn't anyone there to call in emergency officials. "A manageable problem - such as a small electrical fire - can turn into a much larger, more costly disaster," the NAIC said.

However, if a person has a home security monitoring system installed and keeps the service intact until the vacant home is sold, it's much less likely that home invasion will occur or that officials won't be alerted to a fire.
fields.summary: When someone moves out of one home for another, they usually sold the first residence before leaving. However, in some circumstances - such as a hard-to-sell house - residences are left vacant, which can be a security risk for properties.

fields.heading: Creating DIY home security systems
fields.content:
Summer is the peak season for home invasions, and while burglar alarms are a great deterrent, there are also some do-it-yourself options to prevent criminals from entering a person's home.

There a number of low-cost things a person can do to make their home more safe. One of the most common is to use a sturdy piece of wood to keep a window or sliding glass door from being opened, CafeMom.com said. People can also stack pennies on top of a vertically-opening window that will cause noise if opened. Consumers can also purchase reasonably priced battery-operated wireless window alarms and a door stopper alarm.

If someone wants to spend a little bit more money, they can purchase a wireless GE home security system that can be easily installed. There are also several home security system packages available from Protect America that are free when service is paid for.

DIY home security systems will be the most effective when all family members know how to use them properly.
fields.summary: Summer is the peak season for home invasions, and while burglar alarms are a great deterrent, there are also some do-it-yourself options to prevent criminals from entering a person's home.

fields.heading: Homeowner regrets refusing home security system offer
fields.content:
It's not uncommon for homeowners to receive knocks on their doors during the summer from home security door-to-door salespeople. It's a prime time for home invasions.

One man rejected the offer of a home security monitoring system when a salesman came knocking on his door. Soon after, his residence was burglarized while he was away from home for a work commitment, Alaskan news source, the Peninsula Clarion reported.

The homeowner, Neil Robertson, already had a video surveillance system installed and believed that was all the home security he needed, according to the Peninsula Clarion. While the tapes may be helpful in identifying who the thieves are, they weren't able to alert authorities when the home invasion took place.

"Certainly a monthly service might have paid for itself," Robertson told the news source. "I consider myself pretty security conscious, but how far do you go?" The homeowner is now seriously considering making additions to his home security system.

Having a monitored home security device can alert law enforcement to home invasions as well as other incidents such as a potential fire.
fields.summary: It's not uncommon for homeowners to receive knocks on their doors during the summer from home security door-to-door salespeople. It's a prime time for home invasions.

fields.heading: New social networking utility for crime information
fields.content:
Consumers will now be able to use social networking services to discuss neighborhood crime activity.

CrimeReports.com recently launched an update of their website, which will allow consumers to use social networking platforms, such as Twitter and Facebook, to keep up to date with local crime activity. Law enforcement will also be using these tools to expand their community outreach programs.

CrimeReports.com founder and CEO Greg Whisenant said "this is the first social networking tool designed specifically to meet the needs of law enforcement agencies and the communities they serve. This newest product innovation was developed in conjunction with our law enforcement partners to provide world class crime-fighting tools while considering the demands of an increasingly social and tech-savvy public."

Consumers can also use CrimeReports.com's integration of social networking sites to discuss the different types of home security systems that work best for them. There are a variety of options that range from do-it-yourself projects to security cameras to more involved monitored devices that can quickly get in touch with local police and fire officials.
fields.summary: Consumers will now be able to use social networking services to discuss neighborhood crime activity.

fields.heading: Home burglary trend: Bumping
fields.content:
A recent home burglary trend has been popping up across the country, catching both consumers and law enforcement by surprise.

Most people may think that an ordinary lock on their doors is enough protection from home invaders. However, these criminals are proving that they are much savvier than these basic mechanisms. They are using a technique called "bumping" to break through this first line of home defense, according to the National Crime Prevention Council.

It turns out that bumping is a much easier and effective way for picking a lock. "All that is needed for bumping is a 'bump key' that is specially manipulated to pick the lock without other tools," the NCPC said. "This is a huge problem because usually there are no signs of a break-in when bumping is done." There are even "how-to" videos on the internet to teach criminals this popular technique.

The NCPC said that insurance companies are less likely to cover a home invasion if bumping is used as the method of entry because it appears that the door was left open. One way to combat bumping is to install higher quality locks to protect against burglars.

Consumers may also want to consider investing in a monitored home security system.
fields.summary: A recent home burglary trend has been popping up across the country, catching both consumers and law enforcement by surprise.

fields.heading: Consider home security before going on vacation
fields.content:
A lot of preparation goes into getting ready for a vacation. Something that people should never forget is how secure their home will be while they are gone.

Before giving a burglar the opportunity to invade a person's home while they are away on vacation, there are certain things that should be considered, according to Pennsylvania's BerksmontNews.com. Exeter Township Police Department Crime Prevention Officer David Behm told the news source that "bad guys look for any opportunity to prey on the innocent. Unless precautions are taken, an unoccupied home can present a tempting target."

Letting trusted people know when a person is going to be on vacation is one way to protect a home, BerksmontNews.com said. This could be done by both getting a house sitter and filing a vacation report with the local police department. People should also always leave some lights on to give the impression someone is home. Other advice includes stopping mail and newspaper delivery and investing in good door locks.

The best investment could be a home security monitoring system. These allow quick response times if it's believed a person's place is being burglarized.
fields.summary: A lot of preparation goes into getting ready for a vacation. Something that people should never forget is how secure their home will be while they are gone.

fields.heading: Home security systems protect against crime
fields.content:
Knowing that a person's home is safe and guarded against an invasion can give someone peace of mind. There are number of different ways in which a homeowner or a renter can protect their possessions and family from crime.

Residential crime rates have increased recently, and home alarm systems can help protect against a burglar. "Above all, it is a wise investment to make as these security systems makes your home completely safe against every risk or problems," Home Security Systems Outlet said. "Before deciding upon any security system, it is important for you to decide your requirements first."

Home security systems can be both internal and external. The variety of options vary in price, but there is an option for every income level, Home Security Systems Outlet said. There are highly technical and basic systems to suit everyone's different needs. Home security monitoring systems are some of the best and most effective forms of protection around.

Consumers may want to consult friends and family members who have burglar alarms for any recommendations.
fields.summary: Knowing that a person's home is safe and guarded against an invasion can give someone peace of mind. There are number of different ways in which a homeowner or a renter can protect their possessions and family from crime.

fields.heading: Home security systems can lower homeowners insurance costs
fields.content:
There are a number of things that consumers can do to lower the cost of their homeowners insurance. One of those options will not only save them money, but will also provide increased protection against potential burglars.

Taking measures to secure a home against a break-in can reduce the cost of homeowners insurance, according to real estate news website HousingPredictor.com. Something as simple as having dead bolt locks put on exterior doors can save a person as much as 5 percent off of their policy. More savings can be had if home alarm systems are installed - anywhere from 15 to 20 percent. Speaking with an insurer can give a homeowner a better idea of what kind of savings they can expect.

Taking into account the different home security measures available is something that should always be considered by new homeowners. Swinton Insurance development manager Steve Chelton said that "to keep the premiums down, we suggest that you change the locks as soon as you move in and install a good home security system."
fields.summary: There are a number of things that consumers can do to lower the cost of their homeowners insurance. One of those options will not only save them money, but will also provide increased protection against potential burglars.

fields.heading: Rise in crime leads to safety seminars
fields.content:
Georgia's Moultrie-Colquitt County has seen a recent rise in violent crimes and theft, which has led public officials to hold safety seminars for its residents.

This isn't an uncommon seasonal occurrence. Summer is well-known throughout public safety and security communities as the peak time for home invasions. To combat this rise in area crime, Colquitt County Sheriff's Office will hold classes on home and personal safety, the Moultrie Observer reported.

A variety of safety measures can be learned from these classes. Because firearm protection will be taught in these free seminars, all participants must be over 21 years old. "These training seminars will cover realistic and legal ways to protect your home and property, as well as ways to protect yourself and family while at home and away from home," the Observer said. "Discussions will also include home security measures and personal security measures, with the main emphasis being on crime prevention."

In addition to attending a firearms protection seminar, people may want to consider taking a personal defense course as a measure against a possible home invasion or other attack.
fields.summary: Georgia's Moultrie-Colquitt County has seen a recent rise in violent crimes and theft, which has led public officials to hold safety seminars for its residents.

fields.heading: Preventing a home invasion
fields.content:
When it comes to protecting a person's property, there are certain preventive measures that can be taken.

While nothing is 100 percent effective, some safety tips help reduce the risk of a home invasion, the Calderon Enterprise reported. It's often the simple things that people forget to do, such as lock a door, that allows a criminal to enter onto someone's property. Taking a few minutes of every day can be all that is necessary to ensure a safe home.

Safety official Rose DiMarco told the Enterprise "the best protection is prevention. It is important ... to get into the habit of locking your doors, windows and garages before you leave the house for the day." DiMarco advised making these safety tips part of a person's morning routine.

When going away on vacation, it's also important for residents to make their home like someone is there, the Enterprise said. This can be done leaving a garden hose or lawn chair on porch to make it look like a person is at home. Neighbors can also check on a residence while the inhabitants are away.

A good investment may be a home security monitoring system. This can alert officials to danger in one's home.
fields.summary: When it comes to protecting a person's property, there are certain preventive measures that can be taken.

fields.heading: Home security is a must-have
fields.content:
When it comes to home security measures for a person's home, some experts are saying there is no excuse for lacking this sort of protection.

Some consumers may think that they can't afford the best home security system, but there are a number of different products to fit every person's budget, Crime Prevention Products said. There are even some do-it-yourself options that don't require any or much money at all.

"The majority of burglaries are carried out by opportunistic criminals who notice weak points in a property that won't take much fuss to break into, such as easily opened windows, doors and garages," Crime Prevention Products said.

Obvious access points, such as windows and doors, should be the most secure in a person's home, according to Crime Prevention Products. Keeping a residence brightly lit is also a deterrent for criminals. If a consumer wants the best protection available, they need to look into having either a wireless or hard wired home security system installed.

One cheap DIY measure is to stack pennies on top of a closed window, so that if opened, a lot of noise is made to scare off the burglar and alert the resident.
fields.summary: When it comes to home security measures for a person's home, some experts are saying there is no excuse for lacking this sort of protection.

fields.heading: Lexington police seeing rash of garage break-ins
fields.content:
Police in Lexington, Kentucky, say they have seen more than 80 recent cases of local burglaries in which the thieves entered a home through a garage door which is partially or fully open.

Officers say that the items taken are often small and within easy reach, such as tools, sporting equipment or alcohol. In addition, the cases are often tough to prosecute because the thieves leave very little trace.

"Whether you're going to the store for a few minutes, whether you're going to a neighbor's house, keep those garage doors closed," Officer Bige Towery told the Lexington Herald-Leader.

Police added that they have made it a point to try and notify residents if they see an open garage door while on patrol.

The city's police department has also released a brochure for area residents to give them tips on how to avoid the problem, including changing the key code on their garage door opener after purchasing it, keeping the door closed and keeping small items in a locked area.
fields.summary: Police in Lexington, Kentucky, say they have seen more than 80 recent cases of local burglaries in which the thieves entered a home through a garage door which is partially or fully open.

fields.heading: Centralia property crime shows drastic spike
fields.content:
Residents in Centralia, Washington, are dealing with a severe increase in crime.

Property crime in the city has shot up 72 percent in the first half of this year and has reached its highest rate in five years.

Burglaries and thefts, many of which might have been prevented with a home security system, made up much of the increase, the Chronicle reports. While there were 270 thefts and 55 burglaries in the first six months of last year, there have been 475 thefts and 118 burglaries.

The city's police chief told the paper that the statistics were "not very comforting" and that residents should take care to lock their property and not leave valuables in cars where they can be easily spotted.

While property crime in the city spiked, violent crime has remained comparatively stable this year, but has also shown a 13 percent increase.

As a whole, the state has a long history of high property crime rates, although it has improved slightly recently. In 2005, the state had the highest rate of property crime in the country. By 2008, it had dropped to 37th.
fields.summary: Residents in Centralia, Washington, are dealing with a severe increase in crime.

fields.heading: California suspect arrested after being caught on home security cameras
fields.content:
A California man is now facing burglary charges after he allegedly broke into a home in Carmichael, California, earlier this month, and was caught on nine security cameras which were part of the owner's home security system.

Security footage from the home was shown on several local television stations, prompting a number of area residents to call police.

When officers arrived at the house, they also recognized the suspect from the footage. In addition, police found numerous items from the burglary both inside the suspect's vehicle and pockets, more than a week after the original crime.

The suspect, 28-year-old Joshua Lowe, has been charged with burglary and stolen property charges, and was denied bail. Earlier reports on the burglary said that Lowe had made off with roughly $80,000 worth of jewelry and other items, including a gun.

The suspect certainly picked the wrong house to rob. KOVR-TV in Sacramento, California, reports that the homeowner whose house was broken into sells and installs home security cameras for a living.
fields.summary: A California man is now facing burglary charges after he allegedly broke into a home in Carmichael, California earlier this month, and was caught on nine security cameras which were part of the owner's home security system.

fields.heading: Houston sees rise in thefts and burglaries
fields.content:
While the city of Houston has seen a significant drop in violent crime over the past year, it has also seen an increase in the number of thefts and burglaries in the city, the Houston Chronicle reports.

Over the past year, the paper reports that even though police have seen an 8 percent drop in violent crimes, they have also recorded a 1.7 percent increase in the number of thefts, and a 1.2 percent rise in burglaries.

"The drivers of the crime rate in the city of Houston are two offenses - burglaries and thefts. They represent at least … 70 percent of the crime in the city of Houston," Houston Police Department executive assistant chief Timothy Oettmeier told the paper

Crime records also show that the city has a poor record of apprehending the culprits in these crimes, which may have been prevented if the homes had an operating home security system. The paper reports that officers clear an arrest in just 8 percent of burglary cases and 15 percent of thefts.

Officers hope the deployment of a new online crime-fighting tool will help them improve that rate, according to the Tribune. Detectives say the LeadsOnline tool allows them to quickly track down leads, and has been instrumental in a number of recent arrests.
fields.summary: While the city of Houston has seen a significant drop in violent crime over the past year, it has also seen an increase in the number of thefts and burglaries in the city, the Houston Chronicle reports.

fields.heading: Home security system important during retirement
fields.content:
When people retire, they have a number of things they want to accomplish. According to the Richmond Times-Dispatch, having a home security system can help relax both them and their loved ones.

Having added security, the paper writes, like motion-activated lights or a home alarm system, can help make a home feel more secure, and give friends and family assurances that older relatives are doing well without feeling like they have to check in too frequently.

An alarm system can also help put retirees at ease while traveling, because they know that nothing has gone wrong at their home while they are away. Even if something does happen, they know that the alarm system will let them know right away so they won't worry.

While retirees have always been associated with high amounts of travel, a new survey by Mainstay Investments finds that travel is becoming increasingly important among baby boomers. Fifty percent said that taking at least one family vacation a year was a basic need during retirement and not a luxury.
fields.summary: When people retire, they have a number of things they want to accomplish. According to the Richmond Times-Dispatch, having a home security system can help relax both them and their loved ones.

fields.heading: Home alarm systems can offer security for seniors
fields.content:
Sometimes family members may be unsure about older relatives who are living alone. But simple security steps combined with a home security system make the difference that allows them to stay in their home.

In addition to make sure door and window locks are regularly fastened, motion-activated lights outside the home be an important security step. The lights can help deter potential burglars and also alert those inside that someone may be coming to the door.

A home alarm system can help many family members feel safer about their relatives. Many systems offer key chains or pendants which can allow seniors to alert police or emergency personnel in the case of a burglary or fall.

Seniors should also try and schedule at least one check-in - either in person or over the phone - every day to make sure that everything is going well and that nothing suspicious has been happening.

A growing number of crimes have focused on senior citizens - particularly financial scams. A survey earlier this year by Investor Protection Trust found that 20 percent of Americans over the age of 65 had been taken advantage of financially.
fields.summary: Sometimes family members may be unsure about older relatives who are living alone. But simple security steps combined with a home security system make the difference that allows them to stay in their home.

fields.heading: Home invasion suspect caught by security cameras
fields.content:
Police in Scranton, Pennsylvania, have a good look at the suspect in a home invasion at an elderly apartment complex - thanks to a number of security cameras inside, WNEP-TV reports.

One of the residents told officers that she was thrown against a wall when she confronted a man she found in her apartment. The suspect then ran off with her purse, but was captured on a number of security cameras. Police told the station that the victim wasn't seriously injured.

"Very scary. You know when you're alone in that apartment, somebody comes in," another resident of the complex, Beverly Ellis, told the station.

Police say the suspect managed to get buzzed into the complex by another resident by saying he was visiting his grandmother. The suspect is still on the loose.

Scranton is currently dealing with a growth of violent crime in the area. The Scranton Times Tribune reports that violent crime in the city jumped 19 percent last year, and has also risen in six of the past eight years.
fields.summary: Police in Scranton, Pennsylvania, have a good look at the suspect in a home invasion at an elderly apartment complex - thanks to a number of security cameras inside, WNEP-TV reports.

fields.heading: City creating database of area security cameras
fields.content:
The Woonsocket, Rhode Island police department hopes its new security camera protocol will help officers track down suspects before their trail goes cold.

WJAR-TV reports that police are working to compile a database with the location of all of the security cameras in the city - whether its from a home, business or other location. When a crime is committed in the area, they will be able to see what security cameras may have gotten a glimpse of the suspects, and ask the owners if they can see the video.

Officers told the station that the quick access will help them get a better start in their investigations.

"We know how valuable video surveillance is, we see it every day. There are numerous crimes where we've identified criminals with the video surveillance source," detective Eugene Jalette of the Woonsocket Police Department told the station.

The program also may help to curb the increasing trend of robberies in the state. According to the Rhode Island State Police, while there were less than 800 robberies last year, the state is already on pace to surpass that number by more than 10 percent in 2010.
fields.summary: The Woonsocket, Rhode Island police department hopes its new security camera protocol will help officers track down suspects before their trail goes cold.

fields.heading: Indiana Woman catches familiar burglar with home security cameras
fields.content:
When a pair of burglars stole more than $11,000 worth of property from her Indiana home, Keri McMullen posted photos of the suspects from her home security system online. But she later noticed that one of the suspects was one of her own Facebook friends.

Just a few hours after publishing the photos, one of her friends told her that one of the suspects she had caught on camera was an old childhood friend - who has been charged in more than 25 other crimes.

Earlier that night, she had posted a status update on her page saying she was going to a concert - perhaps giving the suspect notice that she wouldn't be home for the night.

"You don't know who all is looking at your private info there because it's really not private if you're on Facebook," Floyd County Sheriff Darrell Mills told WLUK-TV. "You're posting it for everyone."

McMullen told the station that she had just installed the security cameras less than a week before the robbery. Charges have been filed, but both suspects are still on the run.
fields.summary: When a pair of burglars stole more than $11,000 worth of property from her Indiana home, Keri McMullen posted photos of the suspects from her home security system online. But she later noticed that one of the suspects was one of her own Facebook friends.

fields.heading: Homeowners and neighbors need to work together to prevent crime
fields.content:
While burglaries in the Jacksonville, North Carolina, area have begun to dip since last year, police say that area residents need to stay vigilant.

Law enforcement officials told the Jacksonville Daily News that while promoting a neighborhood watch program is an effective tool in the fight against crime, alarms can be a more effective way to stop robberies.

"We have not had a break-in yet this year where the home had an alarm system," Onslow County sheriff Ed Brown told the paper. "There are inexpensive electronics out there that people can purchase to prevent them from becoming victims of break-ins."

Officials also cited a growing trend in which most new robbery victims were under the age of 30. In many of those cases, police told the paper that many of the suspects were people who knew the victim, and had been previously invited inside the house.

Officials have been working to crack down on the area's crime problems. Last month, three U.S. Marines were arrested for a crime spree in the area during which they stole seven cars along with multiple guns and computers.
fields.summary: While burglaries in the Jacksonville, North Carolina, area have begun to dip since last year, police say that area residents need to stay vigilant.

fields.heading: Security officials emphasize preparation to protect homes
fields.content:
The summer heat also brings an increased risk of home invasion. But security officials in Jacksonville, Tennessee, told WLVT-TV that preventative steps, such as getting a home security system, can stop crimes from even happening.

Officials emphasized the need for simple steps, like having - and using - locks on doors and windows and not storing expensive items in places that can be seen from the outside. A home alarm system can also be a deterrent.

"If they know you have a system, they'll go next door," Roger Houser, an employee at ETS Communications, told the station. "Why try yours if they know someone next door doesn't have one?"

Security companies have also begun putting GPS tracking devices on expensive items such as big-screen TVs or computers, so they can easily be found if they are ever stolen.

The city has seen its share of home invasions recently. Last month, two armed suspects broke into the home of an 82-year-old woman, tied her up and stole money from her home. Police were also working to determine if it was related to similar crimes in the area.
fields.summary: The summer heat also brings an increased risk of home invasion. But security officials in Jacksonville, Tennessee, told WLVT-TV that preventative steps, such as getting a home security system, can stop crimes from even happening.

fields.heading: Cameras reduce crime at Baltimore shopping centers
fields.content:
Many shopping centers in the Baltimore area have installed security cameras in recent years - and have seen a significant drop in crime.

The Baltimore Sun reports that shopping centers with cameras have seen violent crime drop by almost a third since 2006 - roughly twice the national rate of decline.

The city's police chief, Jim Johnson, told the paper that the security cameras had "contributed to the significant decreases in crime over the past three years" and were "a very valuable asset in obtaining evidence that has been used by our officers and detectives in solving crimes, and arresting those committing them."

The study of crime statistics examined crime rates at 42 shopping centers in the city. Since 2006, when the cameras were installed, assaults and robberies dropped 37 percent, murders dropped from three to one and there were no rapes.

Baltimore has earned a reputation as a violent city. Earlier this month the Sun reported that although the city saw its fewest number of murders in 20 years last year, it still has one of the highest murder rates in the country.
fields.summary: Many shopping centers in the Baltimore area have installed security cameras in recent years - and have seen a significant drop in crime.

fields.heading: Proposed ordinance would require security cameras for some businesses
fields.content:
A proposed bill in South Brunswick, New Jersey, would create and enforce a requirement for the installation of security cameras in many new businesses to discourage crime.

According to MyCentralJersey.com, the proposed bill would require banks, check-cashing businesses, convenience stores, gun shops and other places of business to install cameras on their property.

"We're looking at ensuring the security of not only the stores, but the employees and customers," Ron Schmalz, the township's public affairs coordinator, told the site.

The bill would apply only to new construction or businesses which have not received a certificate of occupancy, and not those already in operation.

The site reports that the bill is currently being redrafted to give a more specific definition of the types of businesses affected, because some lawmakers were concerned about the bill's impact on small businesses.

Officials are considering the bill even though South Brunswick has traditionally seen very little criminal activity. In 2008, the township was listed as one of the Best Places to Live by CNN Money, in part because of very low property crime rates.
fields.summary: A proposed bill in South Brunswick, New Jersey, would create and enforce a requirement for the installation of security cameras in many new businesses to discourage crime.

fields.heading: Davis officials seeing rise of daytime burglaries
fields.content:
Police in Davis, California, are warning residents about a sharp rise in the number of burglaries in the area, including a large number that are taking place during daylight hours.

Since the start of last month, officers say there have been 66 reported burglaries in the city - more than triple the 21 that were reported during the same period last year. Roughly one-third of those crimes are taking place during the daytime - considered between 7 a.m. and 6 p.m.

Police are warning residents to fully secure their house whenever they leave, because many of the incidents have involved burglars coming in through unlocked doors or windows that had been left open for ventilation in the summer heat and not protected by home security systems. In addition, they are asked to call police if they see anything suspicious, such as a vehicle driving slowly through the neighborhood or remaining parked for long periods of time.

Burglars in the area are also becoming increasingly bold. KOVR-TV reports that one home has been hit three times in recent weeks, and a number of the robberies have taken place when residents were home.
fields.summary: Police in Davis, California, are warning residents about a sharp rise in the number of burglaries in the area, including a large number that are taking place during daylight hours.

fields.heading: Burglary cited as top reason for identity fraud
fields.content:
While much of the attention surrounding identity theft recently has focused on hackers and computer fraud, a new study shows that burglaries and stolen wallets are still the the biggest reason for a stolen identity.

The report, completed by Travelers Insurance, found that 76 percent of identity fraud was caused by either a burglary, a stolen wallet or purse. Just 9 percent of identity theft was caused by online data breaches.

"This study suggests once again that more traditional means of identity fraud are prevalent today and continue to pose significant risks to consumers," said Joe Reynolds, Identity Fraud Product Manager for Travelers. He added that it was "critical" for consumers to take steps to protect their property, such as adding a home security system.

After a consumers' identity was stolen, 74 percent of the time it was used to either open new credit card accounts or use existing cards to make purchases.

Identity theft continues to be a growing problem in the U.S. The Federal Trade Commission estimates that it affects as many as 9 million people every year.
fields.summary: While much of the attention surrounding identity theft recently has focused on hackers and computer fraud, a new study shows that burglaries and stolen wallets are still the the biggest reason for a stolen identity.

fields.heading: Burglaries on the rise in Macon
fields.content:
Both residents and business owners in Macon are ramping up their security to deal with a rise in burglaries.

So far this year, residential burglaries in the city have topped 1,100 - an increase of 28 percent compared with last year.

Burglary rates for businesses have seen an even sharper increase. While there were just 174 incidents to this point last year, that number has jumped 32 percent to 229.

The city's police chief, Mike Burns, told WMAZ-TV that part of the problem is that officers have been focusing their attention on more violent crimes, and those guilty of property crimes have gotten off with less jail time, and ended up back on the street.

"Every time we meet at CompStat, it's the same story. 'I've locked up seven people this week,' then two weeks later another precinct says well I just locked the same ones up. So it's just very frustrating to the officers," he told the station.

Prior to this year, the city had been seeing decreasing crime rates. The Macon Telegraph reports that after peaking at just under 1,700 burglaries in 2006, officials saw three consecutive years with declining crime.
fields.summary: Both residents and business owners in Macon are ramping up their security to deal with a rise in burglaries.

fields.heading: Many residents leave homes vulnerable during vacations
fields.content:
With many households still preparing for one last summer trip, a new survey finds that many of them may not be keeping their homes secure.

The survey, conducted by M&S Insurance, found that 69 percent of respondents said that they would spend at least one night away from home this month. More than half would be leaving the home completely empty, and roughly a quarter didn't have anyone scheduled to look in on their property.

"We would urge homeowners to take appropriate steps to ensure their home is secure while they enjoy their holidays," said Andrew Ferguson, M&S Head of General Insurance.

Many survey respondents also left additional opportunities for burglars. Seventeen percent of those surveyed said that they left keys to their house or home alarm system hidden outside their home for friends, family or neighbors to come around.

Even more people will be heading away over the Labor Day holiday next month. AAA says that an estimated 31.4 million Americans will travel more than 50 miles away from home over the long weekend - a 10-percent increase over last year.
fields.summary: With many households still preparing for one last summer trip, a new survey finds that many of them may not be keeping their homes secure.

fields.heading: Burglars have new ways of breaking in
fields.content:
Most people make it a point to lock their doors and windows when they leave their home to prevent anyone from getting in. But as the Texas-based publication The Paper reports, those steps aren't often enough.

Some burglars are able to defeat door locks using techniques called key bumping or spring bumping, according to the publication. Both methods use a filed down key, which is used to try and pick the lock on a door - letting burglars in while leaving little evidence of forced entry.

Other burglars are taking advantage of what is traditionally a weak point in some home security systems - the garage. Some burglars, the source reports, are able to wedge open a garage door and then use a wire or coat hanger to pull the door's emergency release and get inside. Because the door between a garage and the rest of the home is often unlocked, a burglar getting into the garage can do just as much damage.

Police officers are also putting less effort into stopping property crimes, as they are forced to deal with staffing cutbacks that, as USA Today reports, have left many departments stretched thin.
fields.summary: Most people make it a point to lock their doors and windows when they leave their home to prevent anyone from getting in. But as the Texas-based publication The Paper reports, those steps aren't often enough.

fields.heading: New Orleans police credit home security systems with crime crackdown
fields.content:
Police officers in New Orleans are crediting many city residents with helping to solve a number of local crimes, thanks to home security cameras that some people have mounted outside their homes, WGNO-TV reports.

Deputies say that cameras have helped them track down suspects in a number of recent crimes, including one where a neighbor was caught stealing copper off from the gutters of a nearby home.

"In the last two months alone we've cleared 28 burglaries with 17 arrests, some of which coming from images captured from video surveillance," Col. John Doran told the station. "You'd be surprised who's lurking around at 3 in the morning so this gives us another set of eyes. The camera doesn't lie."

Those numbers may soon grow. According to the station, police added that they are also working on about a dozen other cases where residents captured the crime on tape.

Police in New Orleans have been hard-pressed to keep up in recent years, following Hurricane Katrina. MSNBC says that the crime rate in the city is currently double the national average.
fields.summary: Police officers in New Orleans are crediting many city residents with helping to solve a number of local crimes, thanks to home security cameras that some people have mounted outside their homes, WGNO-TV reports.

fields.heading: String of heat-wave burglars on the loose in New Britain
fields.content:
Police in New Britain, Connecticut, are warning residents to stay alert after a number of area houses have been hit in a string of recent burglaries, the New Britain Herald reports.

Most of the crimes have taken place overnight, and criminals are entering the home while residents have been sleeping. Most instances have involved the burglar either cutting through a window screen or through an open window with an air conditioner inside it.

In some cases, the burglars have even stolen the victims' cars after robbing the home during the night.

Officials are warning residents whose windows are not protected by motion sensors or a home security system to be very careful with leaving windows open overnight, even if they are only open because of window air conditioning units.

The local police force hopes that a recent influx of funding will help it crack down on the recent rise in crime. The Bristol Press reports that earlier this month, the New Britain police department was awarded a nearly $60,000 grant through the Department of Justice.
fields.summary: Police in New Britain, Connecticut, are warning residents to stay alert after a number of area houses have been hit in a string of recent burglaries, the New Britain Herald reports.

fields.heading: Charleston seeing increase in violent crimes
fields.content:
While there has been a slow decrease in the amount of violent crime nationwide, residents in Charleston, West Virginia, have seen an increase in the number of homicides in each of the last two years, the Charleston Gazette reports.

The city's police chief told the paper that while there were just four homicides in the city in 2008, that number has steadily increased. In 2009, there were six murders, and there were 10 in just the first eight months of 2010, a fact which has some residents installing home security systems.

Part of the increase, according to the Gazette, is due to an increase in crimes by youths. Teenagers have been charged in seven of the last 25 homicides in the city.

"Often rises in homicide rates are part of a larger trend," Laura Dugan, an associate professor of criminology and criminal justice at the University of Maryland, told the paper. "As the recession continues to stress out communities, illegal means of obtaining income grows. This often affects the homicide rate, especially if youth are involved."

According to the FBI, the violent crime rate in the country has dropped in recent months. From January to June of last year, violent crime dropped 4.4 percent.
fields.summary: While there has been a slow decrease in the amount of violent crime nationwide, residents in Charleston, West Virginia, have seen an increase in the number of homicides in each of the last two years, the Charleston Gazette reports.

fields.heading: Home alarm systems on the rise in Dickinson
fields.content:
