Faced with a growing population, police officers in Dickinson, North Dakota, say that more and more residents are installing home security systems, according to the Dickinson Press.

Police told the paper that they've seen roughly an 80 percent increase in the number of the alarms they have received. While many of those alerts are false alarms, it shows that residents are taking steps to be more secure.

One family said that while their home has never been burglarized, they have heard of crime in the area, and the added security helps put them at ease.

"The neighborhood has changed," resident Lloyd Lindbo told the paper. "We probably sleep better just because we know something is going to go off if somebody does try to break in."

Part of the reason for the rise in security awareness among residents may be due to a rise in violent crime, the Insurance Journal reported. Statewide, the number of violent crimes increased 8 percent last year, and the number of murders increased by 375 percent.
fields.summary: Faced with a growing population, police officers in Dickinson, North Dakota, say that more and more residents are installing home security systems, according to the Dickinson Press.

fields.heading: Police turning to GPS tracking to watch suspects
fields.content:
As cities and towns across the nation continue to cut back on police resources, more departments are turning to GPS tracking devices to help keep track of suspects, the Washington Post reports.

The issue has raised a significant debate over whether police departments should be required to get a warrant before using GPS tracking. While the paper said that few departments commented on their use of the technology, those that did said that it was no different than traditional police surveillance.

"A police officer could do the same thing with his or her own eyes," Arlington Commonwealth's attorney, Richard Trodden, told the Post. "It helps to cut down on the number of police officers who would have to be out tracking particular cars."

Other attorneys have said that the practice is far more detailed, and can be seen as intrusive.

So far, the U.S. Supreme Court has not issued a ruling on whether police need a warrant for GPS tracking devices, and the decisions of lower courts have often conflicted. Judges in Washington State said that police needed a warrant, but rulings in New York, Wisconsin and Maryland said they did not.
fields.summary: As cities and towns across the nation continue to cut back on police resources, more departments are turning to GPS tracking devices to help keep track of suspects, the Washington Post reports.

fields.heading: Chattanooga rises in latest crime ranking
fields.content:
Many residents in Chattanooga may be shopping for burglar alarms, after an increase in robberies and burglaries has pushed the city to 11th in the Ochs Center for Metropolitan Studies' crime ranking - higher than cities that are traditionally known for high levels of crime such as Detroit and Atlanta.

The report said while the city had seen a significant decrease in violent crime over the past two years, there was also a substantial increase in the number of burglaries, property crimes and robberies.

The most striking figure was the increase in burglaries. Referring to figures from the FBI, the center said that burglaries had increased by nearly 20 percent in 2008, and then risen by an additional 5 percent in 2009 as the economy continued to struggle.

Among all major metropolitan areas, the Center said that St. Louis had the highest crime rate in the country, followed by Little Rock, Arkansas and Springfield, Missouri.

Police told WCRB-TV that they weren't sure about all of the study's figures. Although they acknowledged that the city had a "crime problem," they added that officials were moving in the right direction by increasing the number of police officers.
fields.summary: Many residents in Chattanooga may be shopping for burglar alarms, after an increase in robberies and burglaries has pushed the city to 11th in the Ochs Center for Metropolitan Studies' crime ranking - higher than cities that are traditionally known for high levels of crime such as Detroit and Atlanta.

fields.heading: Crime wave prompts Fayetteville police to ask for assistance
fields.content:
Police in Fayetteville, North Carolina, are asking for the public's help after the area was left shaken by three separate shooting incidents that took place within a week of each other, reports News 14 Carolina.

Four people were hurt in the incidents. Police told the station that the region has several neighborhood watch groups, and that they are hoping increased vigilance in home security monitoring will help deter future crimes.

"We always tell them to report any suspicious activity. In situations like this we will provide suspect information if any is given and ask them to look out and do what they do. Give us a call and report that information to 911," Fayetteville police Crime Prevention Specialist Michelle Lindo told the station.

The local police department has welcomed an increase in staffing levels, which it says have contributed to falling crime rates - although the city still has the second-highest crime rate in the region, the Fayetteville Observer reports. In 2009, the police department was fully-staffed for just one week all year.
fields.summary: Police in Fayetteville, North Carolina, are asking for the public's help after the area was left shaken by three separate shooting incidents that took place within a week of each other, reports News 14 Carolina.

fields.heading: Southern California city puts security cameras in high-crime zones
fields.content:
Police in the city of Victorville, California, are getting some new tools in the fight against crime in the city.

Through a program called Safe City, officials have installed 31 surveillance cameras in high-crime areas, parks and other locations around the city, according to the Sun. To help allay any privacy concerns, local police also established a Citizens Privacy Council, which has access to the cameras at all times to prevent any improper use.

Officials were motivated to help fund the project after seeing the results of video surveillance programs in other local cities, the paper reports. Police in nearby Redlands have installed almost 100 security cameras over the past few years.

"The cameras have been tremendously helpful, especially when you consider the kinds of cuts our city and other cities have made because of the economy," Redlands spokesman Carl Baker told the paper.

The Safe City program has been implemented in a number of cities nationwide. Other cities which have implemented a system include Boston, Denver, Orland and Fresno. Systems are also currently being installed in Baltimore, Miami and Washington, D.C.
fields.summary: Police in the city of Victorville, California, are getting some new tools in the fight against crime in the city.

fields.heading: Burglar alarms scare off suspect in break-in
fields.content:
Police in the Boston area are looking for a suspect who fled the scene of an attempted robbery.

The attempted break-in occurred at the Castle Self-Storage facility in Braintree, Massachusetts. The suspect broke the front glass door of the building, and then tried to pry open the doors of two interior units with a hammer.

That activity set off a burglar alarm at the facility, and the suspect quickly fled without taking anything, and was gone when police arrived on the scene a few minutes later. The facility had been closed since 7 p.m. that evening.

Police added that while the suspect has not been apprehended, he was caught on security cameras at the facility, and officers were able to get an accurate picture of the suspect. Police described him as a man in his 30s.

Officials are also investigating another nearby break-in the same area the next day, the Boston Globe reports. The burglar broke into a home and pried open a safe in a bedroom closet - making off with several pieces of jewelry. No word if the two incidents are connected.
fields.summary: Police in the Boston area are looking for a suspect who fled the scene of an attempted robbery.

fields.heading: Beverly residents urged to improve home security
fields.content:
Police in Beverly, Illinois, are warning residents to take extra precautions after a string of recent burglaries.

Officials in the Chicago suburb have issued a community alert, reminding homeowners to lock their windows and doors, and to consider installing home security systems or motion-activating lighting to deter thieves, the Southtown Star reports.

In most cases, the burglars have entered the homes in the early morning hours by either cutting or simply lifting the window screens on various homes while residents are sleeping, according to the paper. They have stolen various consumer goods, wallets and purses, and in some cases have even taken homeowners' car keys and then driven away from the scene.

Police are also asking residents to alert their neighbors about the situation and watch for any suspicious activity.

The crimes are similar in nature to many other burglaries across the country. According to the New Britain Herald, a number of homes in Connecticut have been robbed by burglars who have entered the home through windows which were left open for air conditioners.
fields.summary: Police in Beverly, Illinois, are warning residents to take extra precautions after a string of recent burglaries.

fields.heading: Celebrities admit carelessness before break-ins
fields.content:
Many of the Hollywood celebrities who were victimized in a rash of break-ins from 2008 to 2009 told a Los Angeles grand jury that they were careless with their security, and often failed to set their home security systems or even lock their front doors, according to unsealed testimony obtained by the Associated Press.

In their testimony, multiple stars said that the robberies had frightened them, and taken away their feelings of safety. Afterwards, many said that they were now taking much greater precautions in terms of their home security systems.

"We have always sort of lived a very, I guess, trusting lifestyle and we just didn't set the alarm," actress Rachel Bilson told the court. "I now do, every time I leave the house. Even if it's for 20 minutes."

The AP says that at this point, officers say that at least $2 million worth of property from the crimes has not been recovered.

To this point, six members of the ring blamed for most of the crimes have been charged. One has pled guilty and served time in prison, while the rest are still awaiting trial.
fields.summary: Many of the Hollywood celebrities who were victimized in a rash of break-ins from 2008 to 2009 told a Los Angeles grand jury that they were careless with their security, and often failed to set their home security systems or even lock their front doors, according to unsealed testimony obtained by the Associated Press.

fields.heading: Property crimes skyrocket in Antioch
fields.content:
While violent crimes have been on the downswing in Antioch, California, officials say there has been a consistent increase in property crimes, the Conta Costa Times reports.

Overall, the city witnessed a 2.1 percent increase in crime over the first seven months of this year, a number fueled by a significant rise in the number of burglaries. Last year, the city saw just 484 such crimes in the first part of the year. So far this year there have been 625 reported burglaries - a 29 percent increase.

Officers told the paper that they had actually expected crime numbers to get worse, given the staff reductions they have been forced to make, although the effects have been seen in a nearly 25 percent drop in arrests.

"Less officers equals less arrests. It takes longer to get to the scene and to go from call to call if there are less people on the streets," Chief Jim Hyde said.

Officials added that the rise in property crime has led to a resurgence in neighborhood watch groups, which have helped residents be more aware of their home security and the use of burglar alarms.

The city's staffing problem may soon get even worse. According to the Times, the city has proposed a sales tax hike, which will appear on the ballot in November. If it fails, the $4.5 million budget deficit may force additional layoffs.
fields.summary: While violent crimes have been on the downswing in Antioch, California, officials say there has been a consistent increase in property crimes, the Conta Costa Times reports.

fields.heading: Bakersfield police notice rise in home security cameras
fields.content:
Police in Bakersfield, California say they are noticing that an increasing number of residents are installing home security systems with security cameras to help prevent crime in the area, the Bakersfield Californian reports.

One camera installer told the paper that his company now installs cameras on roughly 15 homes per month, compared to just one per month in recent years. Officials say that while they don't endorse any particular home alarm systems, security cameras can be an additional asset to police.

"I think it's a good idea in that it's a deterrent for a burglar and it's helpful to us," Bakersfield police Sgt. Mary DeGeare told the paper.

Police added that security cameras mounted on one resident's home captured footage of a suspected prowler in the local area, which has given police a good lead in the case.

The city itself is also installing a number of security cameras to help fight crime in the downtown bar area. Last month, the Californian reported that five new cameras will be up-and-running before the end of the year, and should allow the city to reduce the number of extra patrols it sends through the area on some nights.
fields.summary: Police in Bakersfield, California say they are noticing that an increasing number of residents are installing home security systems with security cameras to help prevent crime in the area, the Bakersfield Californian reports.

fields.heading: Tucson police asking residents to stay alert amid burglary spike
fields.content:
Police in Pima County, Arizona are warning residents following a rash of roughly 15 burglaries which have taken place in one local Tucson neighborhood.

All of the robberies have taken place at night, while residents were sleeping. Most of the instances, according to police, have occurred because a burglar was able to gain easy entry through an unlocked sliding door or an unsecured dog door - which allowed them to unlock the door itself.

Police said that those with home security systems should contact police as soon as their alarm sounds - even if they don't notice anything missing right away. People are also asked to contact police should they see anything suspicious.

The spike in burglaries takes place at the same time as officers in the area are dealing with a significant increase in violent crime. Tucson police have begun a special effort, including increased patrols in high crime areas, to stem a rising number of homicides. Since July, there have been 15 homicides in Tucson.
fields.summary: Police in Pima County, Arizona are warning residents following a rash of roughly 15 burglaries which have taken place in one local Tucson neighborhood.

fields.heading: Burglar alarms help police catch suspect in the act
fields.content:
The burglar alarms installed by a Pennsylvania business owner helped make sure that police were able to apprehend an early morning criminal.

A police officer in Royersford, Pennsylvania, was on patrol when he heard the sound of a burglar alarm going off nearby and followed it back to a local business, where he saw broken glass in the parking lot. A suspect then walked out the front door carrying the store's cash register and merchandise at the same time the officer arrived.

"I identified myself and ordered the male to freeze, at which point the male tossed all of the items into the air and began to walk away," Officer Joseph P. Oberholtzer II wrote in a police filing, according to the Times-Herald.

The suspect was then arrested, and now faces multiple charges.

Police in the Pottstown, Pennsylvania, area have been cracking down on crime in recent months, and have seen a corresponding drop in serious crimes, according to the Pottstown Mercury. But at the same time, officers have also made an increasing number of arrests for crimes such as receiving stolen property, vandalism and drug violations.
fields.summary: The burglar alarms installed by a Pennsylvania business owner helped make sure that police were able to apprehend an early morning criminal.

fields.heading: Security cameras lead to burglary arrest in Arizona
fields.content:
One Litchfield Park, Arizona, burglar is behind bars after his crime was recorded by the home security system at the home he robbed.

The home's owner, Nick, who told KNXV-TV that he didn't want to use his full name, came home to find that his house had been broken into and his television had been stolen. When police arrived on the scene, he told them about security cameras mounted on the house, which had picked up the burglar as he broke in.

Officers told the station that the video was critical in arresting a suspect in the case, who now faces three felonies. Security experts said that sometimes the existence of cameras is enough to prevent crimes from happening in the first place.

"If somebody actually goes to a house and they see cameras pointing at them, red lights on, they're going to think twice about going in there," home security professional Matt Terry told the station. "If they do break in you actually get to catch them. You have the video evidence."

The town, which is located near Glendale, Arizona, is traditionally a very safe area. The Glendale News-Press reports that the city was ranked No. 7 on the list of the safest cities in the country for its size.
fields.summary: One Litchfield Park, Arizona, burglar is behind bars after his crime was recorded by the home security system at the home he robbed.

fields.heading: Fresno crime wave brings increase of neighborhood watch programs
fields.content:
To help combat a rising number of crimes, residents in Fresno, California, have formed a number of new Neighborhood Watch programs, KFSN-TV reports.

The 15 percent increase in home and business burglaries this year has led many people to install burglar alarms and keep a closer eye on their homes. But the president of the city's Neighborhood Watch says that more than 20 people have asked about starting their own groups. Volunteers say that the programs can make a significant impact.

"I've seen people looking, walking around, looking into people's windows around two or three in the morning. I've caught people taking off locks off people's garages, and then taking off after they've seen me," resident and neighborhood watch member Gary Oldham told the station.

The city's police force has also made a significant impact in the fight against violent crimes. Earlier this year, officials created Violent Crime Impact Teams to increase patrols in gang areas. KMJN reports that since the program began, the city has experienced its lowest homicide rate in a decade.
fields.summary: To help combat a rising number of crimes, residents in Fresno, California, have formed a number of new Neighborhood Watch programs, KFSN-TV reports.

fields.heading: California police report rise in crime in homes for sale
fields.content:
Police in Simi Valley, California, say they are seeing an increase in crime at vacant homes in the area.

According to the Ventura County Star, police say that burglars are stealing copper pipes, wiring, air conditioners and appliances from homes that are vacant or up for sale - where home security systems may be inactive.

Officers told the paper that they suspect the criminals appear to be from a moving or repair company, and are parking trucks in the homes' driveway - where they can be loaded up with the stolen goods. They're asking residents to be alert for any unknown vehicles, broken windows and doors or homes with any structural damage.

Police are also warning real estate agents, who may be trying to show the homes to prospective buyers, to stay away from homes with suspicious activity so they don't walk in on a crime in progress.

Vacant homes are often a source of increased crime, the National Post reports. Officers in Detroit told the paper that a large number of vacant homes in the city has contributed to its high crime rate, and that many organizations have begun tearing them down and recycling the materials in order to alleviate the issue.
fields.summary: Police in Simi Valley, California, say they are seeing an increase in crime at vacant homes in the area.

fields.heading: Police use GPS tracking to arrest suspect
fields.content:
GPS tracking technology is allowing one small New York police department to make arrests that surprise even the criminals themselves.

The 15-officer Blooming Grove Police Department was recently able to use the technology to arrest a suspect in a number of home burglaries, according to WCBS-TV. Officers told the station that security cameras helped them place the suspect's car at the scene of a recent home burglary.

They then got approval to place a tracker on his car, and followed him to a high-end neighborhood, where they found him allegedly stealing copper piping from an empty home. Police said that the suspect didn't predict that the local police department would use such a high-tech approach to catch him.

"They look at a small town, police department [and think] ‘We will never get caught, there's no one watching us,'" Blooming Grove police chief Carl Schupp told the station. "He was amazed. He didn't think we would go through that kind of effort to zero in on him."

While it is also used in home security applications, the use of GPS tracking by police has been the subject of much recent debate. A recent decision by a federal appeals court has said that officers do not need a warrant to use GPS tracking on a suspect's vehicle.
fields.summary: GPS tracking technology is allowing one small New York police department to make arrests that surprise even the criminals themselves.

fields.heading: Burglary suspect arrested following jump into a dumpster
fields.content:
Officers in Manchester Township, New Jersey have arrested a suspect in a recent liquor store robbery, even after they attempted to escape police by jumping into a commercial Dumpster, the Asbury Park Press reports.

The paper says that police initially responded to the scene when burglar alarms went off inside a liquor store and found the crime still in progress. They chased two suspects onto the roof of a shopping center before the suspects leaped from the roof into a Dumpster which had been used for construction materials and attempted to flee the scene.

One of the suspects, a 61 year-old man according to the paper, was later arrested after a search of the area, faces multiple charges and is being held without bail. The second suspect has not been found.

Manchester Township generally has a very low crime rate compared with the rest of the state. A crime ranking by HomeSurfer.com found that the township averaged just 24 violent crimes for every 100,000 residents - far less than 342 statewide.
fields.summary: Officers in Manchester Township, New Jersey have arrested a suspect in a recent liquor store robbery, even after they attempted to escape police by jumping into a commercial Dumpster, the Asbury Park Press reports.

fields.heading: Charlotte police warn residents to be alert
fields.content:
Officials are warning residents in Charlotte, North Carolina, to be aware of any suspicious activity after a spike in residential crime has swept through several neighborhoods over the last few weeks.

The Charlotte Observer reported that police in the city's Steele Creek Division said that they had seen an increasing number of vehicle break-ins and thefts of lawn equipment such as mowers.

It's the second such warning in the region in less than a week. The paper says officers in Mint Hill said that there had been a number of crimes in that area in which burglars had repeatedly stolen items such as laptops, GPS units, wallets and music players from unlocked vehicles.

The paper says that residents are reminded to arm their home security systems when they leave the house, and to record serial numbers of any valuable property so it can be tracked down if it's ever taken.

A separate string of robberies in the SouthPark neighborhood has brought an increase police presence in the area, according to WSOC-TV, with additional teams of motorcycle units patrolling the area.
fields.summary: Officials are warning residents in Charlotte, North Carolina, to be aware of any suspicious activity after a spike in residential crime has swept through several neighborhoods over the last few weeks.

fields.heading: Home security worries strongest during vacations
fields.content:
Vacations are intended to be a time when people are able to get away from their everyday cares. But a new survey finds that most people become more worried about something going wrong at home when they're away.

The survey, conducted by Intamac Systems, found that 74 percent of respondents were most worried about a "home disaster" - such as a fire, flood or burglary - while they were away. More than half of the survey respondents also said that they didn't have home security systems or burglar alarms.

"As the holiday season gets fully under way, its open season for housebreakers and accidents," said Kevin Meagher, CEO of Intamac. "The level of home security is the key risk factor for burglary victimization."

The fault for much of that anxiety however, may lie with the homeowners themselves. A survey conducted by M&S Insurance found that more than one in every six homeowner admitted to leaving a key to their home or burglar alarm hidden outside - making it easier for burglars to break in.
fields.summary: Vacations are intended to be a time when people are able to get away from their everyday cares. But a new survey finds that most people become more worried about something going wrong at home when they're away.

fields.heading: Lebanon city officials voice concerns over crime increase
fields.content:
While the overall crime rate in Lebanon, Tennessee has fallen by more than 27 percent over the last two years, a recent rise in burglaries has many city officials concerned, the Tennessean reports.

Officials told the paper that the number of break-ins, robberies and thefts from cars have all showed significant increases compared with last year. In addition, they added that many of the latest crimes had taken place in traditionally safer neighborhoods, where residents aren't used to hearing the sound of burglar alarms.

"We've got burglaries all over town," Councilwoman Kathy Warmath said during a recent city council meeting, according to the paper. "People are scared to death."

Warmath told the paper that she had asked the city's police chief for a regional breakdown of crime statistics, but that after three weeks, she still hasn't received them.

The situation has also created a great deal of tension between city officials and law enforcement officers. According to the Tennessean, following comments by a city council member in which he called officers "lazy," the Lebanon Fraternal Order of Police issued a letter which called those comments "unprofessional" and "unsubstantiated."
fields.summary: While the overall crime rate in Lebanon, Tennessee has fallen by more than 27 percent over the last two years, a recent rise in burglaries has many city officials concerned, the Tennessean reports.

fields.heading: Landlords turning to security cameras to increase apartment building security
fields.content:
While landlords in many apartment buildings used to shun the idea of security cameras, an increasing number are now turning to the technology to improve security in their buildings, Multi-Housing News reports.

The cameras have been successful in helping to reduce crime, and identify those that may not belong inside. But in many cases, the source reports, cameras aren't being installed until after an incident.

"We've found that few landlords are proactive," Matthew De Gennaro, vice president of a Staten Island, security company, told the site. "But then something happens on their property - it isn't necessarily a crime - and they realize that better surveillance ... might have helped them."

The site says that cameras in many buildings have also been able to help with other issues, such as tenants who aren't following building rules and leaving garbage in common areas.

Many colleges have taken a similar approach, and are installing video cameras around residence halls. Penn State University's Daily Collegian reports that the school is currently running a trial program, which could soon expand to put cameras at the entrances to all school dorms.
fields.summary: While landlords in many apartment buildings used to shun the idea of security cameras, an increasing number are now turning to the technology to improve security in their buildings, Multi-Housing News reports.

fields.heading: Security technology helps drive massive drop in California auto thefts
fields.content:
Advances in technology - such as GPS tracking and license plate recognition systems - along with increased enforcement and education programs for the public led to a more than 15-percent drop in California vehicle thefts in 2009, according to statistics from the California Highway Patrol.

That drop was the largest in decades, in addition to being the fourth consecutive year in which auto thefts dropped. Since 2005, vehicle thefts have fallen 35 percent.

"In order to put thieves out of business and keep from becoming a victim, we must remain vigilant in our efforts," said California Highway Patrol Commissioner Joe Farrow. "Vehicle theft is a crime of opportunity," he added. "Citizens are on the front lines when it comes to prevention."

The CHP says that of all the vehicles stolen last year, more than 88 percent were recovered, a 2.2 percent increase over the previous year.

Among those vehicles that were stolen, Honda Accords and Civics were taken with the most frequency. CHP statistics found that different model years of the two vehicles accounted for all of the state's 14 highest theft rates.
fields.summary: Advances in technology - such as GPS tracking and license plate recognition systems - along with increased enforcement and education programs for the public led to a more than 15-percent drop in California vehicle thefts in 2009, according to statistics from the California Highway Patrol.

fields.heading: Missouri City police fighting rise in crime
fields.content:
Police officers in Missouri City, Texas, say they are seeing a significant rise in crime in some area neighborhoods, and are warning residents to stay alert, reports KTRK-TV.

The station reports that the area has seen a 5 percent increase in violent crime so far this year. In particular, crimes involving gun violence have shown a significant increase in recent weeks. 

Officials sent out an advisory to the homeowners associations of a number of communities describing the series of incidents, and urged residents to stay alert and remember to take preventive steps, such as installing burglar alarms or motion sensors.

"In Missouri City, citizens believe in the police department, and we value our positions as a part of, not apart from, the community," police chief Joel Fitzgerald said, according to the station. "We are greatly concerned about the recent rise in felony offenses."'

The rise in crime is uncharacteristic for the Houston-area suburb. Earlier this year, Money Magazine named Missouri City one of the best small cities in the country to live in.
fields.summary: Police officers in Missouri City, Texas, say they are seeing a significant rise in crime in some area neighborhoods, and are warning residents to stay alert.

fields.heading: Home security system helps police arrest burglary suspect
fields.content:
Police in Hastings, Minnesota, have made an arrest in a series of burglaries last week, in part thanks to security cameras at one of the victim's homes.

According to the Star Gazette, the criminal broke into six vehicles in one neighborhood, and got away with a laptop and various other items. But he was unaware that he was caught on tape during one of the robberies, which took place at the home of a local business owner who installs home security systems.

That homeowner quickly posted video of the incident online, and received a number of number of leads within two days. The paper also posted the video of the robbery on its website. Officials say that the suspect shown in the video appeared to be a young male, and suspected he lived locally because he was on foot. No details of the arrest have been released.

Local police are also continuing to work with area residents to improve their ability to respond to issues. The Hastings Police Department is currently conducting a community crime and safety survey, which they told the Star Gazette they hope will help them understand what safety issues residents are concerned about.
fields.summary: Police in Hastings, Minnesota, have made an arrest in a series of burglaries last week, in part thanks to security cameras at one of the victim's homes.

fields.heading: Atlanta subdivision residents push for security cameras
fields.content:
Residents in one Atlanta subdivision are at odds with the president of the local homeowners association over the potential installation of a security camera in the neighborhood to prevent crime, WAGA-TV reports.

A number of people living in the Wyncreek subdivision want to place a security camera at the entrance to the neighborhood. Police told the station that over the past year and a half, the group of upscale homes has seen nearly 20 burglaries. 

Some of them even raised money for the camera and began installing it before they were stopped by the association president, John Nguyen. They say that the cameras would send a message to potential criminals.

"The security cameras would put them on alert, that we're watching them. Secondly, I think it would put our residents at ease a little more, because everybody is scared now," resident Brianna Williams told the station.

Nguyen told the station that he felt the cameras were a threat to privacy and doubted the real impact they could have.

The crime rate in Atlanta has remained among the highest in the nation. According to recent FBI statistics, the city had the fourth-highest per capita crime rate among all U.S. cities.
fields.summary: Residents in one Atlanta subdivision are at odds with the president of the local homeowners association over the potential installation of a security camera in the neighborhood to prevent crime, WAGA-TV reports.

fields.heading: Flushing police to install security cameras to prevent vandalism
fields.content:
Officials in Flushing, Michigan, have approved the installation of security cameras by police officers to monitor Riverview Park, which the Flint Journal reports has seen an increase in vandalism, with incidents occurring nearly every week.

The cameras will be paid for through grants from the federal stimulus bill, the paper reports. Officials say that the cameras won't be monitored consistently, but will instead be used as a deterrent, and to identify suspects once something has taken place.

"These cameras are not designed for someone to be sitting in a room monitoring the park 24 hours a day," Flushing city manager Dennis Bow said at the meeting, according to the paper. "We want to pull video after something happens."

The paper reports that the local police department has been planning the project for years, but didn't have the funding.

The grant money has also been used for other security purposes. Some of the funding was also used to upgrade security cameras in police cruisers and the camera systems in local school systems.
fields.summary: Officials in Flushing, Michigan, have approved the installation of security cameras by police officers to monitor Riverview Park, which the Flint Journal reports has seen an increase in vandalism, with incidents occurring nearly every week.

fields.heading: Police warn of daytime burglars near Jacksonville
fields.content:
Police in St. Marys, Florida, are noticing a sharp increase in daytime home burglaries in the area over the past several weeks, according to the Florida Times-Union.

Officials says that while the city has only had 42 burglaries so far this year, half of them have occurred since the start of July. In most cases, the robberies have taken place during business hours, when many residents are away at work. According to the paper, police recommended that residents install home security systems or security cameras, and said the poor economy may play a role in the crime wave.

"It's easier to break in and steal than to find a job," Lt. Johnny Guy, a St. Marys detective, told the paper. "People need to make sure their homes are secure."

Guy also told the paper that while many burglars broke down doors or smashed windows to get inside the homes, other residents "made it easy" by leaving many windows open with just a screen in place.

The area has been dealing with high levels of unemployment in recent months. While the national unemployment rate sits at 9.6 percent, the jobless rate in Baker County has remained close to 11 percent.
fields.summary: Police in St. Marys, Florida, are noticing a sharp increase in daytime home burglaries in the area over the past several weeks, according to the Florida Times-Union.

fields.heading: James Island sees rash of break-ins
fields.content:
Residents living in James Island, South Carolina, are staying on alert after a series of break-ins and robberies in the area, the Post and Courier reports.

There have six burglaries in the relatively small community over the past three weeks. According to the paper, most of the incidents have involved burglars kicking in the back door of the home and taking what they find inside. The increase in crime has prompted many residents to consider installing a home security system.

"It's scary for two people that live alone," Thelma Bagley, a retiree who lives in the area, told the paper. "I'm checking into alarm systems."

Police have come up with a number of leads on the robberies, the paper reports. While there were no security cameras in the area, a neighbor noticed a car parked outside one of the burglaries earlier in the day. Officers are now searching for its registered owner.

Crime has become an increasingly important issue for many area residents, including the city's newly elected mayor, Bill Woolsey. According to WCSC-TV, after starting his first official day on the job earlier this month, he pledged to cut down crime and pay for increased police patrols in the area.
fields.summary: Residents living in James Island, South Carolina, are staying on alert after a series of break-ins and robberies in the area, the Post and Courier reports.

fields.heading: Protecting a vacation home from burglary
fields.content:
It's one thing to secure a property that's occupied throughout the year. But as the Los Angeles Times reports, ensuring the security of a vacation home - which may go months without anyone there - requires special steps.

The paper reports that most vacation home robberies are carried out by people who live nearby, because outsiders would stand out among the area's year-round residents. In most cases, they will appear as repairmen to cover their robberies.

To protect vacation properties during the off-season, the paper says that it's recommended to install home security systems, and make sure that all entryways are completely secured. If there are a large number of seasonal homes in close proximity, those owners may also want to consider joining up to hire a trustworthy local caretaker to maintain the properties and take care of any issues while the owners are away.

A number of Americans have vacation homes or cabins that they may not inhabit on a regular basis. According to the Census Bureau, there were approximately 7.9 million seasonal properties in the U.S. last year.
fields.summary: It's one thing to secure a property that's occupied throughout the year. But as the Los Angeles Times reports, ensuring the security of a vacation home - which may go months without anyone there - requires special steps.

fields.heading: Syracuse police push for security cameras
fields.content:
Police officers in Syracuse, New York, are continuing their push for the installation of security cameras in some of the city's high-crime areas, WSYR-TV reports.

According to the station, the department hopes to install nine security cameras at various intersections around the city that would be monitored by city police. The specialized cameras are able to follow the sound of gunshots and other loud noises, and have been used successfully in many other local towns.

"I think whatever the city can do to better our community is a good idea. Whatever they're going to try to do, they should just do it, for the kids' sake," Syracuse resident Jennifer Mackey told the station.

While some officials told the station that they are in favor of the program, it still needs to pass a vote by the City Common Council.

The installation of the cameras could prove to be a valuable deterrent. A five-year study by researchers at Rutgers University found that home alarm systems decrease not only crime rates for those specific homes, but for the neighborhood in general.
fields.summary: Police officers in Syracuse, New York, are continuing their push for the installation of security cameras in some of the city's high-crime areas, WSYR-TV reports.

fields.heading: Home offices present unique security concerns
fields.content:
A number of people in the current economy have chosen to work primarily from home instead of going into the office on a regular basis. While it offers a great deal of convenience, it also presents different home security conditions for people to consider.

According to Sentry Security, people who work from home should be sure to have window treatments that prevent potential burglars from seeing what equipment is inside. Because home offices generally have expensive computers, faxes and other machines, they could be more attractive targets for burglars - increasing the need for effective home security systems.

It's also important for workers to be sure that they take extra care when receiving any deliveries, the company says. It's important for people to ask those outside to identify themselves before opening the door, and not to let them inside the house for any reason.

Telecommuting is becoming a much more popular perk offered by a number of companies. Discovery Communications says that 44 percent of American companies offer working from home as a potential benefit.
fields.summary: A number of people in the current economy have chosen to work primarily from home instead of going into the office on a regular basis. While it offers a great deal of convenience, it also presents different home security conditions for people to consider.

fields.heading: Austin homeowners asking police for help
fields.content:
Residents in the Northwest Hills area of Austin, Texas, met with local police officers after an escalation in a string of crimes in the area, KXAN-TV reports.

People told the station that, at first, burglars were breaking into unlocked vehicles. But they quickly grew more brazen, breaking into garages and homes - sometimes while residents were at home. Many homeowners said they've taken extra steps to be prepared, such as installing home alarm systems.

"Everything has changed now, we changed our habits how we protect the house, how we talk to people in the neighborhood, we changed how we watch cars go by," Susan Roberts, whose home was broken into last December, told the station.

During a meeting with approximately 80 residents, the station reports that police said they have multiple nightly patrols, and reminded people to always lock their doors and write down serial numbers of their property so it can be recovered if it's ever taken.

The increase in burglaries coincides with statewide results. According to recent FBI statistics, burglaries in the state increased by 3.6 percent from 2008 to 2009.
fields.summary: Residents in the Northwest Hills area of Austin, Texas, met with local police officers after an escalation in a string of crimes in the area, KXAN-TV reports.

fields.heading: Tuscon police launch increased patrols after violent crime spike
fields.content:
Police in Tuscon, Arizona, are launching a new initiative to tackle an increase in violent crime so far this year.

Officers said that they will temporarily increase police patrols, and also ramp up their surveillance efforts in several high-crime areas in the city.

"I think this is a good temporary measure not only to go out there and increase enforcement in those areas where there's a high volume of violent crime, but also show the public and reassure them we're out here and addressing the problem," sergeant Brandon Musgrave told KVOA-TV.

Police will also increase their focus on gathering intelligence during their patrols as a way to target neighborhoods where they have seen a growing trend of violence.

The area has seen a sharp increase in the number of homicides this year, the most recent of which took place on September 19. Last year, there were 16 murder cases in the county. This year, there are already nearly 20 with more than three months still left in the year, KOLD-TV reports.
fields.summary: Police in Tuscon, Arizona, are launching a new initiative to tackle an increase in violent crime so far this year.

fields.heading: Homeowner's security cameras help police solve multiple crimes
fields.content:
Police in Rehobeth Beach, Delaware, say that home security cameras installed by one area resident have helped them sort out a number of incidents in the local area, the Daily Times reports.

According to the paper, Rick Eisenman first installed the cameras after continued vandalism of his front yard. His home security system now has four motion-activated cameras with night-vision.

"I installed outdoor security cameras five years ago and have been building upon the system ever since. It's an excellent deterrent for intruders," he told the paper. "I've got some videos of people who walk onto my property, then realize there are cameras and walk away."

In addition to patrolling the neighborhood, one of the cameras is trained on a nearby intersection, and police have used its footage to help sort out circumstances of a number of traffic accidents.

His steps are likely also helping make the entire neighborhood safer. A recent study by researchers at Rutgers University found that security systems decrease crime at the homes they are installed in, as well as the surrounding area.
fields.summary: Police in Rehobeth Beach, Delaware, say that home security cameras installed by one area resident have helped them sort out a number of incidents in the local area, the Daily Times reports.

fields.heading: String of break-ins reported in Colonial Heights
fields.content:
Officials in Colonial Heights, Virginia, say that a number of local residents have invested in home security systems after a string of recent daytime burglaries has swept through the area, the Progress-Index reports.

Police told the paper that there have been 14 burglaries over the past month, and they believe that at least 11 of them may be related. The burglars have taken various items, including jewelry, electronics and various collectibles. According to the paper, at least two of the homes had become vacant due to a recent death.

"We believe that [the burglar or burglars] would be familiar with the area and familiar with where these homes are," police sergeant Robert Ruxer told the paper. "It could be that it's a juvenile. With school out, most people wouldn't think anything of a juvenile riding a bike down the street."

Detectives added that residents should remember to secure their doors and windows, and not make it easy for burglars to break in.

The crime spree has put residents on edge in the generally low-crime area. WTVR-TV reports that, under normal circumstances, the town sees just a few break-ins per month.
fields.summary: Officials in Colonial Heights, Virginia, say that a number of local residents have invested in home security systems after a string of recent daytime burglaries has swept through the area, the Progress-Index reports.

fields.heading: Police warning Long Beach residents about a series of burglaries
fields.content:
Detectives in Long Beach, California, are warning residents to stay on alert after a series of burglaries in the area.

Police say that all three incidents occurred when the suspects gained entry to an unsecured home where a woman was alone.

"During each of the incidents the victims were home alone when they discovered a male suspect inside their residence," Nancy Pratt, a Long Beach Police Department spokeswoman, told the Press-Telegram. "The suspects fled the location without taking anything."

Police added that while they think that some of the incidents may be connected, they don't yet have a motive for the crimes.

Officials are warning residents to secure all of their windows and doors and to install home security systems to deter break-ins.

Residents in the area are dealing with a significant increase in home burglaries this year. The Long Beach Post reports that there were 196 home burglaries this July, a 15 percent increase compared with July 2009.
fields.summary: Detectives in Long Beach, California, are warning residents to stay on alert after a series of burglaries in the area.

fields.heading: Homeowners need to step out of their own frame of mind
fields.content:
In order to take steps to prevent themselves from becoming the victim of a burglary, UIA Insurance writes that homeowners need to think of their home like a burglar would, in order to spot any potential weaknesses.

The company says that many homeowners fail to notice things, such as ladders, that they may leave around their home accidentally, that make it easy for burglars to gain entry into their home once they go out.

"From my perspective, it is about actually putting yourself in the position of being a burglar and looking at your house," said Jacqui Hames, a local crime expert.

The company cited a recent study by Opinion Matters, which found that one in five homeowners have left their windows open while they were away from home over the last year.

Something as simple as an open window can be an invitation for burglars. Past statistics from the FBI say that as many as two-thirds of burglars use an open window or unlocked door to enter a home.
fields.summary: In order to take steps to prevent themselves from becoming the victim of a burglary, UIA Insurance writes that homeowners need to think of their home like a burglar would, in order to spot any potential weaknesses.

fields.heading: Simple security measures can drop burglary risk
fields.content:
A new report finds that homeowners who take even the simplest home security steps can help cut down their risk of burglary.

A crime report from investigators in the United Kingdom found that taking simple steps, such as installing and closing vertical blinds on ground floor windows, can drop the risk of burglary by as much as six percent.

"There is undoubtedly a correlation between burglaries and the recession, but just as at any time, sensible security measures will considerably reduce your chance of becoming a burglary victim. In light of this, now is a good time for you to review your home security, just to be sure you are fully protected." said police officer Julian Stanton.

Officials added that installing more advanced home security systems can produce even greater results.

Closing windows is among the many basic security precautions recommended by police officers across the country. By closing, locking and using curtains or blinds to block windows, burglars are unable to see inside a home, and see whatever property might be there.
fields.summary: A new report finds that homeowners who take even the simplest home security steps can help cut down their risk of burglary.

fields.heading: Residents come together to prevent crime
fields.content:
Residents in one Houston-area neighborhood are now coming together to watch out for suspicious behavior after a recent burglary put many residents on edge, the Champions Sun reports.

According to the paper, before the robbery, some residents noticed a pair of men who appeared to be delivering newspapers, but actually were not. They called the police, but the suspects had already left the area when officers arrived.

"There was a break-in and even though we share a fence line and this took place a few yards away, we never even knew it happened," local resident Jackie Kern, who's part of the local neighborhood watch, told the paper. "So I sent a letter around to my neighbors saying, 'We need to watch out for each other.'"

Officers added that residents can't simply install home security systems and pretend like their problems are solved, and that they need to continue to actively keep their homes secure.

According to recent FBI statistics, many burglars take advantage of insecure homes. Of all burglaries in 2009, there was no forced entry in more than 32 percent of them.
fields.summary: Residents in one Houston-area neighborhood are now coming together to watch out for suspicious behavior after a recent burglary put many residents on edge, the Champions Sun reports.

fields.heading: Vehicle GPS tracking helps police catch suspect
fields.content:
Police in Marysville, California, were able to catch a suspected burglar by using the GPS tracking system installed on the vehicle that he stole, the Appeal-Democrat reports.

According to the paper, an area resident returned home to find that their vehicle had been stolen, along with a large amount of property.

"The suspect ... apparently loaded the stolen property into a vehicle parked in the home's garage and took the car using the car keys ... found in the home," Marysville detective Kevin Conde told the paper.

Once the report was called in, police activated the GPS tracking, and found the vehicle parked outside the home in which the suspect was hiding in the next town over. After obtaining a search warrant, officers found the suspect, a 35-year-old man, hiding in the attic.

Police also told the Appeal-Democrat that they suspect the same man is responsible for another attempted burglary in the area earlier this month. In that incident, the suspect fled after burglar alarms installed at the home went off during the attempt.
fields.summary: Police in Marysville, California, were able to catch a suspected burglar by using the GPS tracking system installed on the vehicle that he stole, the Appeal-Democrat reports.

fields.heading: Spotlights, home security systems important to prevent crime
fields.content:
Property crimes have continued to be a serious concern for many homeowners across the country, and preventing them has become a priority. Lock manufacturer Schlage says that having motion-activated lights and home security systems can help prevent many homes from becoming targets.

In addition to making sure that all doors and windows are securely locked, the company says that having motion-activated exterior lights are enough to stop many burglars because they don't want to be seen as they approach a house.

It's also important for homeowners to have working home alarm systems, the company says, because they can allow residents to constantly monitor their home. However, for those moving into a home with an existing system, they should make sure to change the passcode once they move in, so anyone who may have obtained the old code won't be able to gain entry.

Statistics have shown that a burglar will spend the better part of an hour looking for their target, but just three minutes in the commission of the crime itself - putting an emphasis on deterrents.
fields.summary: Property crimes have continued to be a serious concern for many homeowners across the country, and preventing them has become a priority. Lock manufacturer Schlage says that having motion-activated lights and home security systems can help prevent many homes from becoming targets .

fields.heading: Baltimore-area police search for 'preppy burglar'
fields.content:
Police in Highland, Maryland, are on the lookout for a man they've dubbed the "preppy burglar," after he was caught on a homeowner's security cameras robbing the home in a shirt and tie.

According to police, the man walked up to the home, rang the doorbell and checked the windows to make sure no one was home before breaking through a window. A short time later, the cameras captured him walking out of the home with electronics and other items while checking to make sure that he wasn't being followed.

Officers added that they're not sure if the burglary was planned, or whether it was a crime of opportunity. They've also offered a reward.

"We don't know if he was coming somewhere where he was dressed appropriately for the day or perhaps if it was perhaps maybe to throw off neighbors so he didn't look suspicious," said Howard County Police Spokeswoman Sherry Llewellyn.

WJZ-TV reported that the security cameras were only recently installed. The homeowner, who didn't want to be named, decided to upgrade their home security following a previous break-in.
fields.summary: Police in Highland, Maryland, are on the lookout for a man they've dubbed the "preppy burglar," after he was caught on a homeowner's security cameras robbing the home in a shirt and tie.

fields.heading: Beloit police launch 'If I were a Thief' program
fields.content:
Police in Beloit, Wisconsin, are continuing to make strides with a security awareness program designed to give residents a wake-up call about how vulnerable their vehicles may be to burglars, and the need for better home security systems, the Beloit Daily News reports.

Through its "If I was a Thief" program, officers go through residential neighborhoods, posting notices on any vehicles that they think could be easily broken into, along with a note about what made their car vulnerable to theft, such as unlocked doors, visible electronics or keys left in the ignition.

"The project is effective in that it creates a partnership with the community," Sergeant Daniel Molland told the paper.

Police told the paper that since the program was originally started three years ago, the number of auto thefts has significantly decreased - although they are still one of the most common crimes reported. The most common items stolen are car parts and personal items.

The city has one of the highest rates of crime in Wisconsin. FBI statistics show that Beloit has the fourth-highest level of violent crime in the state.
fields.summary: Police in Beloit, Wisconsin, are continuing to make strides with a security awareness program designed to give residents a wake-up call about how vulnerable their vehicles may be to burglars, and the need for better home security systems, the Beloit Daily News reports.

fields.heading: Despite high crime rate, Oakland plans to cut police officers
fields.content:
Officials in Oakland, California, say that residents will have to make do with even fewer police officers in the coming months, as budget cuts forced the city to lay off 80 more officers last month.

Police chief Tony Batts told the City Council this week that the city should have more than 900 officers patrolling the streets. But after recent cuts, there will be fewer than 700.

Batts added that the city has much a higher crime rate than other surrounding areas. Homicides and shootings are three times more common in Oakland than in other large California cities, while violent crimes overall are more than twice as common. In addition, police officers took an average of 15 minutes to respond to a 911 call - nearly twice as slow as the next closest major city in the state - putting increased importance on home security monitoring to help protect residents.

The city's financial situation does not appear to be improving as of yet. KGO-TV reports that Oakland's budget deficit could grow from $30 million this year to $50 million during the next cycle.
fields.summary: Officials in Oakland, California, say that residents will have to make do with even fewer police officers in the coming months, as budget cuts forced the city to lay off 80 more officers last month.

fields.heading: Sarasota installing cameras to reduce crime near public housing
fields.content:
Officials at the Sarasota, Florida, housing authority are preparing to install a series of 21 security cameras in order to help cut down crime near the city's public housing units, the Herald Tribune reports.

Many of the 500 families living in the buildings had pleaded for the cameras to help discourage criminal activity, such as drug dealing, in the area, according to the paper. The city had planned to install six cameras, but a grant from the Department of Housing and Development helped fund for more of them.

"I think it will actually be a deterrent," Bill Russell, executive director of the housing authority, told the paper. "I think it will reduce a lot of that unwanted criminal activity."

The city has used cameras in the past with great success. Police told the paper that crime dropped 78 percent after the city installed security cameras in a nearby park.

In other efforts to stem the area's rising crime rate, police are also stepping up enforcement of curfew laws. According to WWSB-TV, officers are working with the Department of Juvenile Justice to keep a closer eye on the roughly 180 kids who are on probation because of past offenses. If they're not home during a curfew check, then their probation officer is notified.
fields.summary: Officials at the Sarasota, Florida, housing authority are preparing to install a series of 21 security cameras in order to help cut down crime near the city's public housing units, the Herald Tribune reports.

fields.heading: Burglaries showing sharp rise in Mechanicville
fields.content:
Police in Mechanicville, New York, are asking residents to step up their precautions, as they work to stem a growing tide of residential burglaries in the area.

According to the Troy Record, there have been 38 burglaries in the town so far this year - a 50 percent increase over last year. In addition, roughly a third of those crimes remain unsolved.

Police told the paper that while many factors have led to the increase in crime, many residents aren't taking the proper precautions. After noticing the increasing number of crimes earlier this year, police went around town to check on properties. They found that at more than 60 homes, doors were simply left open or unlocked.

"If residents and business owners would add extra precautionary measures, it would help immensely," police chief Joseph Waldron told the paper. "The citizens of Mechanicville have an inherent responsibility to protect themselves too."

Police have recommended that residents consider adding home alarm systems, security cameras and additional lights to help deter further robberies.

Despite the increased police presence, the burglaries have continued, including one earlier this week. The Record reported on Monday that a pair of men held an area apartment resident at gunpoint as they searched his apartment.
fields.summary: Police in Mechanicville, New York, are asking residents to step up their precautions, as they work to stem a growing tide of residential burglaries in the area.

fields.heading: Security expert describes low-cost deterrents
fields.content:
A home security expert in Gwinnett, Georgia, says that while home security systems are important, many homeowners also overlook some simple steps they can take to protect their homes.

Jordan Frankel, an official with a Georgia-based home security firm, told the Gwinnett Daily Post that the floundering economy has fueled a rise in robberies.

"The economy is so bad, the typical home-invader is now stealing items and cash to put food on their own table," Frankel told the paper. "This is not something our government and law enforcement typically wants to report, because it's such a violent crime. With victims, there is such a psychological, brutal trail left behind."

In addition to installing home alarm systems, Frankel says that residents can leave a large pair of men's boots outside the front door to suggest that someone is home, and install motion-activated lighting to startle a potential intruder who might approach the home.

But despite perceptions of worsening crime, statistics show that crime in the local Gwinnett area is actually decreasing. Recent FBI statistics showed that the city actually experienced a drop in crime from 2008 to 2009.
fields.summary: A home security expert in Gwinnett, Georgia, says that while home security systems are important, many homeowners also overlook some simple steps they can take to protect their homes.

fields.heading: Police say businesses, residents not protecting themselves
fields.content:
Officials in Buffalo, Missouri, say that local residents and business owners aren't doing enough to protect themselves from crime, the Buffalo Reflex reports.

Police told the paper that many business owners view security cameras and burglar alarms as an added expense, without thinking about the long-term costs of not having them.

"It's amazing, but true, that there are still a lot of businesses that don't have burglar alarms and/or video cameras and a lot of people who don't lock their cars," Buffalo police chief Sam Hartsell told the paper, adding that the burglar alarms "can be a savings in the long run."

Police told the paper that while the number of crimes in the area has actually dropped compared with last year, residents have reacted to a number of high-profile incidents that have dominated local headlines.

While burglaries have dropped in the city - part of a nationwide trend - violent crime has followed a different trend. According to the FBI, violent robberies in the state increased by 0.8 percent from 2008 to 2009.
fields.summary: Officials in Buffalo, Missouri, say that local residents and business owners aren't doing enough to protect themselves from crime, the Buffalo Reflex reports.

fields.heading: Lighting companies seeing many residents upgrade security
fields.content:
As some neighborhoods are seeing an increase in crime as the economy continues to struggle, many homeowners are buying additional lighting to upgrade their own home security systems, the Journal and Courier of West Lafayette, Indiana reports.

Local electricians told the paper that while most outdoor lighting projects are done in the spring, the fall is traditionally when they see a big uptick in the number of people who buy additional lighting to protect themselves and their homes from burglars.

"We do quite a bit of work," local electrician Chris Voglund told the paper. "People are trying to light up patios and garage spaces to get additional protection."

Electricians also told the Journal and Courier that the technology behind motion-activated lighting has made great strides in recent years, allowing lights to blend in better with the home, and also offer greater energy-efficiency.

The location of those lights is also a critical consideration. According to the Los Angeles Times, it's important to mount lights high enough so they can't be reached by a ladder, otherwise, burglars can easily deactivate them.
fields.summary: As some neighborhoods are seeing an increase in crime as the economy continues to struggle, many homeowners are buying additional lighting to upgrade their own home security systems, the Journal and Courier of West Lafayette, Indiana reports.

fields.heading: Boston seeing spike in violent crimes
fields.content:
After Boston police oversaw a number of recent years with falling crime, the Boston Globe reports that the city is now experiencing a significant rise in violent offenses that is driving many residents to upgrade their home security systems.

According to the paper, the city has seen a 32 percent increase in murders so far this year compared with the same time period last year. In addition, nonfatal shootings and burglaries are also up significantly compared with 2009.

"It's been a strange summer nationwide," Boston police chief Edward Davis told the paper. "We're all struggling with decreases in resources and increases in crimes, which is a significant challenge."

The Globe reports that the city has generally had a relatively low murder rate for a large city - with eight homicides for every 100,000 residents, compared to 37 per 100,000 in Baltimore.

Local police departments have been forced to deal with a number of budget cuts. USA Today reports that residents in the Norton suburb have been told to file their own police reports for lesser crimes because the city doesn't have the police resources to do it.
fields.summary: After Boston police oversaw a number of recent years with falling crime, the Boston Globe reports that the city is now experiencing a significant rise in violent offenses that is driving many residents to upgrade their home security systems.

fields.heading: Plattsburgh police department adding security cameras
fields.content:
Police officers in Plattsburgh, Vermont, are installing a series of new security cameras in the city's downtown area in an effort to cut down on crime in that section of the city, WCAX-TV reports.

According to the station, the cameras will be placed in strategic locations, and while they won't be monitored around the clock, constant recording will allow police to look back at the data recorded and see if they can identify suspects or witnesses after crimes occur.

"They are just another investigative tool in the downtown area. It's having eyes on the street," Plattsburgh's police chief, Desmond Racicot, told the station.

The city also won't have to pick up the cost of the system. The station reports that a private company has picked up the costs, in return for the department providing it a secure location to store some of its data storage equipment.

Statewide, Vermont has seen rising levels of violent crime. According to the Vermont Criminal Information Center, violent crimes increased 2.3 percent from 2008 to 2009, and drug crimes increased by more than 22 percent.
fields.summary: Police officers in Plattsburgh, Vermont, are installing a series of new security cameras in the city's downtown area in an effort to cut down on crime in that section of the city, WCAX-TV reports.

fields.heading: St. Louis touts drop in crime ... after changing counting rules
fields.content:
Officials in St. Louis, Missouri, recently announced a drop in crime compared with last year, but failed to tell the public that the new figures also included a change in the way the city counts the number of crimes, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reports.

The paper says that while the city's police chief, Dan Isom, said that crime had dropped 25 percent over the last tree years, but he failed to account for the city's recent switch to comply with the FBI's crime counting methods - which often count a number of crimes close together as one incident instead of many.

One local expert says that the department needs to be more upfront when it discusses crime data, because residents and business owners installing burglar alarms rely on the data.

"When a change is made, the public is owed an explanation," Rick Rosenfeld, a criminologist at the University of Missouri-St. Louis, told the paper. "Especially when you begin to count multiple victimizations as one."

Isom told the paper that even after accounting for the difference, he feels that the crime rate in the city has still fallen dramatically.

Even the city's mayor has weighed in on the issue. Last week, Mayor Francis Slay told the Post-Dispatch that he felt that statements by police were "garbled" and that the department didn't properly communicate the switch.
fields.summary: Officials in St. Louis, Missouri, recently announced a drop in crime compared with last year, but failed to tell the public that the new figures also included a change in the way the city counts the number of crimes, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reports.

fields.heading: More homeowners purchasing home security systems
fields.content:
Even as the economy continues to struggle, home security companies say that they are seeing an increase in the sales of home security products.

Sales figures from the website InstantSpy.net show a significant uptick in the sales of burglar alarms and other home security devices in recent months, even as consumers as a whole are struggling financially.

"I think that in times of difficulty, individuals are more likely to commit crimes, poverty increases and so do the chances of suffering a home invasion," said Nicholas Halmond, sales manager at InstantSpy.net. "People are willing to spend on an alarm system or security camera system because they feel the need for protection at the moment."

The site added that advances in technology, such as high-tech security cameras, have made it easier for homeowners to secure their property against burglars and other criminals.

Poverty has increased across the country in recent months, leading to rising crime rates in some areas. Statistics from the Census Bureau released last week found that one in seven Americans are below the poverty line.
fields.summary: Even as the economy continues to struggle, home security companies say that they are seeing an increase in the sales of home security products.

fields.heading: Columbus residents concerned about relocation of officers
fields.content:
The residents in one Columbus, Ohio, neighborhood are voicing concern, as a number of police officers are being transferred to other areas of the city, WCMH-TV reports.

Over the last few weeks, the station reports that at least six officers have been transferred away from the city's south side. That reduction has led to a drop in police patrols - a situation that has many residents upset.

"We don't see the police presence as much any more in the neighborhoods and due to that fact and the loss of that police presence, there is some concern in the neighborhood," local resident Kristina Bryd told the station.

The area has also seen an uptick in property crime, according to the station. In response, residents have begun installing home alarm systems and forming block watch groups to keep an eye out for suspicious activity.

The city as a whole has also seen a rise in violent crime. While crime fell significantly in 2009, 2010 has been a different story. Earlier this month WCMH-TV reported that the city was already approaching its murder total for all of last year.
fields.summary: The residents in one Columbus, Ohio, neighborhood are voicing concern, as a number of police officers are being transferred to other areas of the city, WCMH-TV reports.

fields.heading: New York police report crime increase in 88th precinct
fields.content:
Police in New York City's 88th precinct say they're experiencing a rise in crime in the area so far this year, the New York Times reports.

During a meeting of the area's Community Council, police captain Anthony Tasso told area residents that the region has seen a more than 15 percent increase in crime over the past four weeks.

When asked by residents about a perceived lack of patrols in some areas, Tasso said that the department has been forced to allocate its resources towards more high-crime areas, and that residents should take precautions and be sure their home security systems are enough to keep them safe.

"We don't have the manpower we used to have," Captain Tasso said, according to the paper. "If I'm not deploying personnel near the senior center, it's a good thing because it means that people aren't getting robbed there or victimized."

The announcement comes just a short time after New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg touted a drop in the city's crime rate earlier this month. City officials say that the total crime rate in the city had fallen by 5.1 percent in 2009, and dropped further so far in 2010.
fields.summary: Police in New York City's 88th precinct say they're experiencing a rise in crime in the area so far this year, the New York Times reports.

fields.heading: Home security cameras lead to quick arrest
fields.content:
Police in Sharpsburg, Georgia, say that home security cameras mounted on one local home helped them track down the suspects that decided to rob it, the Times-Herald reports.

The burglary occurred earlier this month. Three suspects entered the home and made off with a large television. But, as the paper reports, what they didn't know was that the home had motion-sensing security cameras mounted outside.

After the robbery, police downloaded the memory card from the camera. Among the many images on the camera was one with a picture of the suspects' green Honda, and a clear shot of its license plate.

The three suspects - between 26 and 19 years of age - were arrested the following day. The paper reports that police also suspect them in a number of other robberies in the area, and more charges could soon be filed.

Residents in the state have seen a large number of burglaries in recent years. According to FBI statistics, the state experienced more than 98,000 burglaries in 2009, which actually showed a slight drop from the more than 100,000 the year before.
fields.summary: Police in Sharpsburg, Georgia, say that home security cameras mounted on one local home helped them track down the suspects that decided to rob it, the Times-Herald reports.

fields.heading: Wichita burglar caught on home security camera
fields.content:
A burglar who went through a residential Wichita, Kansas, neighborhood was captured on home security cameras, but the incident has left a number of residents shaken.

Footage from the cameras, taken in broad daylight, show the burglar going from door to door looking for unsecured homes. Police said he hit four homes within a short period of time, some of them while people were still at home.

"It's the manner in which he went about it is what scares everyone," local resident Roger Nelson told KWCH-TV. "You think because we're in a gated community we're safer than most, but that's not the case. You still have to be vigilant about what's going on."

So far, the suspect has not been captured, although police said they were still looking. Police report that he got away with a purse, jewelry and cash.

Police added that many burglaries are simply the result of homeowners leaving their houses unsecured. They said that residents should take precautions - making sure that their home security systems are activated and that all doors and garages are securely locked.
fields.summary: A burglar who went through a residential Wichita, Kansas, neighborhood was captured on home security cameras, but the incident has left a number of residents shaken.

fields.heading: James Island residents taking action amid continued burglary spike
fields.content:
A continued rise in burglaries has many residents on South Carolina's James Island on edge.
