The Post and Courier reports that many residents are installing home security systems, locking their doors and even buying guns to protect themselves. One resident told the paper that he saw an alarm company truck in the neighborhood nearly every day.

Burglaries in the small community near Charleston have sharply risen over the last several weeks. Since the beginning of August, the county sheriff's office has investigated at least 24 burglaries - nearly one every other night - while Charleston police have investigated at least 15 more.

"At one time James Island was a place where people could leave the doors open," town councilwoman Karen Wilder-Smalls, who has been organizing neighborhood crime watches, told the paper.

The brazen nature of the burglars is what has startled many homeowners. In some cases, the paper reports, burglars have taken the time to enjoy food and beverages from inside the home as they make away with high-priced electronics.

Last week, a meeting between residents and police drew a crowd of more than 100, as officers attempted to give residents tips to improve their home security, the Post and Courier reported.
fields.summary: A continued rise in burglaries has many residents on South Carolina's James Island on edge.

fields.heading: Community members in Santa Cruz come together to drive down crime
fields.content:
Residents in a Santa Cruz, California, neighborhood say that their community involvement has helped drive down crime in one of the city's toughest neighborhoods, the San Jose Mercury News reports.

The paper reports that Neighbors of Lower Ocean, a group of concerned residents, was started in 1994, as the city deal with rampant crime. As the group grew, the crime rate continued to fall, reducing the number of police calls by 70 percent from 1995 to 1998. Residents say that home security systems and continued involvement have helped keep the streets clean.

"Ocean Street was getting worse, month by month, year by year. There would be more dealers, more prostitutes ... Now, you don't see any gang members, any prostitutes get called in [by residents], police patrol more and there's neighbor involvement," resident Paul Martin told the paper.

Neighbors of Lower Ocean, along with other similar local groups, will come together later this month in the second-annual Neighbor Night Out, during which residents will meet with city officials to discuss security and crime.

The city has seen a number of violent crimes in recent weeks. In just the past week, the paper reports that some residents have been shaken by a pair of shootings, and there have been a total of 13 homicides already this year.
fields.summary: Residents in a Santa Cruz, California, neighborhood say that their community involvement has helped drive down crime in one of the city's toughest neighborhoods, the San Jose Mercury News reports.

fields.heading: New York city seeing sharp rise in shootings
fields.content:
Many of the most dangerous neighborhoods in New York City are experiencing a sharp rise in the number of murders that have taken place in the city so far this year, a trend that has made many residents nervous.

According to statistics released by the New York Police Department, 386 people have been killed in the city so far this year, a 13 percent increase compared to the same time period last year. The increase in crime may be causing many residents to install home alarm systems to try and protect themselves.

"People are not working, there are no jobs, so people are out on the street," Karen Brown, a home health aide, told the New York Daily News. "You aren't even secure when you're inside your own home."

The increase has been sharpest in the Bronx, where homicides have risen by 46 percent compared to last year. Murder rates have also risen by more than 12 percent in Queens and Manhattan.

The rise in homicides is actually part of a trend that is reflected in many violent crimes in the city. While the overall crime rate has dropped by 1.5 percent so far this year, most categories of felonies have taken place with an increasing frequency, including a 13.5 percent increase in the number of rapes.
fields.summary: Many of the most dangerous neighborhoods in New York City are experiencing a sharp rise in the number of murders that have taken place in the city so far this year, a trend that has made many residents nervous.

fields.heading: Police chiefs nationwide fear increase in crime due to budget cuts
fields.content:
As cities and towns across the country deal with continued budget cuts, many police departments have found themselves short-staffed and fear that criminals may try to take advantage, the Washington Post reports.

In Lawrence, Massachusetts, the paper reports that budget issues forced the police department to cut special units focused on drugs and auto theft. Once the cuts took effect this summer, officials saw auto thefts spike.

"It's what's happening to all police departments, I get it," Lawrence police chief John Romero told the paper. "But it's had a major impact on our city." Romero added that before the cuts, the city had seen crime fall 60 percent since 1999.

Other cities have reported similar issues. The Washington, D.C. police department currently has 100 unfilled open positions, a situation which the district's police chief told the paper makes her "a little nervous."

Earlier this year, a survey by the Police Executive Research Forum revealed the level of concern by police. The report found that 63 percent of local police departments were faced with budget cuts this year, and 44 percent reported increases in crime.
fields.summary: As cities and towns across the country deal with continued budget cuts, many police departments have found themselves short-staffed and fear that criminals may try to take advantage, the Washington Post reports.

fields.heading: Simi Valley police warn of burglaries at vacant homes
fields.content:
Police in Simi Valley, California, say that they've noticed a number of recent reports of burglary involving homes that are vacant or for sale, the Contra Costa Times reports.

Officers told the paper that burglars are typically posing as workmen, and taking anything of value from the home, such as appliances, fixtures, copper wiring and even swimming pool equipment.

"Mostly, it's homes with a for-sale sign out front – it's no different if it's been foreclosed or not," Lieutenant Joe May told the paper. "Realtors who have homes listed, and homeowners, should be vigilant."

According to the paper, officers have advised real estate agents to be alert to any strange work trucks parked in driveways, and consider using GPS tracking devices to help locate them if they are taken.

Earlier this month, the Ventura County Star reported that the city had seen a sharp increase in crime so far this year. The paper said that, compared with last year, property crime had risen 18 percent from January through August.
fields.summary: Police in Simi Valley, California, say that they've noticed a number of recent reports of burglary involving homes that are vacant or for sale, the Contra Costa Times reports.

fields.heading: Police noticing property crime increase outside Houston
fields.content:
Officials in Conroe, Texas - located outside of Houston - say that they're noticing a sharp uptick in crime over the past few years as the economy has gone south.

The Courier of Montgomery County reports that the number of property crimes has increased each of the last two years, and that the rate of property crimes in the city was nearly 8 percent higher in 2009 than it was in 2007. Officials say that higher unemployment and widespread financial troubles may be playing a significant part in the increase.

"What I think we have seen over 2009-10 is that as the economy is slowing down, the number of property crimes have increased," Conroe police sergeant Bob Berry told the paper. "Most of these crimes are property crimes that involve small items that can be pawned or sold on the street."

Berry added that an increase in the area's population may also have played a part in the crime increase, as the city added more than 6,000 residents over that two year span, according to the Courier.

The problem is not limited to Conroe. The Houston Chronicle reports that 14 cities in the Houston area saw more violent and property crime in 2009 than they did in 2008.
fields.summary: Officials in Conroe, Texas - located outside of Houston - say that they're noticing a sharp uptick in crime over the past few years as the economy has gone south.

fields.heading: Police focusing on crime near Orlando's Amway Center
fields.content:
With the city of Orlando preparing for the start of basketball season - and the influx of people that come along with it - police in that area are are putting an increased focus on preventing crime in the area surrounding the Amway Center.

WOFL-TV reports that the arena - home to the NBA's Magic, and the host of several other notable events every year - sits just a few blocks away from one of the worst crime areas in the city. For those who aren't native to the urban area, the city can seem like an imposing place.

To increase security around the arena, police have added a number of security cameras to keep an eye on any disturbances that might arise. In addition, the station says that police are also planning to run bicycle patrols throughout the area on game days.

County officials are also putting a continued focus on preventing crime. Last month, Orange County officials held a meeting with residents, saying that police would continue to come up with new ways to prevent crime, but that community involvement would play a critical role.
fields.summary: With the city of Orlando preparing for the start of basketball season - and the influx of people that come along with it - police in that area are are putting an increased focus on preventing crime in the area surrounding the Amway Center.

fields.heading: Some crimes tougher to solve than others
fields.content:
While the incidence of many crimes has fallen in recent years, that doesn't mean that those crimes that are committed are being prosecuted. Writing for Georgia's Fayette Daily News, Scott Ballard, the local district attorney, says that police are still having a difficult time making arrests for a wide variety of crimes.

Ballard says that in Georgia, police have had the most difficult time trying to solve motor vehicle thefts and burglaries. From 2005 to 2009, the best arrest rate for car thefts was just 8.5 percent, meaning that unless the car is equipped with a GPS tracking system, it's unlikely that officials will be able to arrest the person responsible.

Burglaries are also notoriously difficult for police to make an arrest. During the same four-year span, the arrest rate for burglaries ranged from 9.9 to 10.5 percent.

"Burglary is the second hardest index crime to solve," Ballard writes. "That's why burglar alarms and neighborhood watch programs are so important."

The issues are not limited to crime in Georgia. FBI statistics show that the percentage of property value recovered from auto thefts fell from 59 percent to 56.8 percent from 2006 to 2009.
fields.summary: While the incidence of many crimes has fallen in recent years, that doesn't mean that those crimes that are committed are being prosecuted. Writing for Georgia's Fayette Daily News, Scott Ballard, the local district attorney, says that police are still having a difficult time making arrests for a wide variety of crimes.

fields.heading: Queens reporting rise in vehicle thefts, homicides
fields.content:
New statistics show that vehicle thefts and homicides in the Queens borough of New York City have risen significantly so far this year.

According to the New York Daily News, the number of shootings and murders have risen sharply. During the first nine months of this year compared with the same time period last year, Astoria has seen shootings more than double from nine to 19 and murders jump from two to seven.

In addition, auto thefts have risen 11.9 percent over the first nine months of this year when compared to the same time period last year, giving a greater urgency for residents to protect their vehicle with GPS tracking devices.

"It's surprising that number has gone up," John Jay College of Criminal Justice professor Eugene O'Donnell told the paper. "People may be less diligent about [protecting] their vehicles because crime in the borough and the city has gone down so much."

Police told the paper that recently, many thieves have been using a new skeleton key that will unlock a number of Toyota vehicles.

Some Toyota vehicles were already highly targeted by car thieves, even without the key. Both the Toyota Camry and Corolla appeared on this year's most-stolen cars list from the National Insurance Crime Bureau.
fields.summary: New statistics show that vehicle thefts and homicides in the Queens borough of New York City have risen significantly so far this year.

fields.heading: Several L.A. suburbs report significant crime spike
fields.content:
Five neighborhoods in the West San Fernando Valley outside of Los Angeles have reported significant increases in crime well above normal levels, according to crime alerts from the L.A. Times' Crime L.A. database.

In the areas of Northridge and Canoga Park, a number of recent assaults and rapes triggered the alerts - which were based on crime data for the week ending September 25. A sharp increase in auto thefts was noticed in Porter Ranch and Winnetka, while a number of robberies and assaults in West Hills was also out of character for the area.

A crime alert is triggered if LAPD crime reports for a specific neighborhood rise a significant amount above normal crime levels for that area. However, for low-crime areas, even a small increase in crime can trigger an alert.

The crime alerts system has noticed significant crime spikes in just its first few days of operation. As the database was launched last week, police told the Los Angeles Times that it was a way to help residents "better understand what's going on in our communities."
fields.summary: Five neighborhoods in the West San Fernando Valley outside of Los Angeles have reported significant increases in crime well above normal levels, according to crime alerts from the L.A. Times' Crime L.A. database.

fields.heading: Security cameras help police catch burglary suspect
fields.content:
Police say that one Connecticut resident's decision to install home security cameras following past burglaries at his home helped them identify and arrest a suspect after the most recent incident, the Stamford Advocate reports.

The homeowner was watching the video feed from the cameras when he noticed a young man running away from the home after setting off the burglar alarm. The youth attempted to flee the scene, but was quickly caught by police, the paper reports.

Upon returning to the house, police found a window smashed in the home's master bedroom, but according to the paper, the suspect ran off before they were able to take anything of value. In addition, after looking at the video from the home's cameras, police were able to identify the suspect as the one that had broken into the home, and placed the 17-year-old under arrest.

The area has seen a significant rise in burglaries in recent months. According to statistics from the FBI, burglaries in Stamford jumped almost 14 percent over the last year.
fields.summary: Police say that one Connecticut resident's decision to install home security cameras following past burglaries at his home helped them identify and arrest a suspect after the most recent incident, the Stamford Advocate reports.

fields.heading: Miami community considers fences to cut down on crime
fields.content:
Crime in one Miami neighborhood has deteriorated to the point that officials are considering putting up barriers around the community.

The Miami Herald reports that the Liberty Square residents' council is debating whether to put up fences or walls that would block all but two access points in the area. The logic of the plan, according to the paper, is to contain the high-crime areas to prevent them from spreading, and make it easier for police to catch suspects who tried to escape after setting off home alarm systems.

"We got to try something," Sara Smith, president of the Liberty Square residents' council, told the paper. "Too many people are getting shot."

The idea actually has precedent in the area. In 1987, the state government fenced off a nine-block area in Opa-Locka which became known as "The Triangle." The crime rate has fallen drastically since then, but the paper says that some residents think that the barriers were less of a factor than police cracking down on the drug trade.

Residents have also taken action to help drive down crime in the area. Last month, the Herald reported that members of a neighborhood organization have been going door-to-door to get residents to report crimes and seeing what concerns they have.
fields.summary: Crime in one Miami neighborhood has deteriorated to the point that officials are considering putting up barriers around the community.

fields.heading: Fairfax police offering free home security survey
fields.content:
Police officers in Fairfax County, Virginia are now making house calls to make sure that residents are safe in their homes.

The department is encouraging residents to take advantage of their free home security survey program where a crime prevention officer will come to a resident's home and give them recommendations to help deter burglars, such as motion-activated lighting or security cameras.

"An officer will come to your house, walk around your house, and go over things you can do to protect your home," Bud Walker, Public Information Officer for FCPD, told the Annandale Patch. "There are things people can do to make a home less of a target to burglars. "

Local police also offer training for residents interested in starting a Neighborhood Watch program, which officers say also play an important role in preventing crime.

The city has been the site of a recent series of burglaries. The Fairfax Police Department says that there have been at least 87 separate incidents, including 57 burglaries and numerous other thefts from unlocked vehicles.
fields.summary: Police officers in Fairfax County, Virginia are now making house calls to make sure that residents are safe in their homes.

fields.heading: Flint police recruiting residents to help with Halloween patrols
fields.content:
Officials in Flint, Michigan, are asking area residents to volunteer to help deter crime over the upcoming Halloween weekend, and asking others to stay alert and keep their home security systems active.

The city says it expects to have about 70 to 80 volunteers walking the streets over the weekend as part of its Blue Badge Patrol program, looking for signs of trouble.

"This community has a history of arsons around Halloween and Devil's Night," Flint Mayor Dayne Walling, told WJRT-TV. "We know that what prevents these crimes from taking place is people being vigilant in their own areas."

Although Halloween falls on a Sunday this year, the city is observing it on Saturday in order to keep kids off the streets during a school night.

The city already deals with high levels of crime on a regular basis, a trend that has not improved this year. Late last month, the city recorded its 50th homicide of the year. Even with three more months in the year, that number is already the fourth-highest total since 1986.
fields.summary: Officials in Flint, Michigan, are asking area residents to volunteer to help deter crime over the upcoming Halloween weekend, and asking others to stay alert and keep their home security systems active.

fields.heading: Report: Chicago home to country's most dangerous neighborhood
fields.content:
A new report says that the most dangerous neighborhood in the country is in Chicago, although local law enforcement officials disagree.

According to a study of crime statistics by NeighborhoodScout.com, the area surrounding West Lake Street in Chicago had the highest rate of violent crime the country. The report said that people in that area had a one in four chance of becoming a victim over the course of a year, enough motivation for many to purchase home alarm systems.

However, official police statistics paint a completely different picture of area crime. The Chicago Police Department says that the area was relatively safe, ranking 775th out of 873 census tracts in the city in terms of total crime.

WBBM-TV in Chicago reports that the area highlighted in the study, which is located just a few blocks away from the United Center arena, was the former site of a major public housing development, which was demolished in 2007. Most of that land is currently vacant.

Other cities also fared very poorly in the NeighborhoodScout.com study. The report also listed three Las Vegas neighborhoods in its top 10, along with a pair of areas in Atlanta.
fields.summary: A new report says that the most dangerous neighborhood in the country is in Chicago, although local law enforcement officials disagree.

fields.heading: Burglars hit wealthy Virginia neighborhood
fields.content:
Officials in Virginia are investigating whether a string of recent burglaries in Prince William County - outside of Washington, D.C. - may be connected to a series of recent crimes in nearby Fairfax, WJLA-TV reports.

The station reports that someone robbed four residents in the pricey Haymarket community, taking cash and purses while residents slept. In two cases, the burglar was able to enter the home through an unlocked garage door, while another involved an unlocked car.

Police, who have described the thieves as brazen, have reminded residents to remember to arm their home security systems - even when they're home - and to make sure that all of their doors and windows are locked.

"I can't imagine doing that. I really can't. I mean, people are in their home. They were at night," resident Norbert Lucash told the station.

Police say the crimes may be connected to a series of dozens of crimes in nearby Fairfax county, which have also targeted wealthier households looking for cash. More than 90 homes in Fairfax County have been burglarized recently.
fields.summary: Officials in Virginia are investigating whether a string of recent burglaries in Prince William County - outside of Washington, D.C. - may be connected to a series of recent crimes in nearby Fairfax, WJLA-TV reports.

fields.heading: Crime increase in Montgomery County
fields.content:
Federal statistics show that Montgomery County, Texas, has experienced a sharp increase in crime over the past year.

The Conroe Courier reports that according to the FBI, the crime rate in the county jumped by nearly 13 percent from 2008 to 2009, with significant increases in violent crimes, burglaries and vehicle thefts, a trend which may be leading many residents to install home security systems. Perhaps the sharpest increase was seen in auto thefts, which jumped from 362 in 2008 to 680 in 2009.

"Some crimes are not preventable," Montgomery County Sheriff's Lieutenant Dan Norris told the paper. "Police agencies cannot prevent some forms of violent crimes from occurring, even if you put a police officer on every corner. These crimes are going to occur."

One possible factor in the increases, the paper reports, is the increase in population that the region has experienced in recent years. Since 2007, the county's population has increased by more than 35,000.

At the same time, area police departments have been facing the budget ax in recent months. Both the Magnolia and Pearland Police Departments have cut multiple officers for the upcoming fiscal year.
fields.summary: Federal statistics show that Montgomery County, Texas, has experienced a sharp increase in crime over the past year.

fields.heading: Phoenix mayor becomes burglary victim
fields.content:
Phoenix Mayor Phil Gordon's private security detail couldn't prevent him from becoming a crime victim over the weekend, as burglars broke into his home early Saturday morning.

The mayor said that he woke up at roughly 4 a.m. Saturday to make coffee, but didn't notice anything unusual until 6:30 a.m., when he found that his back door had been damaged and his computer had been taken, the Arizona Republic reports.. Officials say he may have actually scared off the burglars when he woke up, so they weren't able to take anything else.

Police quickly arrived on the scene to collect evidence, but no one has been arrested yet.

The mayor has a five-person security detail, including four detectives and a sergeant, but doesn't necessarily have someone on-duty 24-hours a day. There was no word whether any home security systems were installed at the mayor's home, or whether the alarm simply wasn't activated.

KTVK-TV reports that a meeting is expected to take place today between his staff and the Phoenix Police Department to see if there will be an increase in security for the mayor following the incident.
fields.summary: Phoenix Mayor Phil Gordon's private security detail couldn't prevent him from becoming a crime victim over the weekend, as burglars broke into his home early Saturday morning.

fields.heading: Crime increase prompts special patrols in Detroit
fields.content:
A sharp rise in crime in the Osborn community of Detroit - with more than 500 crimes in September alone - has prompted officials to set up a special patrol in the area.

The county sheriff's office has dedicated five deputies to the area, who will be available by cell phone to respond to any crime reports or burglar alarms that have been triggered. The officers will operate separate from 911, and will be on task at all hours of the day.

"We are not a substitute for 911," Wayne County Sheriff Benny Napoleon told the Detroit News. "We are an additional tool for the citizens of the area or the officers in the Detroit Police Department."

City officials hope that a successful few months will help them retain the grant which is funding the program. According to the paper, the money is set to go away in the spring.

The city, which has faced much of the brunt of the economic recession, has also experienced a corresponding rise in crime. According to FBI statistics, Detroit experienced a 2.2 percent increase in violent crime in 2009, wtih many suburbs seeing an even sharper rise.
fields.summary: A sharp rise in crime in the Osborn community of Detroit - with more than 500 crimes in September alone - has prompted officials to set up a special patrol in the area.

fields.heading: Columbus officials installing security cameras in high-crime neighborhoods
fields.content:
Police officers in Columbus, Ohio, will soon have access to a series of new security cameras mounted in high-crime areas around the city.

The 114 cameras will be installed in five different areas around the city. While they will be recording constantly, officials say they will only be specifically monitored during peak hours. To help allay privacy concerns, they will also include technology that will mask residential windows. Officials said the locations were chosen based on interest by area residents, crime statistics and information from patrol officers in the area.

"These cameras are not a silver bullet to end crime in the City of Columbus," Mayor Michael B. Coleman said in a statement. "They will be another tool officers can use to potentially prevent crimes before they happen and solve crimes after they happen."

Officials said that if the pilot program is a success, it could potentially be expanded to cover additional areas around the city.

The city has experienced a significant increase in violent crime this year. Last month, WCMH-TV reported that after only nine months of 2010, the city had almost reached its homicide total from all of 2009.
fields.summary: Police officers in Columbus, Ohio, will soon have access to a series of new security cameras mounted in high-crime areas around the city.

fields.heading: Topeka crime shows sharp rise from '09
fields.content:
Residents in Topeka may be working to install home alarm systems shortly, as police are reporting a significant crime increase over the past several months.

Police told WIBW-TV that so far this year, crime in the city has risen more than 7.5 percent compared with last year. In addition to an increase in homicides, rapes and assaults, officials say that there have been nearly 400 more thefts so far this year compared to the first nine months of 2009. Five of the murders in the city this year also remain unsolved. In those cases, police are asking the public for help.

"Our job is to keep the community safe," said Topeka Police sergeant Steve Taylor. "But we can't do that unless we have help from the community itself."

The rate of unsolved homicides is also not a new trend. The Topeka Capital-Journal reports that the city has failed to solve more than half of the city's murders in each each of the last three years. The paper says that in the past, the city's clearance rate has topped 80 percent.
fields.summary: Residents in Topeka may be working to install home alarm systems shortly, as police are reporting a significant crime increase over the past several months.

fields.heading: Family sleeps while burglar breaks in
fields.content:
Police in Palo Alto, California are warning residents to be on alert after a burglar broke into a local home over the weekend while the family was asleep inside.

Over the weekend, a burglar crept in through an open window, stole several items, and then took the keys to the family's vehicle and drove away in it. The family didn't even realize a crime had been committed until they woke up the following morning to find the items and the vehicle missing.

Police later recovered the car, but to this point have been unable to find any suspects.

Officials are asking residents to keep their windows closed, ensure any outdoor lighting is still working and arm their home alarm systems, even when they may be home.

The San Jose Mercury News reports that police are also investigating whether the incident is related to a similar crime earlier this year. In early July, a burglar entered a home on the same street, stealing a television a computer and various other electronics before getting away in the family's minivan.
fields.summary: Police in Palo Alto, California are warning residents to be on alert after a burglar broke into a local home over the weekend while the family was asleep inside.

fields.heading: Solid door and locks the first step against burglary
fields.content:
Workers at a local hardware store in Tennessee say they've seen a significant increase in the number of families looking to upgrade their home security.

WLVT-TV reports that many consumers have been out buying new locks or re-keying their homes, while others have been purchasing stronger doors.

"If someone was gonna try to kick it in it's gonna be a lot harder than an interior door which is hollow core. Or even a steel door is gonna be a little bit stronger because you're also gonna have steel framing," Lowe's foreman Charlie Rackette told the station.

Rackette added that the technology in home security systems has improved dramatically over the past few years, and that modern security cameras come in a variety of price ranges.

However, many burglaries are caused by simple carelessness, like leaving a window open that could make it easy for a burglar to enter the home. Past statistics from the FBI say that as many as two-thirds of burglars use an open window or unlocked door to enter a home.
fields.summary: Workers at a local hardware store in Tennessee say they've seen a significant increase in the number of families looking to upgrade their home security.

fields.heading: Modesto businesses form watch group after crime spike
fields.content:
A group of businesses in Modesto, California, are coming together to try to stop the sharp increase in burglaries, robberies and vandalism in recent months.

According to the Modesto Bee, the downtown businesses have formed the Business Crime Watch Group in an effort to upgrade their security measures and burglar alarms and better work with police to help fight the rising crime.

"We're not going to take this anymore," Jorge Martinez, pastor of Friendly Tabernacle Church - which has been robbed twice - told the paper. "We have people who have been here a long time and we won't back down."

One business owner told the paper that they used to notice crime or burglar once every six months or so. But now, their business has been victimized nearly once every two weeks, despite efforts to upgrade security.

Not even the county Democratic headquarters has been safe from the crime increase in the city. Earlier this month, someone threw rocks through many of the building's windows and spray-painted the walls. Police aren't sure if that crime was politically motivated.
fields.summary: A group of businesses in Modesto, California, are coming together to try to stop the sharp increase in burglaries, robberies and vandalism in recent months.

fields.heading: Crime rate rises in Manatee County
fields.content:
The overall crime rate in Florida's Manatee County jumped in the first half of 2010, led by a sharp increase in the number of burglaries.

According to data from the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, property crimes have risen by nearly 8 percent compared to the same period last year - an sharp increase of more than 500 incidents that may have led many residents to install home security systems. The steepest increase has been seen in Longboat Key, where there was a 19.6 percent increase in total crime over the first half of the year.

Officials say they are also facing a difficult challenge of trying to maintain a street presence while the city continues to cut budgets. The Bradenton Police Department says it's already hearing about more budget cuts, even after the department put some of its management staff back on the street.

"It's going to become a big concern. I can't predict what's going to happen in the future. It's going to be a difficult task for us if we have to cut again," Sheriff Brad Steube told the Bradenton Herald.

While the statewide crime rate has showed some improvement compared with previous years, it remains high in several areas. Tuesday, the FDLE said that murders had risen by 19 percent in Central Florida.
fields.summary: The overall crime rate in Florida's Manatee County jumped in the first half of 2010, led by a sharp increase in the number of burglaries.

fields.heading: Home security systems can give working parents peace of mind
fields.content:
For many working parents, it may be a source of worry not knowing what children are doing once they get home from school. But home security systems may help alleviate some of that nervousness for many parents.

Having a home alarm system and security cameras in place can reassure parents that nothing has gone wrong in their home, says Alarm.com, in addition to letting them see whether their children are actually doing their homework or just playing video games instead.

Using a cellular-based home security system also helps ensure that the home will still be protected even if a burglar attempts to cut the phone or internet cable in an attempt to stop an alarm from being triggered, according to the site. Many home security companies offer a cellular conversion service that can convert an existing system into a wireless one.

Both parents work in a majority of families - even those with young children - meaning that many children may spend a significant amount of time alone. Census data shows that in 2009, more than 64 percent of children under 6 years of age lived in a household where all of their parents were working - an increase of more than 4 percent compared to 2005.
fields.summary: For many working parents, it may be a source of worry not knowing what children are doing once they get home from school. But home security systems may help alleviate some of that nervousness for many parents.

fields.heading: Miami Beach crime spikes in 2010
fields.content:
New statistics show that residents in sunny Miami Beach may want to invest in home security systems, as crime in the area has increased significantly so far this year.

Data from the Florida Department of Law Enforcement shows that there were more than 4,900 reported crimes in the area during the first six months of the year - the highest number for that time period since 2004. Increases in crime were seen nearly across the board in every type of crime. Property crimes were the most prevalent since 2004, while violent crimes reached their highest level in three years and the number of homicides was most in more than a decade.

In addition, as the number of crimes increased, the number of arrests during the same time period also fell. The 4,925 arrests were the fewest in the area since 2006.

While officials told the Miami Herald that it was tough to find a reason for the increase in crime, the reduction of the police force may play a role, with police chief Carlos Noriega saying that fighting crime "becomes harder and harder when you don't have resources." Since 2007, the number of officers in the department has dropped from 403 to 370 - a reduction of more than 8 percent.
fields.summary: New statistics show that residents in sunny Miami Beach may want to invest in home security systems, as crime in the area has increased significantly so far this year.

fields.heading: Knoxville police say residents not taking proper security steps
fields.content:
Police in Knoxville, Tennessee, say that they're investigating a large number of vehicle burglaries in the area - mostly because residents aren't taking proper precautions.

Officials told WBIR-TV that they have received reports of nearly 100 recent crimes all over the city over the past few weeks, an unusual trend given that the increase is taking place before holiday shopping season picks up. In most cases, the vehicles were left unlocked, with no burglar alarms and valuables such as electronics and purses left in plain sight.

"It always increases over the holiday time, but we're already seeing the increase now," Knoxville Police lieutenant Tim Snoderly told the station. "You'd be surprised how often these criminals pull on car doors, waiting for a car door to be open."

So far, police aren't sure if the crimes are connected, but told the station that crimes outside of the city limits are taking place at roughly normal levels.

The spike in burglaries also goes against the local trends. According to FBI Statistics, property crime in the state last year actually decreased by just over 6 percent compared with the previous year.
fields.summary: Police in Knoxville, Tennessee, say that they're investigating a large number of vehicle burglaries in the area - mostly because residents aren't taking proper precautions.

fields.heading: Home security improvements can cut insurance costs
fields.content:
Experts say that some simple home security improvements - many of which are do-it-yourself projects - can not only help keep a home safe, they can also translate into financial savings.

The website lets-do-DIY reports that home insurance experts understand the importance of installing quality locks and home security systems, because they act as a strong deterrent to potential burglars.

"If a burglar is walking down the road and there are a couple of houses that he is interested in, if one has got an alarm flashing away and other one hasn't, then he may well take the easy option," insurance expert Graeme Trudgill told the site.

Trudgill added that homeowners considering adding home alarm systems should consult with their agent beforehand, so they can figure out how to get the biggest discount.

Those homeowners insurance savings can really add up. A 2007 report from the National Association of Home Builders said that while the bonuses for different devices such as burglar alarms or deadbolts can vary, many companies give combined discounts of up to 20 percent.
fields.summary: Experts say that some simple home security improvements - many of which are do-it-yourself projects - can not only help keep a home safe, they can also translate into financial savings.

fields.heading: Officials noticing uptick in vacant properties and connected crimes
fields.content:
Police in Rocky Mount, North Carolina, say that as the number of vacant properties in the area have increased, so have the number of crimes reported at those homes, the Rocky Mount Telegram reports.

According to the paper, while police patrol the areas surrounding known vacant properties, they have noticed a number of burglaries and fires at the homes, some of which may have been prevented if real estate agents installed home security systems.

"The circumstances really vary. At times, we see juveniles entering these residences doing vandalism or people stealing appliances," police captain Laura Fahnestock told the paper. "With older abandoned houses, we see prostitution and drug activities."

Police also told the paper that they have made pleas to residents to report any unusual activity, and not to assume that something has already been reported.

The issue is not limited to the East Coast by any means. According to the Ventura County Star, police in Simi Valley, California, say that burglars have been targeting vacant homes for everything from appliances to copper piping.
fields.summary: Police in Rocky Mount, North Carolina, say that as the number of vacant properties in the area have increased, so have the number of crimes reported at those homes, the Rocky Mount Telegram reports.

fields.heading: Halloween thieves caught on security cameras
fields.content:
One Colorado family has cancelled its usual display of Halloween spirit after a pair of thieves stole some of their decorations.

KWGN-TV reports that as the family slept, two men hopped over their fence and stole a number of decorations. They were caught on the home's security cameras, but no one has been caught yet.

In response, the family has taken down all of its holiday decorations. The family's yard is now bare, except for a large sign that says, "No Halloween due to thiefs."

"I didn't want to keep getting stolen from so I decided to take everything down," resident Elizabeth Coovert told the station. "Maybe we will try again next year, but this year, it's done."

The station says that the family's Halloween display is well known in the local area, and is known to attract families from miles away to see it.

While many areas have seen crime decrease in recent months, Colorado has not. According to figures from the Colorado Bureau of Investigation, the state's crime rate increased by 0.4 percent last year.
fields.summary: One Colorado family has cancelled its usual display of Halloween spirit after a pair of thieves stole some of their decorations.

fields.heading: Bangor crime rate triple the state average
fields.content:
New statistics show that Bangor, Maine has roughly triple the crime rate of the rest of the state, casting a shadow on its reputation as one of the safest cities in the country.

Data from the Maine Department of Public Safety showed that significant increases in the number of burglaries pushed the city's crime rate to 71.6 per 1,000 people last year. That ratio is much higher than the 25.3 for the rest of the state, and news that may lead some residents to purchase home alarm systems.

Local officials told the Bangor Daily News that they expected the rate to increase, but said the statistics don't say everything.

"We have to look at how crimes are reported, because these numbers account only for reportable crimes. We can't assume that every agency reports the same way," chief Ron Gastia told the paper.

Higher-than-normal levels of unemployment may also be playing a role in the large number of property crimes. While the jobless rate in the city was 4.7 percent in 2008, it jumped to 8.2 percent last year.
fields.summary: New statistics show that Bangor, Maine has roughly triple the crime rate of the rest of the state, casting a shadow on its reputation as one of the safest cities in the country.

fields.heading: Strong door frames can help prevent burglaries
fields.content:
As the economy continues to struggle, some areas have seen an increase in burglaries and home invasions. But while home security systems can help deter many burglars, and ensure others are caught, a strong door frame is also important to help prevent those crimes.

Citing FBI statistics, Door Security Pro says that in a vast majority of home invasions, the door frame fails to hold up to criminals' attempts to kick in or break down the door, because many of of those frames are made up of soft woods, such as pine or fir, that can't take the strain.

To prevent that issue, homeowners can either check to make sure that their door frame is of solid construction, and, if necessary, add reinforcing material, such as steel, to help ensure than the entryway isn't vulnerable.

However, many homeowners fail to take even the simplest steps to prevent burglaries. A recent check of homes by police in Mechanicville, New York, found that more than 60 homeowners hadn't even locked their doors to prevent illegal entry, the Troy Record reports.
fields.summary: As the economy continues to struggle, some areas have seen an increase in burglaries and home invasions. But while home security systems can help deter many burglars, and ensure others are caught, a strong door frame is also important to help prevent those crimes.

fields.heading: Chicago reassigning officers to deal with crime increase
fields.content:
The Chicago Police Department has reassigned about 150 officers to help cut down on crime in some of the city's most dangerous neighborhoods.

The officers are being moved from a crime unit, and will be dispatched as needed to the various communities under the direction of district commanders. The various district commanders have a close knowledge of the area, and know what kinds of things make each area unsafe. The Chicago Tribune reports that officials were concerned that officers weren't always policing the areas they were assigned to.

The department is also stepping up its use of a high school outreach program designed to curb gang violence. Officials say the program - which started in March - has been a success, with many students working to leave their gangs.

Police in the area are noticing a sharp increase in the number of vehicle thefts. The Tribune reports that area police are reporting a 23 percent increase in car thefts over the first nine months of the year - making GPS tracking a higher priority for many owners. More than 13,000 vehicles have been stolen so far this year.
fields.summary: The Chicago Police Department has reassigned about 150 officers to help cut down on crime in some of the city's most dangerous neighborhoods.

fields.heading: Burglars taking advantage of careless homeowners
fields.content:
While many homeowners have worked to increase their safety by adding home security systems, many of them are failing to actually use the system properly.

"Burglars have a special fondness for homeowners and business managers who neglect to arm their security devices," says Matthew De Gennaro, vice president of Video Surveillance Corp. "Intruders appreciate any additional help people unknowingly provide to make their criminal activity easier."

Gennaro adds that even for homes with home alarm systems, there are a number of ways that homeowners can leave themselves vulnerable. For example, leaving expensive children's toys outside, while not an obvious security risk, may signal that there are additional expensive items inside the house.

Other suggestions include making sure that a home appears lived-in while people may be away. While holding mail and newspaper deliveries are fairly common steps, it's also important to make sure a neighbor is signed up to shovel out a walkway in the winter, so those passing by will believe someone is home.

Many others make the mistake of leaving keys outside, which burglars can easily find. A survey earlier this year from M&S Insurance found that more than 15 percent of homeowners left keys to their home hidden outside.
fields.summary: While many homeowners have worked to increase their safety by adding home security systems, many of them are failing to actually use the system properly.

fields.heading: Safeguarding a home on Halloween
fields.content:
While Halloween is known for kids out trick-or-treating in various costumes, it's also known as a night when many homeowners become the victims of vandalism and burglary. But security expert Frank Fourchalk tells QMI that there are some simple steps that can help.

The first step, he writes, is not to leave the home vacant - making it a defenseless target. However, for people who are going away, it's important for them them to arm any home alarm systems, and lock all windows and doors to keep people from getting in. At the same time, he says that homeowners should be sure to turn on exterior lights - preferably on a motion-sensor - to light up the home when people approach.

Even for people who are home, Fourchalk says that homeowners can still take additional steps to protect themselves. Because many kids turn to mischief during Halloween, it might be a good step to tape shut a mail slot if it leads into the home to prevent anyone from slipping trash or smoke bombs in it.

Some neighborhoods have also organized walking patrols of parents to keep any eye out for any suspicious activity, WIVB-TV in Buffalo reports. Having adults out and about can sometimes discourage criminals from starting trouble, and send them to another area.
fields.summary: While Halloween is known for kids out trick-or-treating in various costumes, it's also known as a night when many homeowners become the victims of vandalism and burglary. But security expert Frank Fourchalk tells QMI that there are some simple steps that can help.

fields.heading: Burlington police warn of daytime burglary trend
fields.content:
Police in Burlington, North Carolina, say that they're noticing a growing trend of daytime burglaries in many of the more affluent areas around the city.

Officials in nearby Guilford County told the Times-News that there's been a significant uptick in the number of crimes committed during daylight hours. Burlington police added that the fall increase seems to be a recurring trend, as they noticed a jump in similar crimes around the same time last year.

"The last time this happened, people noticed suspicious vehicles but didn't call," Burlington police assistant chief Greg Seel told the paper. "A strange car in a neighborhood in the daytime is just as suspicious as a strange car in the neighborhood in the nighttime."

Police told the paper that they're asking residents to be sure they arm their home security systems, make sure their doors and windows are locked and keep any valuables out of sight.

While some areas of North Carolina have noticed decreasing crime in recent months, others have not. According to the State Bureau of Investigation, the state capital of Raleigh experienced a crime increase last year.
fields.summary: Police in Burlington, North Carolina, say that they're noticing a growing trend of daytime burglaries in many of the more affluent areas around the city.

fields.heading: Car burglaries spike outside Chicago
fields.content:
Police in the Chicago suburb of Hinsdale are warning residents to lock up their vehicles and remember to arm any burglar alarms after a recent series of burglaries.

The Chicago Tribune reports that the town has seen nearly two dozen vehicle burglaries in just the past two weeks. Most of the crimes have occurred overnight, and police believe they may be connected.

"The common denominator in these recent cases is the vehicles are unlocked and there's no forced entry," deputy police chief Mark Wodka told the paper. "I think some residents take comfort in knowing crime is generally low in our area and feel it's safe to leave their vehicles unlocked. Criminals know this and take advantage of the opportunity."

Among the items taken from vehicles include music players, cash, golf clubs and purses. So far, no suspects have been apprehended.

This also isn't the first string of auto burglaries the area has seen. The Tribune reports that residents experienced a similar string of crimes back in March, in which at least seven unlocked vehicles were robbed.
fields.summary: Police in the Chicago suburb of Hinsdale are warning residents to lock up their vehicles and remember to arm any burglar alarms after a recent series of burglaries.

fields.heading: Forbes: Memphis is country's most dangerous city
fields.content:
A new report by Forbes finds that Memphis is the most dangerous city in the country, a situation which may have led many residents to purchase home alarm systems.

Memphis earned the dubious top spot in the ranking due to its recent increase in gang violence as well as an extremely high rate of traffic fatalities. However, analysts said that even though a city may have a low overall crime rate, families need to be more concerned with activity in the specific neighborhood.

"When people move into cities, they should be finding out the lay of local land. A homeowner would want to do due diligence and look at it neighborhood by neighborhood - not just by city," Bruce McIndoe, president of the Maryland-Based risk-assessment firm iJet Intelligent Risk Systems, told the source.

Also appearing on the list's top five was St. Louis, Missouri; Kansas City, Missouri; Detroit, Michigan and Miami, Florida.

Other recent studies have also pointed to Memphis as a site of much violent crime. A recent report by NeighborhoodScout.com listed two Memphis neighborhoods as some of the 25 most dangerous areas in the country.
fields.summary: A new report by Forbes finds that Memphis is the most dangerous city in the country, a situation which may have led many residents to purchase home alarm systems.

fields.heading: Downtown Long Beach to get additional security cameras
fields.content:
Officials with the Long Beach Redevelopment Agency have voted to continue contributing funding to help install a number of new security cameras to help prevent crime in the downtown area, Gazette Newspapers reports.

The group voted unanimously to approve the funding for 10 additional security cameras, which will be monitored through a partnership with the Long Beach Police Department.

"I think everyone agrees that they are good for downtown. Just the fact of having the cameras there and having the signs posted is a deterrent itself [to crime]," said Barbi Clark, the RDA's development project manager.

The new installation is actually part two of a three part security upgrade for the downtown area. Phase one - which was first approved in 2005, led to the installation of 17 cameras in various trouble spots. The third phase will be included in the organization's 2012 budget.

The installation of the cameras may be even more important given that the city's recent crime trends. The Press-Telegram reports that Long Beach, along with nearby Lakewood and Norwalk, all saw increases in violent crime last year, while the national rate declined.
fields.summary: Officials with the Long Beach Redevelopment Agency have voted to continue contributing funding to help install a number of new security cameras to help prevent crime in the downtown area, Gazette Newspapers reports.

fields.heading: New Jersey neighborhood site of series of burglaries
fields.content:
Police in Maplewood, New Jersey, say that at least 10 homes have been the site of burglaries or attempted burglaries in the last two weeks, reports WCBS-TV.

Many of the recent crimes have taken place during the day, when most residents are at work, so police have stepped up patrols in the area. Officials told the station that in many cases, the criminals often fled the scene without taking anything if they realized certain properties had home security systems installed.

"They were scared off, thank God, by our alarm, and so they didn't actually get anything," one resident, who didn't want to be named, told the station. "But it was still pretty scary, you know, because you don't want to feel violated that way."

Many local residents told the station that the incidents had them on edge, and many were considering installing burglar alarms.

Police hope some recent arrests may help reduce the number of incidents. Officials told local news sources that a pair of recently arrested suspects may be linked to some of the recent attempted burglaries and break-ins, while three other juveniles were also arrested earlier this month.
fields.summary: Police in Maplewood, New Jersey, say that at least 10 homes have been the site of burglaries or attempted burglaries in the last two weeks, reports WCBS-TV.

fields.heading: Police say many residents install, but fail to use burglar alarms
fields.content:
Police in Collier County, Florida, say that while home security systems can be an effective deterrent against many types of crime, many area residents fail to use them regularly after putting them in, the Naples Daily News reports.

Officials say that many residents fail to realize exactly how much their home security might be vulnerable, often leaving doors unlocked, or home security systems inactive.

"You want to make it as hard as you can for someone to get into your home," Connie Ledbetter, a member of the sheriff's Crime Prevention Unit, told the paper. "That's why it's good to have as many deterrents as possible to discourage criminals from selecting your home as a target."

Ledbetter added that aside from the security systems, one of the weakest points for many area residents are sliding glass doors - saying that roughly 70 percent of break-ins involve criminals entering through there.

Police in the area are also taking an active role in trying to help residents further protect against crime in their homes. Members of the CPU will do a free home security survey to help residents identify potential problems.
fields.summary: Police in Collier County, Florida, say that while home security systems can be an effective deterrent against many types of crime, many area residents fail to use them regularly after putting them in, the Naples Daily News reports.

fields.heading: Alarm systems can provide peace of mind while away
fields.content:
While the coming of Halloween means an influx of costumes and candy, it also brings with it a number of troublemakers set on causing damage or breaking into a home. But as Alarm.com writes, there are a number of ways homeowners can protect themselves.

The first, and probably most important, tip is that homeowners need to remember to arm their system. Many people, according to the site, purchase systems and then fail to arm them when they go out. Even if they're just taking a trip around the block for trick-or-treating, having the system in action is an important step.

While they're out, the site says that new technology, allowing residents to monitor their homes from their smartphones, can help put their mind at ease while they are out. Home security cameras can send a live feed right to the phone, so homeowners aren't worried about what's going on.

Burglary continues to be a problem in many neighborhoods across the country. According to the National Crime Prevention Council, more than 23 million people were victims of personal and property crimes last year.
fields.summary: While the coming of Halloween means an influx of costumes and candy, it also brings with it a number of troublemakers set on causing damage or breaking into a home. But as Alarm.com writes, there are a number of ways homeowners can protect themselves.

fields.heading: Home security systems embracing high-tech development
fields.content:
Much like nearly every category of electronic devices, the Dallas Morning News reports that home security systems are undergoing a transformation as they adapt to new technologies and cultural changes.

The technology has allowed homeowners to take a more active role in monitoring their own homes. Instead of just watching for burglars, the paper reports residents can now watch live video feeds from security cameras mounted inside the home from their laptops and smartphones to check on their kids doing homework or the plumber making repairs.

"Security is transitioning from being a stand-alone product and service, if you will, to being part of a much broader universe of offerings – offerings which have become as much lifestyle as life safety," Jonathan Klinger, vice president of marketing for Honeywell, told the paper.

The industry has also adapted cellular phone technologies into the systems themselves, the paper reports. Traditional systems relied on traditional phone lines, which could be compromised by a burglar cutting a phone line. But newer systems are cellular, circumventing that issue.

In addition, a growing number of households don't pay for a traditional landline phone. According to the trade group CTIA, 24.5 percent of U.S. households were wireless only in June of this year.
fields.summary: Much like nearly every category of electronic devices, the Dallas Morning News reports that home security systems are undergoing a transformation as they adapt to new technologies and cultural changes.

fields.heading: Davis County seeing increase in crime as area undergoes shift
fields.content:
Once hailed as an area with very low crime, officials in Davis County, Utah, say that they're witnessing a sharp rise in crime as the region has grown quickly in recent years, the Davis County Clipper reports.

Officials say that the rapid growth of the area's population is one of the biggest reasons for the rise in crime. The paper says that before that development took hold, there was a buffer of empty space between the area and Salt Lake City - where crime was higher. But now that buffer zone is gone.

"It definitely varies from city to city, but crime is here and it is growing," Layton Police chief Terry Keefe told the paper. "People need to understand that times have changed. The county has changed."

Officials added that the low rate of crime in the past has given many residents a "false sense of security," and that many of them leave homes unlocked a home alarm systems inactive when they go away on vacation - making things easy for burglars.

The county has also been dealing with a growing drug problem. Last week, the Clipper reported that the local board of health took the step of outlawing "spice," a designer drug with effects similar to marijuana. Officials called it a "challenging problem in the community."
fields.summary: Once hailed as an area with very low crime, officials in Davis County, Utah, say that they're witnessing a sharp rise in crime as the region has grown quickly in recent years, the Davis County Clipper reports.

fields.heading: Home security cameras lead to an arrest following long neighborhood dispute
fields.content:
An ongoing dispute between neighbors over the past few months in East Nashville, Tennessee, has now been brought to a close after local residents turned over footage from their security cameras to local police, leading to the arrest of a local minister.

Officers arrested 67-year-old Horace Wilkinson, the pastor of a local Methodist church on 10 counts of aggravated assault. Police said that issues between Wilkinson and his neighbors had been ongoing since at least June. Neighbors had said that Wilkinson had made indecent gestures toward them while carrying a firearm, and repeatedly patted a gun in his waistband while looking at them - making them fearful.

After the incidents began, residents installed a number of security cameras around their home, and recorded some of his behavior. After viewing the video, police handed the recording over to a grand jury, which indicted the minister.

The area has also been stricken by a rash of burglaries in recent months. According to WTVF-TV, the crime issue has been significant enough that many East Nashville residents have formed a neighborhood watch group.
fields.summary: An ongoing dispute between neighbors over the past few months in East Nashville, Tennessee, has now been brought to a close after local residents turned over footage from their security cameras to local police, leading to the arrest of a local minister.

fields.heading: Preventative security measures important on Halloween
fields.content:
Halloween has a reputation for many things - costumes, candy and a rise in crime and vandalism. According to the firm Security Choice, criminals are sometimes able to blend in to the neighborhood because of all the holiday activity taking place.

One of the best ways to prevent anything from happening, according to the firm, it to make sure that those walking by know that home alarm systems have been installed, by clearly displaying the sign outside. Having the system armed is also important, because it can be easy for criminals to tell which residents aren't home.

The company also recommends that local parents talk about their schedules and plan out a possible watch group for the evening, so they can make sure that everyone is safe while out trick-or-treating.

In addition, because of the usual rise in crime, many police departments send out extra patrols over the weekend to help clamp down on any issues. Officers in Twin Falls, Minnesota told the Times News that last year, the department saw double its usual number of vandalism reports on Halloween weekend.
fields.summary: Halloween has a reputation for many things - costumes, candy and a rise in crime and vandalism. According to the firm Security Choice, criminals are sometimes able to blend in to the neighborhood because of all the holiday activity taking place.

fields.heading: Security cameras help police catch candy burglars
fields.content:
Security cameras installed in one Modesto, California, business - along with a literal trail of evidence - helped police track down two men suspected of breaking in and stealing a candy machine.

The two suspects were seen on surveillance cameras breaking the business' front window, grabbing a vending machine full of candy and throwing it in the bed of their truck. Police used the footage to identify the vehicle - an older model Chevy pickup - which was stopped by police a few hours later.

When police pulled the vehicle over, they noticed candy in the bed of the truck, and quickly took the suspects into custody. They then went to the home of one of the suspects, where they found a trail of candy leading up to the front door. Inside, they found the machine had been broken open to access the money inside.

The two men were actually already on probation when they were arrested, and now face multiple charges. Police are also investigating whether they may be linked to any additional burglaries in the area.
fields.summary: Security cameras installed in one Modesto, California, business - along with a literal trail of evidence - helped police track down two men suspected of breaking in and stealing a candy machine.

fields.heading: Ohio security companies noticing uptick in use
fields.content:
Home security companies in the Ohio Valley say they're seeing a significant increase in the number of residents looking to install home alarm systems, WTOV-TV reports.

According to the station, firms are noticing about a 30 percent jump in interest, after the area has seen an increased number of home and care break-ins in recent weeks.

"The robberies late at night don't seem to be the MO anymore. They're getting more bold," local security expert David Hindman told the station. "Think about it through the eyes of that person that's going to break into your home. They're walking down the street. The norm today if you have a security system, you have that sign in your yard. They don't see that sign so they go up and knock on the door."

Hindman added that many of those residents are also choosing to install security cameras to supplement the systems.

The Cleveland Plain Dealer reports that many residents near the city have also experienced a rise in crime, as officials told the paper that burglaries have risen 10 to 12 percent in the last few years. A poll conducted by the paper also found that 61 percent of Cleveland residents said that a neighbors' home had been vandalized or broken into during the last five years.
fields.summary: Home security companies in the Ohio Valley say they're seeing a significant increase in the number of residents looking to install home alarm systems, WTOV-TV reports.

fields.heading: Sox' Ortiz issues PSA against rising violence in Boston
fields.content:
Boston Red Sox slugger David Ortiz has issued a public service announcement, asking residents to stop the rise of violent crime that has taken place in the city over the past several weeks.

In the video, the baseball star is seen at multiple locations around the city which have been the site of recent killings. Officials told NECN that Ortiz volunteered to do the PSA, which was recorded in both English and Spanish.

"Boston is my city, too, and together we can stop the violence," Ortiz says in the 45-second message.

Officials say that they hope Ortiz's message will sink in, and encourage residents to take more steps to cut down on violent crime. Police also told the station that they have worked to reassign patrols to areas where problems have been occurring.

The city of Boston has seen a sharp increase in violent crime and shootings in recent days, which may have motivated many residents to install home security systems. Over just this past weekend, seven people were shot in a number of different incidents around the city.
fields.summary: Boston Red Sox slugger David Ortiz has issued a public service announcement, asking residents to stop the rise of violent crime that has taken place in the city over the past several weeks.

fields.heading: Security cameras catch attempted burglar in the act
fields.content:
Security cameras installed outside a Long Island home helped one resident see who had tried to break into his home while he was away during the morning, and has given police a suspect for which to look.

The Long Island Herald reports that Bellmore resident David Mahler, who works in home technology as a profession, saw video of the suspect unsuccessfully trying to force his way through the home's front and rear doors.

Mahler told the paper that when he returned home later that day, he noticed that the front gate had been left open, and quickly found the suspect on the video. He says that the cameras help him monitor things even when he's not home.

"Whenever we're away, I keep an eye on the house," he told the Herald. "Clearly they've paid off." He added that in recent weeks he's also begun installing similar systems for some of his neighbors as well.

Many areas of Long Island have been dealing with significant increases in crime. WCBS-TV reports that the Guardian Angels have now begun patrolling Huntington Station after more than a dozen violent crimes and murders have taken place over the last two months.
fields.summary: Security cameras installed outside a Long Island home helped one resident see who had tried to break into his home while he was away during the morning, and has given police a suspect for which to look.

fields.heading: Home alarm system owners in St. Louis advised to check permit status
fields.content:
Police are asking St. Louis residents who have home security systems installed to check the status of their alarm permit, after an issue with one caused officials to take 30 minutes to respond to a local burglary.

KMOV-TV reports that the home security system inside a local home went off when burglars broke in through the side window, but police didn't immediately respond because the permit number for the alarm was invalid. The burglars eventually made off with a large flat-screen television, some personal items, and a gun safe that was hidden in a closet. By the time police finally arrived, they were long gone.

A city regulation, passed in 2005, requires owners to register their alarms if they want police to respond. Otherwise, according to the station, they need to call police and "prove" it's not a false alarm. The homeowners thought that the alarm company had taken care of that when the system was installed, but it hadn't.

Other areas have also initiated alarm registration policies to cut down on false alarms, reports KBTX-TV. Officials in Bryan and College Station, Texas have both created new policies, some of which fine residents for not registering their home alarm systems.
fields.summary: Police are asking St. Louis residents who have home security systems installed to check the status of their alarm permit, after an issue with one caused officials to take 30 minutes to respond to a local burglary.

fields.heading: Hollywood residents startled after finding burglars in closet
fields.content:
A Hollywood, Florida, couple was left shaken after they came home to find a pair of teenage burglars hiding in their closet, saying they had a gun, the Sun Sentinel reports.

After being arrested, the paper says one of the suspects told police that he and a friend, who has not been caught, noticed that the couple had just walked out of the apartment and decided to break in, since there were no home alarm systems installed. But they were surprised when the couple returned 15 minutes later for a quick stop before heading out to the beach.

"I had just put on my bikini and then opened my closet door to get a sun dress and there was a man there standing in the closet. I screamed and yelled," 28-year-old resident Christina Aiken told the paper. "They kept saying they were in the wrong apartment. Well, obviously they were in the wrong apartment."

Once discovered hiding in the closet, the pair claimed to have a gun, and the couple let them go. The paper reports one of the suspects, who lives in the same building, was later identified in a lineup.

The area has seen a rise in burglaries in recent months, even as other crimes in Broward County have decreased. According to state crime data, there were nearly 400 more burglaries in the first half of this year than during the same time period last year.
fields.summary: A Hollywood, Florida, couple was left shaken after they came home to find a pair of teenage burglars hiding in their closet, saying they had a gun, the Sun Sentinel reports.

fields.heading: Buffalo residents turn out for meeting on local crime
fields.content:
A large number of residents in Buffalo's University Heights district turned out to a recent community meeting to address a sentiment of increased crime, a trend that may have some local residents looking at home security systems.

More than 100 people attended a recent monthly meeting of the local block club, a sharp increase from the 20 or so that usually attend, WKBW-TV reports. Officials told residents that statistics say that crime in the area has decreased, but residents say that it's the nature of the crimes that has put them on edge.

"So the escalation of the crime ... maybe the numbers are down but the severity of them is increased and that's what has a lot of the residents like myself worried," local resident Anthony Ingram told the station.

Other residents also complained that police response time was often poor, and they sometimes had to make multiple calls in order to get a prompt response from police, the station reported. Officials said that they would work to address the issue, and might authorize overtime for police officers if needed.

A rash of break-ins in North Buffalo has also startled many in the area, according to WIVB-TV. The station says that residents have organized block clubs to better share information with police.
fields.summary: A large number of residents in Buffalo's University Heights district turned out to a recent community meeting to address a sentiment of increased crime, a trend that may have some local residents looking at home security systems.

fields.heading: South Bend area police offering home security checks
fields.content:
Faced with the threat of burglary and home invasion, many residents are looking to upgrade their home security systems. Police in Berrien Springs Orinoko Township have now created a program to help residents understand what steps they might want to consider.

The South Bend Tribune reports that local police offer a free home security survey to residents, in which they take a look at landscaping, lighting windows and doors and give residents an opinion of how it might be perceived by criminals.

"If the resident would like to take their existing level of security, kick it up a notch if you will, we can give them some common sense suggestions," Smiedendorf told the paper. "We tell them that it's not a guarantee that their home is going to be crime free, but it's going to put them at a less likely risk that a criminal event would happen there."

Officials told the paper that the survey is similar to those offered by many police departments across the country, and takes about 30 minutes to complete.

Police in Collier County, Florida, offer a similar program, the Naples Daily News reports, which can help residents understand any weaknesses in their security.
fields.summary: Faced with the threat of burglary and home invasion, many residents are looking to upgrade their home security systems. Police in Berrien Springs Orinoko Township have now created a program to help residents understand what steps they might want to consider.

fields.heading: Long-term crime report shows rising burglaries and robberies
fields.content:
While violent crime rates across the country have shown modest improvement in recent years, an analysis of crime data in Oklahoma City shows that the area has seen steadily rising rates of assaults, burglaries and robberies over the past decade, the Oklahoman reports.

The report says that burglaries have risen significantly in recent years, with the number of reports jumping from just over 7,200 in 2000 to almost 10,600 in 2009 - an increase of more than 45 percent. Local residents spoke of the need for home alarm systems and watchful neighbors.

"I think you really do need to get to know your neighbors and befriend them," Tommy Hay, a board member of the Riverpark Neighborhood Association in Oklahoma City, told the paper. "Communicate and talk to each other. They can tell you, 'I saw a car in your driveway while you were gone that I wasn't familiar with.'"

While that increase in burglaries was also accompanied by a rise in population, the per-capita crime rate still rose, as the population increased just 11 percent.

The state has traditionally had a higher crime rate than the rest of the country. Citing 2008 statistics, the National Institute of Corrections says that the state's crime rate was 8 percent above the national average.
fields.summary: While violent crime rates across the country have shown modest improvement in recent years, an analysis of crime data in Oklahoma City shows that the area has seen steadily rising rates of assaults, burglaries and robberies over the past decade, the Oklahoman reports.

fields.heading: Surveillance cameras catch burglary on tape
fields.content:
