Police in Indiana are now searching for a pair of suspects in a recent home burglary that was caught on tape by security cameras the homeowner installed in his home, WNDU-TV reports.

The station says that the video shows the pair knocking on the door, and when no one answers, kicking it down. They stole a video game system, a television and even a number of frozen dinners from the freezer. The victim says it shows that the cameras were a worthy investment.

"I have my own business and I use a lot of security cameras there and I thought that it's something that helps in business, it might help at home. I decided it's much more affordable than it used to be, they're pretty automated," the victim, who didn't want to be named, told the station. "It's one of those things that I only look at if I need it, so it might go six months before I even check on it, but when there's a situation it's there for me."

Local police are also working to give residents advice on stopping burglaries. Indiana State Police officials told WISE-TV that residents need to understand that many burglars may knock on the door to see if anyone is home, and then offer to do an odd job or ask directions if someone happens to be home.
fields.summary: Police in Indiana are now searching for a pair of suspects in a recent home burglary that was caught on tape by security cameras the homeowner installed in his home, WNDU-TV reports.

fields.heading: Authorities credit security cameras with a number of convictions
fields.content:
Officials in Hilton Head, South Carolina, are crediting the installation of a number of security cameras at a local park with at least seven arrests since being installed three years ago.

According to the Island Packet, the community installed 200 cameras in Chaplin Park in 2007 after a number of robberies in the area. Since then, police have noticed reduced criminal activity in the area, and say the cameras help them obtain evidence even when people may not be willing to offer information about a crime.

"The problem is people don't want to give us information because they think it will get back to them. People are scared," Sheriff's Capt. Toby McSwain told the paper. "These cameras have been a huge asset to us."

The town is now also planning to add more cameras. The paper reports that town officials have asked police to list other sites - including those on private property - where cameras could be placed to help cut down on crime.

Despite the additions, other areas of town have not seen the same crime trends. The sheriff's office says that burglaries and thefts during the third quarter were up by more than 9 percent compared to the same time last year.
fields.summary: Officials in Hilton Head, South Carolina, are crediting the installation of a number of security cameras at a local park with at least seven arrests since being installed three years ago.

fields.heading: North Las Vegas experiences rash of murders
fields.content:
Residents in North Las Vegas may be thinking about installing home security systems following a series of murders that has many residents staying close to home.

According to KLAS-TV, the city has experienced four murders in the span of only a few days, in addition to a stabbing and a shooting at a wake over the weekend. The feeling has many people on edge.

"It's a pretty tragic thing to experience - especially so close," resident Tony Lowe told the station. "We don't like to seem unfriendly to people, but it does make you a whole lot more cautious about where you go and when you go."

Police told the station that they have arrested a suspect in one of the killings, however, those behind the other killings are still at large. So far this year, there have been 14 murders in North Las Vegas - one more than was seen last year.

Last year was actually a down year in terms of crime in the region. FBI statistics showed that murders in the Las Vegas area in 2009 had dropped 7.5 percent compared to 2008.
fields.summary: Residents in North Las Vegas may be thinking about installing home security systems following a series of murders that has many residents staying close to home.

fields.heading: Study: Trees help protect against burglary
fields.content:
Researchers now say that neighborhoods with large trees may amplify the effect of home security systems and help reduce crime.

A study by the U.S. Forest Service looked at the crime data for nearly 3,000 homes in Portland, Oregon, and found that there were more than 400 crime incidents in that area. By looking at ground surveys and aerial photos, researchers found that areas with larger trees had measurably lower crime rates than those with smaller trees.

"We believe that large street trees can reduce crime by signaling to a potential criminal that a neighborhood is better cared for and, therefore, a criminal is more likely to be caught," said Geoffrey Donovan, USFS research forester who led the study. "Large yard trees also were associated with lower crime rates, most likely because they are less view-obstructing than smaller trees."

Study researchers advised residents with smaller trees surrounding their property to keep them well-trimmed, so they didn't give as much cover to criminals.

The idea of having too many smaller trees has been seen in a rash of property crimes near Daytona Beach, Florida. The News-Journal reports that police have responded to more than 20 burglaries in the Daytona Park Estates subdivision, and told the paper that the wooded area makes it difficult to search for suspects.
fields.summary: Researchers now say that neighborhoods with large trees may amplify the effect of home security systems and help reduce crime.

fields.heading: Burglar alarm protects kids and scares off potential burglar
fields.content:
A mother in New Jersey is thankful that her home alarm systems were active earlier this week, as the sound of the burglar alarms going off was able to scare off a potential burglar while her children were home alone.

According to MyCentralJersey.com, the mother called police saying that her 9-year-old son had seen someone try and enter the home through a sliding glass door Tuesday afternoon, but ran off when the alarms sounded. The 9-year-old, who was home with an older sibling, then reset the burglar alarms before their mother returned home a few minutes later.

The mother quickly spoke to police to report the incident. While nothing was taken from the home, officers looked throughout the neighborhood for the suspect, but were unable to find them.

Sliding glass doors often present one of the easier opportunities for potential burglars. Recently, police officials told the Naples Daily News that roughly 70 percent of break-ins are made through those types of entrances, and that they are often one of the weakest points of residents' home security systems.
fields.summary: A mother in New Jersey is thankful that her home alarm systems were active earlier this week, as the sound of the burglar alarms going off was able to scare off a potential burglar while her children were home alone.

fields.heading: Long winter nights create opportunities for burglars
fields.content:
As many residents prepare to set their clocks back this weekend, the change will mean that darkness will come sooner as the winter nights grow longer. But insurers told the Telegraph that darkness can also create cover for burglars.

The insurer NFU told the paper that it saw a 52 percent increase in home insurance claims as vandals took advantage of the long November nights. In addition, Halifax Home Insurance said that it saw a 63 percent rise in burglaries during the winter, although they say that having visible home security systems can help homeowners discourage those incidents.

"Burglars will tend to go for the path of least resistance and look for homes that lack even the basic security measures, so a few simple steps can go a long way to avoid a break-in," Martin Foulds, senior claims manager for Halifax Home Insurance, told the paper.

The approaching winter season also brings the threat of snow, which can create unshoveled walks that are giveaway to criminals that no one is home. New York-based Video Surveillance says that those who are traveling should arrange to have a neighbor shovel out their home in the event of snow.
fields.summary: As many residents prepare to set their clocks back this weekend, the change will mean that darkness will come sooner as the winter nights grow longer. But insurers told the Telegraph that darkness can also create cover for burglars.

fields.heading: Chicago suburb seeing a rash of burglaries
fields.content:
Police in Wheaton are adivising residents to watch out for suspicious activity, after the area experienced a sudden spike in burglaries last week.

According to the Wheaton Sun, there were 17 total burglaries in the last week of October, including four office burglaries and one residential burglary and a number of incidents involving vehicles.

Most of the incidents occurred during darkness, and most of the vehicles involved had been left unlocked, according to the paper. However, the office burglaries were done by force, with many companies reporting stolen cash and computers.

The paper says that local police have issued an alert for residents, reminding them to keep their valuables out of view, keep their vehicles and doors locked and remember to activate any home alarm systems.

Other areas of Chicago continue to be among the most dangerous in the country. A recent study of crime statistics by NeighborhoodScout.com found that the area surrounding the city's West Lake Street had the highest rate of violent crime of any neighborhood in the country.
fields.summary: Police in Wheaton are adivising residents to watch out for suspicious activity, after the area experienced a sudden spike in burglaries last week.

fields.heading: Burglars rob home of Iowa's Secretary of State
fields.content:
Outgoing Iowa Secretary of State Michael Mauro says that he now plans to install a home security system in his home after burglars ransacked the house earlier this week, the Des Moines Register reports.

The paper says that the criminals likely used a crowbar to break into the home, stealing a computer, linens, jewelry, and a safety deposit box with credit cards, birth certificates and passports. The burglars also damaged a flat-screen television when they tried to rip it down off of the wall, and took some wrapped Christmas presents in the closet.

"It was just like you see on TV," Mauro told the paper. "The whole place was ransacked. It wasn't a hate crime or anything. They didn't paint on the walls, so I guess I can be thankful for that."

Mauro added that it's the first incident he can recall in the three decades he's lived at the house.

The burglary wraps up a rough week for Mauro. On Tuesday, the 30-year veteran of public office lost his re-election bid, as he was defeated by Republican Matt Schultz by a margin of 50 percent to 47 percent, in what WHO-TV described as one of the biggest surprises of the election.
fields.summary: Outgoing Iowa Secretary of State Michael Mauro says that he now plans to install a home security system in his home after burglars ransacked the house earlier this week, the Des Moines Register reports.

fields.heading: Worcester residents voice concerns over crime
fields.content:
Members of the more than 50 local neighborhood watch groups showed up at police headquarters in Worcester, Massachusetts, to speak with officials about their concerns regarding the state of crime in the city, the Worcester Telegram reports.

At the meeting, officials were optimistic about crime, even though some statistics, such as the number of shootings in the city, have increased this year. So far this year, those incidents are up 15 percent - a fact which may have led many residents to install home security systems.

Officials added that they've gotten positive responses from the department's text-a-tip program, which has led to more than 250 leads so far this year, and urged residents to continue being active in reporting incidents to police. One captain said that if residents don't think a concern is being addressed, they should call back and ask to speak to a supervisor.

Many of those recent shootings have involved teens. Last month, the Telegram reported that the number of shootings involving teens so far this year was already higher than in any year since 1995.
fields.summary: Members of the more than 50 local neighborhood watch groups showed up at police headquarters in Worcester, Massachusetts, to speak with officials about their concerns regarding the state of crime in the city, the Worcester Telegram reports.

fields.heading: Sharp rise in auto thefts in Chicago
fields.content:
While many crime rates in Chicago fell in October, the city is currently dealing with a sharp rise in auto thefts - a trend which many lead some residents to install GPS tracking systems on their vehicles.

According to data from the Chicago Police Department, motor vehicle thefts in the city through October have jumped by 22.7 percent compared to last year. In addition to the high rate of auto thefts, the city also maintained its high rate of burglaries, which have fallen roughly 2 percent compared with last year. The city's murder rate continued to be dominated by gangs.

"Nearly 55 percent of murders this year through the end of October were gang-involved and we need to continue to strategically target the gang lifestyle - particularly guns and drugs - in order to decrease murders to our ultimate goal - zero," said police superintendent Jody Weis.

Gang enrollment has been increasing at a national level in recent months. A recent report by the National Gang Threat Assessment found that gang membership has grown 25 percent since 2005.
fields.summary: While many crime rates in Chicago fell in October, the city is currently dealing with a sharp rise in auto thefts - a trend which many lead some residents to install GPS tracking systems on their vehicles.

fields.heading: Wilmington crime rate outpaces many nearby communities
fields.content:
A new report says that crime in the city of Wilmington, North Carolina, has escalated well beyond the levels of many of its neighboring cities and towns.

An analysis of five years of crime data by StarNews has found that while the city's crime rate was relatively steady over much of that time period, it jumped across many categories in 2009, as the economy went downhill. The paper says that both violent and property crimes increased sharply, rising by 5 and 14 percent, respectively.

That increase added to the city's generally high rate of criminal activity. The paper says that one in every 16 residents reported a property crime last year, a statistic that may motivate many of those residents to install home security systems. Analysts say the city's high crime rate is often puzzling.

"Wilmington has had historically high rates," Randy LaGrange, a professor of sociology and criminology at the University of North Carolina Wilmington, told the paper. "There have been many folks who have tried to figure this out."

One of the factors in the city's crime rate may be that residents are so tightly packed. According to Census Bureau statistics, the city has a population density 11 times higher than the state average.
fields.summary: A new report says that crime in the city of Wilmington, North Carolina, has escalated well beyond the levels of many of its neighboring cities and towns.

fields.heading: Atlanta residents joining together to stop crime
fields.content:
Residents in Atlanta's Vine City neighborhood are now coming together in an attempt to stop the neighborhood's high crime rate after a string of recent violent incidents.

According to WAGA-TV, the area has seen five separate murders over the past two months - a spike that may be driving many residents to install burglar alarms in their homes.

Investigators told the station that in one of the most recent incidents, a teen was shot and killed on Halloween after someone in the street was hit by an egg. In another incident last week, a shooting occurred at a local nightclub, leaving three people hurt and one woman dead.

The station reports that neighbors are now working to band together to help fight the recent crime wave, and help unite the community itself.

The area has been targeted by local officials. Last month, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported that the Atlanta Development Authority gave grants worth $3.3 million to Vine City and English Avenue neighborhoods to help fund businesses, create jobs and help the neighborhood stamp out crime.
fields.summary: Residents in Atlanta's Vine City neighborhood are now coming together in an attempt to stop the neighborhood's high crime rate after a string of recent violent incidents.

fields.heading: Rise in Delaware burglaries making residents uncomfortable
fields.content:
Crime figures in the state of Delaware show that while many types of crimes are dropping, the number of burglaries has continued to rise - a fact that's left many residents uneasy, the News Journal reports.

The paper says that state crime statistics show that the number of burglaries is on pace to increase by 2 percent this year after jumping 6 percent last year. Many residents say that the frequency of the incidents has led some to install home alarm systems and others to become more vigilant after becoming victims.

"It makes you feel like you've really been violated," local resident Layton Hope told the paper. "Now I'm more cautious. I make sure all the doors and windows are locked before we go to bed and make sure the alarm is on before we go out."

The paper says that roughly two-thirds of the recent wave of burglaries have involved residential properties, nearly half of which did not involve forced entry. Police have asked residents to take extra precautions.

The increase in burglaries follows a drop in crime overall in 2009. FBI statistics show that crime dropped off 6.5 percent in the state last year.
fields.summary: Crime figures in the state of Delaware show that while many types of crimes are dropping, the number of burglaries has continued to rise - a fact that's left many residents uneasy, the News Journal reports.

fields.heading: Old Saybrook residents blame economy, police relocation for crime surge
fields.content:
Many people in Old Saybrook, Connecticut say that both the economy and the movement of the main police station are the main reasons behind a significant rise in crime over the last few months which may have led some of them to install home security systems.

The New Haven Register reports that residents say that crimes in the downtown area have sharply increased since the department's police station was evacuated because flood damage, mold and mildew made it impossible for officers to work there.

"Some people are saying there is more crime happening downtown because we don't have a presence on Main Street. I think that's probably a decent theory. I don't think there is more crime in the whole town because we moved, but I bet there is more crime in certain parts of town," police chief Michael Spera told the paper.

Police say they're also seeing a rise in more violent crime in recent weeks, as a number of recent businesses have reported criminals using guns or bomb threats during robberies.

The New Haven area has been dealing with a rise in overall crime in recent months. Earlier this year, the city experienced a series of five murders in an eight-day period, a trend which alarmed some students at nearby Yale University.
fields.summary: Many people in Old Saybrook, Connecticut say that both the economy and the movement of the main police station are the main reasons behind a significant rise in crime over the last few months which may have led some of them to install home security systems.

fields.heading: Houston residents ask for increased patrols amid burglary spike
fields.content:
Homeowners in Houston's Sunnyside neighborhood are asking for increased police patrols after a sharp increase in the number of residential burglaries in recent months has created a feeling of uneasiness, KTRK-TV reports.

The station says that the area has seen 339 burglaries so far this year, up 11 percent from the 375 at this time last year. In addition, there have been 30 incidents since September 1, and the situation may have caused some to install burglar alarms.

"Something has to be done about this, ASAP," local resident and business owner Travis McGee told the station. "It's about time that we become a priority of our city government."

Local residents told the station that an increase in the number of vacant homes in the area also seems to be playing a significant role in the uptick in crime. Police said they have beefed up their patrols of the area.

Overall, crime has dropped so far this year in Houston as a whole. The HPD released statistics last week showing that violent crimes during the first nine months of the year had dropped 11 percent compared to last year.
fields.summary: Homeowners in Houston's Sunnyside neighborhood are asking for increased police patrols after a sharp increase in the number of residential burglaries in recent months has created a feeling of uneasiness, KTRK-TV reports.

fields.heading: Crime in New York showing increases in 2010
fields.content:
While the state has seen its crime rate drop almost constantly over the past several years, new data shows that crime in New York appears to be on the rise this year.

According to budget testimony from Sean Byrne, acting commissioner of the Division of Criminal Justice Services, statewide crime data from the first six months of the year shows a total 1 percent increase in major crimes, the Associated Press reports.

According to the report, murders have increased by 11.5 percent, aggravated assaults have risen more than 4 percent and burglaries and rapes have jumped 3.5 and 3.4 percent, respectively - a trend which may lead some residents to install home security systems. Drops in larcenies and vehicle thefts helped balance out the overall numbers and prevented a larger increase.

Byrne said that at this point, it wasn't clear whether the increase in crime was a growing trend or just a blip. The source says that state crime rates have steadily declined over most of the past 20 years, with index crimes in New York city falling from more than 711,000 in 1990 to 188,000 in 2009.

A number of recent reports have also focused on the rates of lower-level crimes in New York City - data that hasn't been released from the NYPD since 2002. The New York Times reports that some criminologists have said that an emphasis on major crime may have led some officers to reclassify some offenses into more minor categories.
fields.summary: While the state has seen its crime rate drop almost constantly over the past several years, new data shows that crime in New York appears to be on the rise this year.

fields.heading: Cincinnati residents express worry about potential police cuts
fields.content:
Fears of drastic cuts to the Cincinnati Police Department may bring more residents to install home security systems, as the city's crime-fighting resources may be stretched even thinner, WXIX-TV reports.

According to the station, the city is facing a nearly $60-million budget deficit going into next year, a gap which could mean a reduction in the size of the police force. Recently, the city's police chief revealed plans that would lay off between 140 and 300 officers. Residents say that cutting officers, however, isn't the way to go.

"Some kind of gun violence is happening in this city daily," resident Tonia Mason, whose son was killed in 2008, told the station. "How is it we're even proposing police cuts?"

Police union officials also criticized some of the city's decisions, according to the station, such as having an officer guard a streetcar display downtown 24 hours per day.

The city is home to some of the country's most dangerous neighborhoods. According to a recent survey by NeighborhoodScout.com, Cincinnati's Moore Street area was the 24th most dangerous neighborhood nationwide and the third-worst in all of Ohio.
fields.summary: Fears of drastic cuts to the Cincinnati Police Department may bring more residents to install home security systems, as the city...

fields.heading: Police in Boston tie rise in killings to drug crime
fields.content:
Boston Police says that an increase in drug crime is likely to blame for much of the city's recent wave of murders, according to the Boston Globe.

So far this year, the number of murders in the city has risen more than 46 percent compared with last year, including more than 21 homicides since the beginning of September - a situation that may have led to the increased use of burglar alarms. Police told the Globe that it appears many of the incidents are connected to the surging drug trade.

"My thought is that we could be seeing the impact of a long-term economic downturn and a lack of jobs available for people who are starting to get back in the drug business," police commissioner Edward F. Davis told the paper. "When there are more people involved in drug robberies, it upsets the whole environment."

The increase in killings goes against the overall statewide trend so far this year. The paper reports that homicides are slightly down across the Bay State.

However, that drop also follows an increase in violent crime in 2009. According to the FBI, violent crime in Massachusetts increased by 0.8 percent last year.
fields.summary: Boston Police says that an increase in drug crime is likely to blame for much of the city's recent wave of murders, accordin...

fields.heading: U of Illinois tightens security after attacks
fields.content:
Officials at the University of Illinois are increasing their on-campus security after a number of recent attacks have left many students uneasy about the area.

Over the past few weeks, officials say there have been a string of assaults in the area, in which assailants have attacked male students who were walking along late at night. In addition, a female student was recently assaulted in a dormitory shower earlier this week.

"We are experiencing what we think is a really unusual increase in aggravated batteries, in particular in the campus district," campus police chief Barbara O'Connor told the Chicago Tribune. "And that's concerning."

In response, police have installed extra security cameras, increased patrols, and approved unlimited overtime for its security officers. The school has also added a number of self-defense classes and approved the hiring of additional officers.

Officials are also holding a town-hall style meeting Saturday to address any concerns from parents and students. The school is also streaming the meeting live over the web, and will post it online for viewing later.
fields.summary: Officials at the University of Illinois are increasing their on-campus security after a number of recent attacks have left many ...

fields.heading: Columbia Sportswear's Gert Boyle uses home alarm system to stop home invasion
fields.content:
Gert Boyle, author and chairwoman of Columbia Sportswear, used a silent panic button in her home security system when she was held at gunpoint this week.

A man approached her on the street with a gift basket and asked her to sign a copy of her book. When she refused, he took out a gun, and told her to deactivate her burglar alarms.

But instead, she pressed the panic button, which called police to the home. When they arrived, they saw the suspect fleeing from the scene and Boyle with her hands tied. After a brief manhunt, the suspect was arrested. He now faces multiple charges, including burglary, robbery and kidnapping.

Boyle, who suffered just minor injuries, was remarkably settled following the incident. KGW-TV reports that she even made it a point to "dress down" the local police chief when he arrived wearing a North Face jacket to ask how she was doing. Sergeant Neil Hennely told the station that Boyle "said she was doing fine until that jacket walked through the door."
fields.summary: Gert Boyle, author and chairwoman of Columbia Sportswear, used a silent panic button in her home security system when she was ...

fields.heading: Lights and locks a low-cost deterrent
fields.content:
With burglaries and property crimes rising in many cities across the country, home security experts tell Cleveland's WKYC-TV that beefing up residents' home security systems can be very simple.

According to the station, replacing locks or adding a deadbolt to doors can make it tougher for burglars to enter, and generally doesn't cost much. Even adding stronger screws to existing locks can make a difference.

"It's a bad situation. People feel like they've been violated and they never feel comfortable in their home after they've been broken into," Dennis Bregitzer, co-captain of the recently formed local block watch organization, told the station.

Security experts also told the station that simply shutting the blinds can make it so burglars don't see things that might be worth stealing, and adding lights in dark areas can prevent them from hanging around for a closer look.

While crime rates have remained fairly level in Cleveland over the past several years, many people don't feel safe in their own areas. A poll conducted by the Cleveland Plain-Dealer earlier this year found that nearly one-third of area residents didn't feel safe walking in their neighborhoods at night.
fields.summary: With burglaries and property crimes rising in many cities across the country, home security experts tell Cleveland's ...

fields.heading: Security doors provide security and style
fields.content:
Homeowners are always trying to provide their homes with as much security as possible, and Vanguard reports security doors are another sufficient way to keep intruders out of the home.

In addition to preventing unauthorized entry from intruders, the doors are aesthetically pleasing and can also withstand the toughest weather abuse. Vanguard Homes said that some of the commonly used security doors are hardwood doors, steel doors and timber doors, but it was noted that the timber doors are becoming outdated.

The doors can even be made more secure by installing some bullet-proof devices that can make them impenetrable. Messrs Damache Nigeria Limited, a major provider in the sales and distribution of security doors, declared, “our bullet-proof security doors come with exquisitely detailed outer wrought iron copper finish,” adding that the bullet-proof doors offer heavy blow resistance and come equipped with double safety-lock systems.

Vanguard Homes noted that apart from local manufacturers of security doors, many of them are imported from China.

Security doors offer much better protection than glass sliding doors, which are sometimes a weak point in home security systems. Local police officers in Florida told the Naples Daily News that they are at the point-of-entry for nearly 70 percent of break-ins.
fields.summary: Homeowners are always trying to provide their homes with as much security as possible, and Vanguard reports security doors are ...

fields.heading: NYC on track to see double-digit increase in murder rate
fields.content:
The purchase of home security systems may be on the rise this year in New York City, as the Associated Press reports the city is in danger of ending up with a double-digit increase in its murder rate.

The AP obtained the latest numbers last Friday, and the statistics show homicides totaled 464 through November 11, which is up 16 percent from the 400 reported at the same time last year and seven short of the total for all of 2009 with seven weeks left to go.

The report noted that even if the current pace continues, New York Police Department officials project the year-end murder total would still be the third lowest since the department started keeping records in 1962.

"Things have generally been going in the right direction," Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly said last week, according to the AP, noting the longer-term decreases indicate the department’s efforts and strategies are continuing to work.

According to Reuters, city councilman and chairman of the council’s Public Safety Committee Peter Vallone cited budget cuts, a weaker economy and state lawmakers’ weaker stance against prison terms for low-level drug felons as several of the reasons for the surge in the city’s murder rate.
fields.summary: The purchase of home security systems may be on the rise this year in New York City, as the Associated Press reports the city ...

fields.heading: Survey shows support for security cameras
fields.content:
The Post Standard released a report of a Syracuse, New York, Police Department survey which indicated 96 percent of Near West Side residents support the installation of nine security cameras in their neighborhood.

Syracuse Mayor Stephanie Miner claims that the alarming rate of violence that has recently taken place in the area has solidified her stance in regards to the importance of safety taking precedence over the privacy concerns raised by parents. “Unfortunately, the Near West Side has seen an explosion in crime,” she said.

According to the report, Miner said the camera recordings would be erased after 14 days and the evidence would fall under the same statutes as any other criminal evidence. She noted that multiple security cameras have already been installed throughout the city, and added that six cameras in the Near West Side already exist.

The report mentioned the survey was conducted by officers going door-to-door. The results indicated that 88 percent of the respondents said the cameras would make them feel safer in areas that they currently avoid. In addition, 89 percent said that the cameras would make them feel safer at home.

The camera proposal has been publicly resisted by some residents. WCAX-TV reports that many gathered outside city hall earlier this month to protest the plan.
fields.summary: The Post Standard released a report of a Syracuse, New York, Police Department survey which indicated 96 percent of Near West ...

fields.heading: Increase home security for $5
fields.content:
A member of the Cape Coral Police Department in Southwest Florida presented an almost free home security system outline after officer John Tsourkas explained that $5 can go a long way in keeping burglars out, according to WBBH-TV.

Tsourkas noted that the first place of access a Southwest Florida burglar looks for is the sliding glass doors. “What they’re going to do is grab a hold of the slider and lift it off its tracks and pull it out,” said Tsourkas, noting a brief visit to the hardware store can solve that specific problem.

According to the report, the officer stated that a dowel rod, priced at roughly $0.49, is the cheapest and easiest solution to this problem due to the fact that the rod will eliminate the extra space on top of the slider and take the leverage out of the door, so, as he says, “There is no way anyone can lift up the door anymore.”

As for windows, the report cited the officer stating that window lock clips costing $2.99 can be used to prevent a burglar from crawling through them.

Despite a number of recent incidents, burglaries were down from last year. According to the FBI, the total number of burglaries in the state was 181,884 in 2009, a figure that is down 3.5 percent from 2008.
fields.summary: A member of the Cape Coral Police Department in Southwest Florida presented an almost free home security system outline after ...

fields.heading: Americans urged to be cautious during holidays
fields.content:
The holiday months are a time for family joy and plentiful feasting, but it is also a time when people need to become more involved when it comes to home security monitoring, as the FBI says approximately 400,000 burglaries occur in the United States from November through December each year.

Lifeshield Security has several tips for people to abide by when it comes to avoiding a burglary from occurring in their home. First and foremost, the company says to make sure all the entrances to the home are locked with deadbolts to keep burglars from kicking them down.

Another valid tip the company noted is to break down and conceal empty computer and television boxes that are going to be disposed of in the trash because a burglar may figure out there are valuable goods in the home. Additionally, making sure any voice messages on a landline or cell phone do not declare to a possible burglar that a person is away from home for a certain amount of time remains an important step.

Burglaries of suburban homes represent a sizable number of burglaries every year. According to the FBI, there were 715,548 suburban burglaries in 2008 and 701,615 burglaries in 2009, a 1.9 percent decrease.
fields.summary: The holiday months are a time for family joy and plentiful feasting, but it is also a time when people need to become more ...

fields.heading: Michigan residents plead for increased police presence
fields.content:
A number of condo residents in Westland, Michigan, are speaking out about a significant increase in crime in recent months, according to the Westland Observer.

The paper reports that there have been more than 35 break-ins in recent months, and residents said that they have been forced to install home security systems and other deterrents to make themselves feel safer. One development has even hired a private security guard.

"Up to a year ago, we were very comfortable in our surroundings," Sherry Springer, president of the 250-member Deerhurst Condominium Association, told the paper. "People are afraid of leaving their homes, they are afraid of leaving the doors open to say hello to a neighbor. People no longer walk the streets. We've had an unbelievable increase in crime."

Springer added that she felt the spike in crime was ironic, as the neighborhood is located just half a mile from both City Hall and a police station. At a recent meeting, police said they have dedicated a number of plainclothes officers to the area.

Recent efforts have started to make a dent in the crime spike. Earlier this month, the Observer reported that the recent arrest of one suspect, who officials believe was responsible for several incidents, has slowed the number of burglaries.
fields.summary: A number of condo residents in Westland, Michigan, are speaking out about a significant increase in crime in recent months, ...

fields.heading: Police in Los Angeles to test new security camera access
fields.content:
The Los Angeles Police Department is set to test a new procedure which allows deputies to access the video feeds for private security cameras inside businesses in the town of Industry before they go inside, the San Gabriel Valley Tribune reports.

Officials have joined a partnership with the Chamber of Commerce for a test program that will soon give officers the ability to access the web and tap into secure live video feeds from their police cars in the event of an alarm or a call. The paper reports the system is based on the same system used by many daycares, allowing parents to monitor their children.

According to the Tribune, police will not monitor or record the camera feeds throughout the day, and a time-stamped audit will help prevent abuse by police. The program is expected to get off the ground in January, when officials begin inviting businesses to join.

Many businesses and schools have also worked to install additional security cameras to help maintain safety. The Associated Press reports that a program similar to that in Industry is taking place in Johnson City, Tennessee, where officers can access the video feed from inside local schools from their cars.
fields.summary: The Los Angeles Police Department is set to test a new procedure which allows deputies to access the video feeds for private ...

fields.heading: New Jersey murder rate lowest in a decade
fields.content:
New statistics show that New Jersey’s murder rate in 2009 was at its lowest level in ten years, and the overall crime rate curtailed 9 percent, according to the state’s Uniform Crime Report.

The report declared that there were 320 murders reported in 2009 compared to 376 in 2008, which shows that last year’s homicide total is inching closer to the 288 murders reported in 2000.

“Our latest crime data shows reductions in just about all major categories of crime. This is testimony to the skill and dedication of the men and women of our law enforcement community,” said state attorney general Paula Dow, noting the total crime rate for the Garden State was 23.9 victims for every 1,000 residents, a 2.3 point decrease from 2008.

The best home security system is one that does not encounter a significant number of crimes, as the report noted violent crime in the state went down from 28,281 reported incidents to 27,108, a decrease of 4 percent. This statistic marked the eighth consecutive year that the crime rate decreased, according to the report.

According to the FBI, there were 1,318,398 violent crimes reported nationally in 2009, a violent crime rate of one incident for every 429.4 people in the country, which is a 5.3 percent decrease from 2008.
fields.summary: New statistics show that New Jersey’s murder rate in 2009 was at its lowest level in ten years, and the overall crime ...

fields.heading: Protect your home for the holidays
fields.content:
There is no place like a safe home during the holidays, so if the holiday plans include traveling and not being home for a period of time, SmarterTravel.com suggests following prototypical home security measures to make sure the home remains protected.

First and foremost, the report recommends making sure the home looks like someone is actually home, when, in reality, the homeowner is away. Jim McGuffey, founder of A.C.E Security Consultants, told the site, “You want to make sure your home looks lived in.” He noted that, if it snows, make sure there are arrangements for plowing the driveway and clearing off the steps.

The report cited other home security steps such as unplugging garage door openers, making sure the landscaping and shrubbery on the property is trimmed low enough so potential burglars can’t use those areas for a hiding spot, and using outdoor and indoor motion-sensor and timer lighting systems as part of the residents’ home alarm system so burglars can’t use the darkness to their advantage while on the property.


According to the FBI, of all burglaries committed in 2009, 61 percent involved forcible entry, a statistic that validates the need to secure a home to the fullest extent possible.
fields.summary: There is no place like a safe home during the holidays, so if the holiday plans include traveling and not being home for a ...

fields.heading: St. Louis labeled most violent city
fields.content:
St. Louis, Missouri is now known as the most dangerous city in America, a title that was formerly held by Camden, New Jersey, according to CQ Press. The most violent city list is made up from the FBI’s 2009 uniform crime statistics, which cover murder, rape, burglary, robbery, aggravated assault and vehicle theft, says the report.

The report statistically noted that St. Louis had more than 2,000 crimes per 100,000 residents, compared to the national average of about 430 crimes. Experts told CNN that these rankings sometimes reflect oversimplifications, adding that the FBI does not endorse using its stats to make complete generalizations about crime and entire cities.

“When you look at these rankings and lists, the findings fall apart,”John Jay College of Criminal Justice professor Andrew Karmen told CNN. “Crime reporting is nuanced and is affected by factors that can differ from one zip code to another.”

The report cites the faltering economy as a huge factor in the crime data. After St. Louis, the next most violent cities are Camden, New Jersey; Detroit, Michigan; Flint, Michigan and Oakland, California.

Not only can it provide the security needed, but GE home alarm systems allow consumers to save money with home insurance. In some cases, the savings can be as much as 20 percent, according to Alarm Zone.
fields.summary: St. Louis, Missouri is now known as the most dangerous city in America, a title that was formerly held by Camden, New Jersey, ...

fields.heading: Violent crimes see increase in New York City
fields.content:
Although New York City’s overall crime rate has dropped for the 22nd straight year, violent crimes such as murders, rapes and robberies are all on track to show increases, according to a Wall Street Journal report.

The New York Police Department showed, as of November 7, the city’s overall crime rate dropped 1.26 percent from a year earlier, but the report noted that all four violent crime categories are projected to show increases by the end of the year. This projection includes 15 percent hikes in both murders and rapes, according to the report.

Determining if the recent surge in violent crime is a serious trend or not is difficult to pinpoint. “A 15 percent increase is only important if it’s the beginning of an upturn,” Michael Rand, a statistician with the U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics told the paper. “And unfortunately we won’t know that for many years.”

Whether the statistical spike in violent crimes in New York is something for residents to worry about or not, taking necessary precautions and installing home security systems may decrease the chances of any crime taking place in one’s home.
fields.summary: Although New York City’s overall crime rate has dropped for the 22nd straight year, violent crimes such as murders, rapes ...

fields.heading: Home security systems create peace of mind
fields.content:
Homeowners without some kind of home security system may increase their odds of a crime occurring in their home, according to the Buffalo News, which declaring that installing home security equipment creates a peace of mind for those living inside.

Home security options can include simple alarms for entry doors, motion detectors placed throughout a home and video surveillance that can be used around the outside of the home and is able to store footage for up to a month, according to the report.

Charlene Fadel, a victim of a home burglary, told the paper “It’s worth it. You can’t put a price on your safety,” she said. “After a burglary happens to you, you think differently about alarms; you can’t think any other way.

As part of the high-tech culture, home control panels can be linked to the Internet, so alarms can be be activated or deactivated remotely, people can view live images from their security cameras, and the capability of turning lights on and off from a smart phone as well as the computer is a viable option, according to the report.

Security systems for homes can be generic and moderately priced, or detailed and expensive, but any home security system is easy to set to preference in order to fit the security needs of any home, says Home Alarm Directory.
fields.summary: Homeowners without some kind of home security system may increase their odds of a crime occurring in their home, according to ...

fields.heading: Home security tips to follow
fields.content:
Every homeowner should make it a priority to ensure the safety of their home by taking necessary home security precautions.

Whether a person decides to put in a home security system or not, Oneindia living released a list of its best home security tips that will protect a home and the family inside. First, the report says to turn down the telephone and answering machine volume when going out so burglars can’t hear that no one is home.

Secondly, the report recommends installing sensor lights around the outside entrances. Putting in deadbolt locks on all the entry doors and locking the garage and slider doors are a must when taking the more efficient home security measures, says the report.

Other important tips cited in the report include having a neighbor pick up the mail, check for any vulnerable spots on the home, and to see if there is a Neighborhood Watch association in the community, which will provide updates on neighborhood problems and allows additional people to provide protection for the home and family.

Homeowners can also strongly consider installing a monitored home security system to keep intruders at bay. The FBI said victims of burglary offenses suffered an estimated $4.6 billion in lost property in 2009, an average dollar loss per burglary of $2,096.
fields.summary: Every homeowner should make it a priority to ensure the safety of their home by taking necessary home security ...

fields.heading: Metro residential burglaries on the rise in Savannah
fields.content:
The Savannah Morning News reports residential burglary in the city has jumped by about five percent from the same time period in 2009, according to data from the Savannah-Chatham Police Department.

The data provided by metro police indicates the department’s Central Precinct has seen the most amount of burglaries this year, which was followed closely by the Islands Precinct and the West Chatham Precinct. According to the paper, the data shows, as of November 6, the Central Precinct has reported 41 more incidents than the same point in time last year.

In addition, statistics show at least 26 percent of suspects detained on burglary charges are juvenile, and of the 46 suspects arrested on burglary charges, 12 were juvenile, according to the paper.

Some officers are encouraging residents to provide themselves with some form of home security equipment. Corporal Tony Lopez, metro police Central Precinct crime prevention officer, told the Savannah Morning News, “Home security should always be implemented in layers,” he commented, noting by “hardening a target,” a criminal will be deterred.

When installing home security systems, residents should make sure all the wiring from the system is fully concealed because an experienced burglar will scope it out and cut or disconnect the security system, writes Home Security Systems Advice.
fields.summary: The Savannah Morning News reports residential burglary in the city has jumped by about five percent from the same time period ...

fields.heading: Holidays equal increase in crime
fields.content:
The holidays are a time for traveling, which opens up opportunities for intruders that might take advantage of a vacant home without sufficient home security. Local police gave KSNT-TV a report full of safety tips for people that are going to be away from home during the holidays.

The Shawnee County Sheriff's Office told the station that residents need to make sure the garage door is locked, keep all doors and windows locked and be sure to have a trusted person pick up the mail and check the home inside and out.

For those out shopping on Black Friday, the report encourages people to keep their car doors locked at all times because burglars look for unsecured vehicles with valuables in them. Additionally, the report says not to overstock the car with bags of gifts, as a burglar will notice them and break the car windows in order to attain the items.

Other areas have also noticed an increase in crime around the holidays. The Iowa Press-Citizen reports that police there are stepping up patrols over Thanksgiving.
fields.summary: The holidays are a time for traveling, which opens up opportunities for intruders that might take advantage of a vacant home ...

fields.heading: Tips to protect the home during Thanksgiving weekend
fields.content:
A large quantity of American homeowners are planning to go away for Thanksgiving, leaving the home vulnerable, which is why police are providing home security tips for people who are going to be away.

WMBF-TV released the report of tips given to them by South Carolina’s Horry County Police. The most important advice is to make sure it looks someone is home. Horry County Police Sargent Robert Kegler, says, “The best thing you can do is make sure it doesn’t look like you’re away,” he said. “Whether it’s a light on in the kitchen, a light on in the living room, make it look like you’re home.”

According to the report, Horry County Police reported 31 burglaries during Thanksgiving week alone in 2009. The report cites experts recommend having a trusted neighbor come and collect the mail and newspapers to aid in concealing the fact that the home is empty.

The station noted that home security companies are coming up with innovative tools like cell-phone applications that can allow a person to monitor their home from anywhere in the world.

Other areas have noticed an increase of crime during the holidays, as the Daily Breeze reports police in Gardena, California will step up their patrols during the holidays.
fields.summary: A large quantity of American homeowners are planning to go away for Thanksgiving, leaving the home vulnerable, which is why ...

fields.heading: Ohio city to add surveillance cameras
fields.content:
Seven surveillance cameras will be installed in high-crime areas throughout Canton, Ohio.

Police Chief Dean McKimm said that the security cameras will cost a total of $4,500 and will be funded with grant money, as he then noted they will be wireless and will have connection with the Internet.

Additionally, officials noted that the cameras will be moved around to different areas in the city where crime is prevalent and won’t be fixed in one location. “We’ll be moving them from place to place according to the need expressed by citizens,” McKimm told CantonRep.

The cameras will not be watched continuously and footage will only be looked over by police after a crime has been reported in close proximity to the camera, McKimm said.

According to Neighborhood Scout, the city has a crime index of 3, meaning that Canton, Ohio is safer than just 3 percent of American cities. The property crime rate in the city is 75.5, compared to the national median of 34.3, says Neighborhood Scout. Video security as well as additional home security equipment may be a good idea for people living in that area who want to increase their safety.
fields.summary: Seven surveillance cameras will be installed in high-crime areas throughout Canton, Ohio.Police Chief Dean McKimm said that the ...

fields.heading: Home security tips for those in need
fields.content:
The Associated Press reports that Folsom, California has been victim to multiple home burglaries within the past week, so the Folsom City Police Department provided home security tips for anyone who needs them during the holidays.

The objective of these tips is to make it look like someone is home even when in reality no one is home, says the report. Suggestions include using bright exterior lighting to diminish the stealthiness of a possible burglar, sufficiently locking entry doors, windows and sliders and installing light timers and a radio to give off the effect that someone is home, according to the report.

Additionally, the report cites more tips such as stopping newspaper and mail deliveries, securing valuables in a safe, using audible door alarms to attract attention to a burglary, and providing a trusted neighbor who knows the home is going to be vacant for a certain period of time with contact information.

Home security measures should be implemented by residents and the community during the holidays. Police are stepping up their patrols during the holiday season in many areas throughout the country. WAFF-TV reports the Huntsville Alabama Police Department will provide their county with increased enforcement from November 26 through December 31.

fields.heading: Indiana town is victim to rash of burglaries during Thanksgiving break
fields.content:
The holidays bring families and friends together, but it is a time when burglars try to crash the festive atmosphere, as was the case in Bloomington, Indiana where numerous homes experienced property crimes, according to the Indiana Daily Student.

The paper declared at least 10 Bloomington homes suffered damage including broken windows, kicked-in doors and missing property during Thanksgiving break. The local police department notes the high volume of students leaving town for holiday opens up opportunities for thieves.

Lieutenant David Drake, of the Bloomington Police Department, says, “Any time students are gone for Thanksgiving or Christmas break, we usually see an increase in burglary reports when they return.”

Valuable items such as high-definition televisions, guitars, video game consoles and iPod devices were among the many items stolen during the burglaries, according to the paper.

Installing home security equipment in a residence may decrease the chances a burglar has to get away without consequence. Even a small security camera can perform well in these situations, as the San Diego Union Tribune cites a story where a camera was installed in a home and captured the image of a recent burglar, which has now been posted online.

fields.heading: Mississippi cities see increase in crime
fields.content:
Crime has increased in certain Mississippi states, most notably in Columbus, Mississippi where residents saw a 16.9 percent increase from 2008 to 2009, according to the Commercial Dispatch.

An FBI study showed the city reported a total of 2,494 crimes last year, which is the most since 2005 when 2,749 crimes were reported, according to the paper. The increase is due to more burglaries committed by a marginal group of people, Columbus Police chief Joseph St. John said to the paper.

The study showed there 276 burglaries in 2009, which is 77 more than there were in 2008. “That is why we have to stay vigilant,” St. John told the paper. “If two or three people are allow to run free and commit crime unfettered, it impacts the community and the numbers.”

Columbus continues to be plagued primarily with property crimes, larceny and motor vehicle theft, according to the paper. However, violent crimes and aggravated assault statistics in the city were comparatively low.

People wanting to decrease their chances of being the victim of a crime at their home may want to consider installing home security systems to ensure their property is protected. KPTV recently cited national statistics which show only 15 percent of homeowners in America have a home security system, leaving 85 percent of the nation’s homes more vulnerable to a burglary.

fields.content:
Homeowners without some kind of home security system may increase their odds of a crime occurring in their home, according to TimesDaily, which reported that the choice to install home security equipment can create a safe atmosphere for those living inside.

One security expert says the objective of putting in home security equipment is to feel safe, according to the report. Jim Fiorillo, owner of Huntsville Security, says, “When we put in a security system, the homeowner is paying for security, but they are getting peace of mind, and that’s what they want,” he said.

The report cites research done by the Insurance Information Institute, which noted that burglars are thrown off if it takes them longer than expected to break into a home, or if they can’t get in without making noise. Additional research from the institute claims a burglar is likely to not go through with the burglary if it take more than five minutes to break in, says the report.

Home security systems may become a necessity if property crimes continue to increase. There was a 2 percent increase in the number of burglaries in 2009 when compared to 2005, according to the FBI.

fields.heading: Advice to avoid holiday crime
fields.content:
A surge in crime is normal during the holidays, and that is why KPSP-TV is offering tips for people to follow in hopes of deterring a crime from creeping up on them.

Police departments in California have already juiced up patrols, as many were expecting the spike in thefts and robberies during this time of year, according to the station. The network cited incidents that have already taken place in the past week, including a restaurant and its customers that were robbed.

Some tips to follow to lessen the chances of being targeted this holiday season consist of not displaying gifts where they can be clearly visible and to make sure all the home and car doors and windows are locked, the station reports.

For those traveling out of state for the holidays, the station advised that residents should make sure to ask a trusted neighbor or friend to watch over the house and pick up the mail and newspapers, and do not post anything on a social networking site that may indicate someone is out of town.

Home security equipment may also provide people with the most proficient way to maintain safety on their property. One insurance services owner recently said an alarm can offer peace of mind for those who feel vulnerable to a home invasion, according to a Times Colonist report.

fields.heading: Tips to secure the home from burglaries
fields.content:
The Chillicothe Gazette is offering a few tips from the Chillicothe police department for people to abide by if they want to keep their homes safe from a burglary.

First of all, the report urges residents to lock their doors no matter what, and to be sure not to leave empty boxes out for the trash to pick up. Depending on the value of the item that was inside the box, it might signify to a burglar there are expensive items in the home.

Another strategy homeowners can apply is to ask a friend or neighbor to walk around the home with the mentality of a thief, which may help spot any security weaknesses, says the report.

The Chillicothe police department recommends residents install home alarm systems with an exterior alarm that will alert neighbors, and possibly police officers on duty. Police chief Roger Moore told the Gazette, "On several occasions police officers on patrol have heard the alarm sounding several minutes before an alarm company has notified our department."

There were more than 2.1 million burglaries last year in America, and 73 percent of those were home burglaries, according to the FBI.

fields.heading: Ways to protect the home while away
fields.content:
Between family get-togethers and parties, homeowners have a lot weighing on their mind during this time of year, but they should be mindful of securing their homes if they plan on traveling or being away for a period of time.

EMC News has provided a number of helpful tips for people to implement in hopes of improving their home security and making it difficult to impossible for a burglar to break in while the house is empty.

Making an empty home look like it is occupied is a key factor in neutralizing an intruder’s ability to make a move, says the report. Stopping the mail and newspaper delivery and setting lights on the property on timers are both common tips for people that are going to be away from home.

Locking all the windows and doors is something that should be done anytime a person leaves their home, says the report. Homeowners should also be sure not to forget to hide all the valuables and keep expensive items out of the windows.

Home security systems may be the most proficient way keep the property safe from intruders. Police in the Tri-state area validate the notion that the holiday season means more homes get burglarized because criminals believe it is their best chance for a big pay-off, says a WFIE-TV report.

fields.heading: Burglaries prevalent in upstate New York
fields.content:
The Pine Hills neighborhood in Albany, New York has experienced a rash of burglaries since October, according to WNYT-TV.

Albany police told the station that there have been 34 reported burglaries since the start of October in and around the neighborhood. In addition, the authorities noted that 14 of the incidents happened during the day and 14 occurred during the overnight hours. Poor home security measures were taken by residents, as the police indicated roughly half the burglars entered unsuspecting homes through windows or doors that were not locked.

The lack of security awareness by residents caused the police to provide tips to the station for people who want to ensure that their properties are secure from intruders. Locking the doors and windows at all times is a strongly emphasized suggestion after the recent events. The authorities referred community service officers to citizens, who can survey a resident's property and inform them of what needs to be done from a security standpoint.

There were 321.6 burglaries per 100,000 residents in the state of New York in 2009, according to the FBI. Implementing home security systems in residences are known to be an efficient way to deter intruders from properties.

fields.heading: New Jersey's Ocean City sees rash of burglaries
fields.content:
Ocean City, New Jersey, residents have been victim to 18 burglaries in the past three weeks, according to a report from the Press of Atlantic City.

Ocean City police told the paper that the burglars are primarily stealing flat screen televisions. Additionally, the high number of break-ins have resulted from intruders gaining access through side entrances of the homes, which authorities noted were not visible from the road.

As a result of the burglaries, police said they are providing extra patrols in the areas where it is needed. Also, authorities told the paper they are taking home security to the next level by performing random property checks in hopes of ensuring the amount of break-ins decreases.

Residents have been informed by police to personally check their homes periodically and to activate home security systems if they have them. Furthermore, any residents who plan on being away from home for a long time should keep valuables hidden as opposed to leaving them in the windows.

Other states in the country have seen an increase in burglaries in recent weeks, such as Newton, New Hampshire, where the Eagle Tribune reports that the police in the town have also increased their patrols.

fields.heading: Free home video security cameras for Flint Township residents
fields.content:
The Flint Township Police Department is planning to hand out free home video security cameras next Tuesday to the first 50 residents in line from certain neighborhoods, according to WJRT-TV.

The cameras are worth $150, and they are made up of two wireless video cameras and a remote transmitter, says the station. After the selected citizens get their security cameras, they simply have to screw the devices into place and plug them in. The transmitter will allow people to hook them up to a television or computer.

Local authorities note that installing security cameras will provide a safer environment for residents. Lieutenant Tim Jones told the station, "It's peace of mind," he commented. "Sometimes people are nervous about answering the door in the middle of the night. This allows them to not have to open the door."

A federal grant along with contributions from the Target Corporation and other organizations made the give-away possible, according to the station. Some of the eligible Flint Township subdivision areas, include Dayton Heights, Riverview, Ridgecliff and Utley Hills.

In addition to preventing crime, security cameras may help provide evidence one might need to prosecute or locate a perpetrator if a crime does happen, according to HomeSecuritySystemSales.com.

fields.heading: Ways to prevent property crime
fields.content:
Property crime prevention is something every homeowner should be aware of, because anyone can become a victim. The Eugene Police Department provided helpful home safety tips to the Oregon Daily Emerald.

For those planning on traveling during the coming weeks, the department told the paper it is wise to recruit a trusted friend or neighbor to check on the home periodically to make sure everything is safe and in order. Another safety step consists of sufficiently locking all the windows and doors.

In addition, the Eugene Police Department has a volunteer group which provides free home checks while homeowners are away. By request, the group keeps track of inventory on the property to ensure everything is accounted for.

Crimes in the collegiate section of the town also see a rise in property crimes when the fall term ends and students leave to go home for winter break, which is why local police are encouraging them to lock all of the entry ways into their residences.

According to the FBI, the property crime rate in Oregon was 2,967 per 100,000 residents in 2009. Home security systems are one of the most efficient ways to keep intruders off the property.

fields.heading: Safety tips for the holiday season
fields.content:
This is the time of year when people are concerned about gaining weight, but they also should be wary about making sure their home is secure for the holidays. Burglaries are known to increase when residents are away from home celebrating with their families, which is why WNDU-TV recently released a report of safety and security tips for local residents to abide by.

The Mishawaka Police Department provided the station with home security suggestions, such as locking all the doors, windows and garage doors. In addition, those going out of town for the holidays should not announce their plans to the world, by leaving any informative destination comments on the answering machine or on any social networking sites.

Authorities told the station that having a reliable friend or even the police department come check around the property to ensure everything is as it should be is a method for residents to consider. Making the home look like it is occupied by setting outdoor and indoor lights on timers when people are away is a tactic that might scare off potential intruders.

Police officers encourage residents to install home security systems. Getahomesecuritysystem.org notes that 90 percent of authorities believe home security systems prevent burglaries.

fields.heading: Indiana town trying to fight crime
fields.content:
New Albany, Indiana, is known as an inner-city neighborhood where crime happens once in a while, but this past summer local police saw an increase in activity.

The New Albany Police Department is now working to stop crime before it starts. The department's first initiative is to launch "Problem Oriented Policing" which is a detail that the authorities will use to increase patrols in certain areas. In addition, the officers will primarily focus on preventing thefts, burglaries, vandalism and juvenile problems.

The department is adamant about preserving the city's safety. Police chief Bailey told the station, "I have people who truly and genuinely want to make a difference in our community," he commented to WDRB-TV. "They've been asking for this. This is something our staff wants."

Bailey also added that he wants to bring back the neighborhood watch program, which he says used to have a "strong presence" in the city.

Burglars appear to have done damage in Indiana, as the FBI reports that the burglary rate per 100,000 residents in the state was 761.5 in 2009, compared to the national rate of 716.1. Homeowners concerned about becoming a victim of a break-in may want to consider installing home security systems, due to their effectiveness against intruders.

fields.heading: Burglaries increase in Indiana city
fields.content:
Many U.S cities see an increase of break-ins during this time of year, and Gary, Indiana, is no exception. The Post Tribune recently reported that there were 210 burglaries in November, averaging out to seven per day.

Detective Keith Richardson told the paper that the combination of decreased day light hours and an increase in holiday shopping makes this time of year ideal for burglars. Police chief Gary Carter said last week, "It's bad here, but it's bad everywhere," he commented, noting that at a recent meeting he listened to other law enforcement officials cite increases in residential break-ins.

In response, the authorities created a burglary task force in the city, which consists of officers monitoring the streets in unmarked vehicles while looking for burglars.

Carter noted that having a trusted neighbor watch the house while the homeowner is gone is a great way to decrease the risk of becoming a victim of a burglary. In addition, authorities encouraged residents to use timers for inside and outside lights and added that keeping valuables out of the windows may help keep perpetrators at bay.

Home security systems are one of the more efficient ways to keep burglars out. Based on statistics, a criminal is less likely to break into a home that has home alarm monitoring, says a post on ArticlesBase by Home Security Systems 123.

fields.heading: Oregon area sees a recent increase in property crime
fields.content:
The Florence, Oregon, area has seen a recent rash of burglaries and vehicle break-ins, which has local police investigating nearly 30 crimes that have accounted for the loss of thousands of dollars worth of valuables belonging to residents, according to the Siuslaw News.

Since the start of last month, at least 16 burglaries were reported to the Florence Police Department on top of a dozen vehicle thefts. Police chief Maruice Sanders told the paper that this is the highest number of incidents within a 30-day period in 2010. Last year, the highest number of burglaries in a month was seven in July.

Sanders noted that no property is off the burglary radar, as business, residences and a local chapel have all been victims to break-ins. Knowing that no area is safe from a possible burglary, residents in the area may have to start thinking about installing home security systems to ensure the safety of their property and themselves.

Burglaries remain one of the more common forms of property crime in America, as the FBI says they accounted for 23.6 percent of property crimes that took place in 2009.

fields.heading: Ways to prevent burglaries
fields.content:
Burglaries tend to increase during this time of year, as intruders try to take advantage of empty homes that may be vulnerable. The Memphis Police Department has issued a report of burglary-prevention tips that homeowners can put to use all year round.

The basic home safety tips include making the residence look as though it is occupied even when it is not. Leaving the indoor and outdoor lights on timers so they turn on and off periodically may make it more difficult for intruders to take the risk. People should also routinely lock all doors and windows, says the report.

If plans include being away from home for an extended period of time, officials say residents should be sure to make arrangements with a trusted neighbor to come check the property at least once a day. Additionally, the report recommends having a neighbor bring in the mail or let the post office know that all mail deliveries need to be stopped for the time being.

The department also recommends investing in home alarm systems, because they feel, "An alarm system is excellent for home security." The Orlando Police Department also encourages residences to use home alarm systems because they say intruders generally avoid homes with one.
fields.summary: Burglaries tend to increase during this time of year, as intruders try to take advantage of empty homes that may be vulnerable. ...

fields.heading: Western Massachusetts city named one of the most dangerous
fields.content:
Springfield, Massachusetts, has been labeled the 35th most dangerous city in America this year, according to the 2010 CQ Press rankings that were recently released.

City authorities told the Daily Collegian that Springfield saw a 5 percent increase in its overall crime rate in 2009. Going deeper into the statistics reveals the city may have a burglary problem, as the area saw a 21 percent increase in burglaries last year. The city also saw a 7 percent increase in motor vehicle related crimes and a 6 percent increase in felony assaults.

The authorities noted they are doing their best to keep the residents in the community safe. Kathleen Brown, the Springfield community police liaison, told the paper, "We try to provide the best services and collaboration in the community to prevent harm."

She added that diligence of police officers, community participation and "positive municipal outlets" for residential involvement will provide the city with lower crime rates.

Home security systems are helping people realize how secure the devices can make a home. Burglaries are common in any neighborhood, as FBI statistics show that a burglary occurs in the U.S. more than once every 15 seconds.

fields.heading: Home security and monitoring tips for travelers
fields.content:
A large number of Americans travel for the holidays, usually leaving their homes unattended and vulnerable to a possible burglary. However, there are now more different types of home security systems and tools which provides homeowners with many different options to protect their homes.

Alarm.com recently released a list of tips for people to use to protect their homes from intruders. The company noted that the wireless technology contained in present-day home security systems gives homeowners the opportunity to monitor their properties by using remote alarms while they are on the road. A mobile phone can now be used to control entire home security systems, and the devices allow homeowners on the road to watch footage from their security cameras right on their phones.

Another common tip for holiday travelers is to lock all the doors and windows, but with new mobile device technology, homeowners can be notified if their locked doors become unlocked.

AAA projected that 87.7 million people would be traveling 50 or more miles away from home during the holidays in 2009, and the company predicts similar numbers in 2010.

fields.heading: Keeping burglars away is a community effort
fields.content:
Burglaries can happen anywhere at any time, but a thief looking to score big may tend to prefer a residential home. The Palm Beach Police Department has released a report of tips people can use that will help keep intruders away from residential properties.

If a suspicious person is lurking in any neighborhood, the department strongly recommends that people within the area should call the police as soon as possible. Residential neighborhoods can work together by looking out for fishy activity on each other's properties. All homeowners need to make sure that all doors and windows are sufficiently secured, as the department notes at least one-half of all residential burglaries enter through doors or windows that are unlocked.

Another tip is to try to keep indoor and outdoor lights on timers if possible, because as the department suggests, burglars "hate" bright lights. This method is especially useful for people who are going to be away from home for an extended period of time. Residents should also take care to hide all the valuables in case a perpetrator does manage to get in.

If there are home alarm systems in the home, the department recommends using them all the time. The Memphis Police Department also recommended that homeowners should consider installing home security systems to protect their property.
