fields.heading: Home security cameras creating peace of mind
fields.content:
Residents in the Flint Township area are already feeling a sense of security after the local police department gave out free security cameras to the first 50 people who showed up to a giveaway last week, according to WJRT-TV.

After becoming victims of a home break-in earlier in the year, one local elderly couple has regained their home security confidence since receiving the surveillance equipment. Larry Lemieux told the station, "We are elderly and we feel we were taken advantage of once before because of our age," noting that his wife's purse was stolen during the incident.

Now they, along with their neighbors, are hoping that the addition of the security cameras will create safer neighborhoods and add a certain level protection from perpetrators. The equipment given to the 50 residents consists of two cameras that run on a wireless system which can hold up to four cameras, according to the station.

Homeowners are at risk of losing more than just their sense of feeling safe, as FBI statistics indicated that property crimes resulted in estimated losses of $15.2 billion in 2009.

fields.heading: Thieves enjoy being in other homes for the holidays
fields.content:
Being home during the holidays is generally meant for family members to enjoy each other's company, but burglars also want to get it on the festivities, specifically the part where gifts are opened. To help people safely enjoy their presents, security experts provided CBS 2 in New York with some safety tips for homeowners.

Security expert David Bohem recommends thoroughly checking all the doors and locks periodically to ensure they are sturdy and working sufficiently. Another tip is to always request a signature when a package is delivered to the door so they won't be left on the doorstep. He also warns homeowners to not keep anything that looks valuable under the Christmas tree because a thief may try to test his luck.

Although home security systems are an effective way to keep burglars away, one security system expert urges people to keep them on all the time rather than just at night. Ethan Blumenfeld, of Advanced Security Systems, told the station, "You are paying for it. It is really a premium service and it is another way to protect yourself."

Police departments around the country also encourage homeowners to invest in home security systems, as the Vermilion Parish Sheriff in Louisiana told the Vermilion Today paper that residents should consider a home security or alarm system.

fields.heading: North Carolina residents see rash of burglaries
fields.content:
Certain communities in North Carolina have lost their sense of security after several towns have seen a recent increase in crime, specifically burglaries and larcenies, according to the Star News.

In 2009, Wilmington saw property crimes increase from 5,447 to 6,236 and such crimes in Wrightsville Beach jumped 39 percent, according to FBI data cited in the report. Additionally, property crimes in Carolina Beach saw a 34 percent increase and Bayshore Estates reported more than 54 property crimes in the past two years.

One Wilmington family recently experienced an incident where a man with a black wreath-hanger was attempting to break-in through the couple's kitchen door, says the report. As a result, the burglar never gained entrance to the home but the door's double-paned glass was destroyed and the family was understandably shaken from the incident.

Burglar alarms are one way homeowners can ensure their property is safe. The Insurance Information Institute says burglar alarms that project noise outside will most likely frighten intruders from trying to enter the home.

fields.heading: Safeguard homes for the holidays
fields.content:
The holidays are a time for families to enjoy each other's company, but burglars are also trying to enjoy this time of year by breaking into unsuspecting households and stealing presents.

Newton, California, police chief Randy Richardson has provided tips for people to follow in hopes of deterring thieves from their homes. He suggested to securely lock all the windows and doors. A home that looks like it is occupied even when it is not may keep intruders at bay, says the police chief. An efficient way to make the home look like people are home is to leave the lights on by timers.

Burglaries tend to increase in neighborhoods during the holidays. "We do see an increase in burglaries in December," Richardson told The West Side Index & Gustine Press-Standard.

Another recommendation for homeowners going away for an extended period of time is to stop the mail and newspaper delivery, as Richardson noted that a build-up of papers on one's front step may indicate to a criminal that people are away.

Some form of home security systems are encouraged by authorities throughout the country, as the Orlando Police Department recommends residents using at least an alarm system because it will decrease the risk of a home burglary.
fields.summary: The holidays are a time for families to enjoy each other's company, but burglars are also trying to enjoy this time of year ...

fields.heading: Texas city sees crime increase
fields.content:
Round Rock, Texas, has seen its crime rates increase as its population has grown from 2004 to 2009.

The city has seen its population rise 23 percent since 2004, and with that growth came a spike in crime. During that time period, crime surged 39 percent, and overall crime numbers have doubled in the past 10 years. However, while violent crime has plateaued, property crime had the largest increase this past year.

The city's police chief noted a lack of police officers as one of the reasons for the increase in property crime. Police chief Bryan Williams told KXAN-TV, "In the long term it's not enough," he commented. "We've got to provide more resources with the growth we're experiencing."

One crime hot spot in the town is in the area along the Interstate 35 corridor, where criminals have no problem quickly getting away after breaking into cars, hotels and shopping centers.

If there aren't enough police officers to keep all the residents safe, home security systems are not a bad alternative to make things more difficult for burglars. Research done by the Insurance Information Institute indicates that intruders are deterred if it takes extra time to break into a home or if they can't proceed quietly.

fields.heading: Avoid informing burglars what presents were under the tree
fields.content:
An empty box that once contained a high-definition television in front of the house may be the thing that entices a burglar to decide to break into a residence. The Chattanooga Times Free Press has provided some suggestions for homeowners to think about in terms ensuring their home security during the holidays.

The paper says that burglars may mark down addresses where there was an empty box outside, then come back when the home is vacant. There are ways to destroy any evidence of boxes before a thief can suspect anything. Taking the box to be disposed of at a recycling center, or breaking it into multiple pieces and putting it into different trash bags are two ways to prevent potential perpetrators from knowing what may be inside.

As for keeping the home secure, locking all windows and doors eliminates easy access for burglars. Also, burglar alarms are considered to be one of the more efficient types of home security systems, as long as homeowners remember to use it.

A five-year study that was completed last year indicated that installing burglar alarms in homes will decrease crime, according to the Rutgers University School of Criminal Justice.

fields.heading: Security cameras becoming more common for homeowners in Dallas
fields.content:
Burglaries are a year-long issue in communities throughout the country. But when the holidays come, so does increased risk for a home burglary.

Homeowners in the Dallas area are favoring the use of security cameras, as they hope it will help identity criminals if they do try to kick down the door or steal a package from the front step. The Dallas Morning News reported one incident in which packages containing several items were stolen right from a resident's steps.

However, the homeowners who had their packages stolen used their security cameras to capture the thief on video, which they then posted on You Tube, says the paper. The use of security cameras may become more widespread in the area.

Dallas County prosecutor Marc Moffitt told the paper he recently used homes' video surveillance equipment to prosecute criminals connected to a burglar and murder investigation. He added that the advancements in technology and video quality will make home security cameras "more common."

Burglaries are common in Dallas, as the FBI says that there were 19,428 incidents in 2009, more than any other city in the state except Houston.

fields.heading: New Jersey town sees multiple daytime burglaries
fields.content:
Police are investigating two daytime burglaries that took place this past Monday in Hillsdale, New Jersey.

Hillsdale Police detective Bob Francaviglia told Pascack Valley Community Life that both incidents may have involved the same intruder who gained access to the homes by kicking through the doors. Furthermore, authorities said that the perpetrator stole jewelry from the master bedrooms.

He added that both houses were unoccupied at the time and did not have burglar alarms. However, the thief attempted to break into a third home, but was stopped in his tracks after setting off a burglar alarm. The detective noted that his department believes the incidents are associated due to how close all of the homes are.

The authorities are urging residents to implement crime prevention techniques by putting strong locks on doors and windows, as well as keeping properties well-lit during the night to help deter burglars. "Be aware and be cognizant of everything," Francaviglia told the paper. "Everyone needs to watch everyone's home and report anything suspicious."

As noted in the perpetrator's third break-in attempt, an alarm scared them off. Burglar alarms provide a loud enough noise to scare intruders away the majority of the time, according to the Insurance Information Institute.

fields.heading: Missouri city sees rash of burglaries
fields.content:
Residents in Columbia, Missouri, are on edge after several home burglary incidents occurred so far in December, according to the Columbia Daily Tribune.

The police department has been investigating the burglaries in the northeast Columbia area of the city, including an attempted break-in at a local high school. The paper noted that among the items that have been stolen are electronics, televisions and antique coins.

One resident reported a loud noise in her home, and as she checked to see what it was, she ran into the burglar who apparently entered the home through an unlocked door, says the paper. Another incident on the same day saw a resident come home to find his back door forced open. Additionally, between December 3 and December 12, there have been 15 vehicle thefts.

Police are urging residents to lock all their home and car doors and windows, says the paper. Extra officers are on patrol in the area during the holidays in hopes of decreasing the amount of burglaries.

Home security systems are rapidly advancing in technology and making it easier for families to keep intruders away. WMBF-TV reported that home security companies are providing new tools to protect homes, such as cell phone applications that can be used to monitor a household from anywhere.

fields.heading: California town sees burglaries increase
fields.content:
Property crimes in Chico, California, have spiked since Thanksgiving, as local authorities say there have been over 40 home break-ins during the past three weeks.

College students who have gone home for holiday break have made up the majority of burglary victims, which provides prime opportunities for intruders, says the station. The most common items that have been stolen are electronic devices such as laptops, video game consoles, and cameras. A Chico State student, Josh Faylor, told KRCR-TV three of his friends had items stolen from their school residences over Thanksgiving.

However, the Chico Police Department has provided burglary-prevention tactics for all residents in the area. One recommendation is for residents not to let the world know via a social networking site where and how long an individual is going to be away from home. Keeping valuables like electronic devices by one's side is something to consider. While away from home, people should also request a trusted neighbor or friend to watch the home periodically.

Another recommendation from other police departments is to install burglar alarms in the home. The Palm Beach Police Department says homeowners should always have their alarms on, as burglars tend to shy away from residences with home security systems.

fields.heading: Violent crimes increasing in Washington, D.C.
fields.content:
Violent crimes have risen significantly in the nation's capital over the past month, increasing the need for residents to use home security systems.

The Washington Times says that internal police department documents show that during the 30 day period that ended this past weekend, every category of violent crime in the city was up compared to last year.

Among the largest jumps is the number of recent sexual assaults. During the 30-day period, there were 21 incidents, compared to just nine in the same timeframe last year. Homicides, robberies, and assaults are also up.

Some officials say that local law enforcement needs to take steps to raise awareness among area residents.

"Why aren't we actively reaching out to the public and saying, 'Hey, listen, this is what you need to be doing'?" Kristopher Baumann, chairman of the labor committee that represents Metropolitan Police officers, told the paper.

The city's police chief has also come under fire in recent months. The Associated Press reports that chief Cathy Lanier, the city's first female chief, is not popular with union officials. However, the Mayor-elect of the city says that she will remain in her current post.

fields.heading: Burglars taking advantage of unoccupied vacation homes
fields.content:
While many of the part-time residents of the Atlantic City area head home for the winter months, local officials told the Press of Atlantic City that they see an uptick in the number of burglaries and other incidents during the same time period.

The paper says that some parts of the city have already experienced a number of burglaries, as criminals have broken down doors or shattered windows to get inside before making off with valuable electronics or other goods.

"They're picking these isolated neighborhoods. It's obvious someone has taken the time to stake out and watch the properties for a few days," police Lieutenant Steven Ang told the paper.

The problem has also been an issue in the past. The paper says that in 2003, a homeless resident broke into one home without burglar alarms and pawned many of the home's belongings. The homeowner didn't even discover the issue until they received a higher-than-usual electric bill.

Police are also warning full-time residents to take precautions and secure their properties. Officials told WMGM-TV reported earlier this month that robberies and burglaries were "on the rise."

fields.heading: Crimes rise in Northeast, suburban areas
fields.content:
A new report from the FBI says that while crime levels across the country declined during the first part of this year, states in the Northeast part of the country have seen many crime rates increase, while property crime has become more prevalent in suburban and rural areas.

According to the agency, during the first six months of this year, the murder rate in the Northeast increased by 5.7 percent compared to the same period last year, while reports of aggravated assault and burglary also showed significant jumps - showing the need for home security systems across the region.

The report added that while property crime dropped across the country as a whole, it increased when looking outside of counties in metro areas. In non-metro areas, property crimes increased by a full 1 percent compared to 2009.

One Northeastern city that may be reflective of the higher rate of crime is Boston. A few weeks ago, the Boston Herald reported that the city had experienced its 70th homicide of the year, approaching a 10-year high of 75 set five years ago.
fields.summary: A new report from the FBI says that while crime levels across the country declined during the first part of this year, states ...

fields.heading: Alarm systems not just for high-end homes
fields.content:
While home alarm systems were once just focused on higher-end homeowners and residents with extremely valuable possessions, Angie's List founder Angie Hicks tells the Indianapolis Star that the systems have developed many more practical applications as technology has evolved.

She says that parents can now use security cameras to see if their kids returned home from school on time from their computer at work, or even from their cell phone, giving them added peace of mind.

In addition, while the systems may not catch someone who tries to break into the home, Hicks says they often serve as a deterrent, especially if the home has signs from the company displayed. Burglars may simply search for another, less guarded, target.

"Years ago, home-security systems were thought of as just for people in higher-income brackets," Dominic Cipollone, of the security company Protection One, told the paper. "Today, really, there's a system for everyone out there. What's really important is that something in the home is better than nothing at all."

However, at this point the systems are still not widely installed. KPTV in Oregon reports that just 15 percent of homes nationwide currently have systems in place, and many homeowners neglect to turn them on regularly.

fields.heading: Iowa law enforcement warns about security over holidays
fields.content:
Speaking with Radio Iowa, Iowa Department of Public Safety spokesperson Jessica Lown gave some recommendations on how to protect one's home during the frantic holiday season.

Some of the biggest tips Lown recommends is to put a hold on newspaper and mail deliveries to homes and setting automatic light timers in and around the house. By doing this, Lown said "it looks like someone in your house is flipping the lights on and off a few times, even though you’re not home."

She added closing curtains and drapes and having police officers check in on homes can be effective as well at deterring home invasion.

A surprising no-no in Lown's book is posting on Facebook where you are headed for the holidays, citing "would-be thieves" who could take advantage and burglarize homes of people they know are on vacation.

The Iowa Department of Public Safety reports that 15,735 burglary cases and 1,191 robbery cases were reported in 2009. Of the total number of robberies and burglaries last year, 17.4 percent of robberies and 68.4 percent of burglaries happened in a residence.

fields.heading: Improving home alarm technology becoming more enticing
fields.content:
Though once only used as an expensive precaution for home invasion and disturbances, home alarm technology has now advanced to help with protection against all home threats, including fire and carbon monoxide, while also becoming fairly inexpensive.

The Indianapolis Star reports home video systems are becoming increasingly popular among all suburban homes, now allowing people able to monitor the safety of their homes from mobile devices and remote locations and remaining relatively cheap.

"You can make sure your kids have gotten in fine. Basically, keep an eye on your home," said Shawn Morgan, an installation technician with Nelson Alarm in Indianapolis. He added the ease of new systems, as most do not require a telephone line or internet connection anymore.

Dominic Cipollone, the district general manager of Protection One in Greenwood, Indiana, said the point of home alarm systems is to "scare the intruder out of the home," and described the qualities of burglar systems as "intangible."

In addition to the use of security cameras, burglar alarms and home safety systems, ADT recommends these tips for home safety: protecting points of entry to the house, being mindful of fire hazards and not advertising your absence from home.

fields.heading: Report: Property crime up in Washington in first half of 2010
fields.content:
New statistics released by the FBI detail the rise in property and violent crimes in Washington state over the first half of 2010.

According to the Seattle Times, the number of violent crimes in Seattle and Tacoma decreased from the first half of 2009. However, property crimes in those cities grew this year compared with the same period in 2009, while the number of violent crimes increased in Spokane.

Seattle Police Department spokesman Sgt. Sean Whitcomb told the paper that the decrease of overall US crime is "meaningless to someone who may have had their home broken into or their car stolen," though he did mention the news of decreased crime in the city.

Sgt. John Urquhart, a spokesman for the King County Sheriff's Office in Washington, doesn't take too much stock in the new statistics, insisting they "could mean anything, or [they] could mean nothing, according to the report.

The FBI report states the total number of murders reported in the country dropped 7.1 percent compared with the first six months of 2009, while robberies lessened by 10.7 percent, reports of rape shrunk by 6.2 percent and reports of vehicle thefts dropped by 9.7 percent.

fields.heading: Omaha firefighters teach kids about fire safety
fields.content:
More than 400 students from Hillside Elementary School in Omaha, Nebraska, were treated to songs, games and prizes on Tuesday when the Omaha Fire Department visited to discuss the importance of fire safety.

Captain David Mann discussed things like replacing smoke alarm batteries and escaping a burning home, according to the Omaha World-Herald. Some of the prizes for the children included home fire alarm systems.

The event was part of the fire department's "Home Escape Plan," which has been presented to more than 3,600 students statewide thus far with a goal of reaching 9,000 students across the state.

Mann estimated 80 percent of children attending a presentation will complete an escape plan with their families. The fire department credits the program and others like it in the area for keeping Omaha without a fire fatality for more than two years.

The US Fire Administration estimates 250 home fires involving Christmas trees and another 170 home fires involving holiday lights and other decorative lighting occur each year.

In order to maintain home security during the holidays, the USFA suggests inspecting holiday lights, not overloading electrical outlets and using nonflammable decorations only.

fields.heading: Elderly man in Alabama robbed in home, Christmas money stolen
fields.content:
The Times Daily of Florence, Alabama, reports an elderly man was a victim of home invasion, as he was robbed and beaten at his house in Tuscumbia. In total, the victim was robbed of $700.

Tuscumbia police detective Stuart Setliff told the newspaper the assault and robbery of the 71-year-old resident took place around 10:45 p.m.

"After beating him a few times with his fists, the robber told the victim to 'give it up' and forced [the victim] to give him all the money he had, which was $700,” Setliff said. According to the report, police believe the perpetrator entered through a window, despite the victim claiming the suspect came in through the front door.

According to the Times Daily, the victim told authorities the $700 was his Christmas shopping money.

According to the 2010 FBI Uniform Crime Report, there were 1,130 cases of robbery, 7,030 cases of burglary and 1,796 cases of aggravated assault in Birmingham, Huntsville, Mobile and Montgomery between January and June of this year.

fields.heading: Finance blog recommends home safety tips to protect assets
fields.content:
By spending time and money putting together a security plan for one's home, the risk of financial loss is substantially diminished, according to Everything Finance, a personal finance blog.

Advice is offered for things one can do around the house to deter home invasion and theft, such as refraining from putting a spare house key on the home's property, making the home appear occupied while vacant - like turning lights on - and installing motion detectors on the property.

However, despite these tips the article states home alarm systems are the best way to go when looking to protect one's house.

"Alarm systems that provide the best protection are those in which wiring is concealed," the article says. "A professional burglar knows how to deactivate and disconnect a variety of security systems, however, he or she cannot disable what cannot be seen."

The Insurance Information Institute says many insurance companies give discounts of at least 5 percent for a smoke detector, burglar alarm or dead-bolt locks installed in homes. Also, some insurance companies may cut premiums by as much as 15 or 20 percent if you install a sprinkler system and a fire and burglar alarm that rings at the police, fire or other monitoring stations.

fields.heading: 'New strategies' called for as D.C. home burglaries up
fields.content:
An editorial in the Washington Post recently acknowledged the district's continual increase in home burglaries over the last year, asking for "new strategies" to deal with the issue.

The article urges the importance of police in D.C. to focus on treating home invasions with the same importance as other serious cases handled by authorities.

"Burglars typically don't commit just one crime, nor do they age out of the offense," writes The Post. "So there is an incentive to solve cases."

The article reports that the Washington, D.C. Police Department has solved 85 burglaries with the arrest of 76 people in a 60-day period earlier this year.

The editorial suggests the formation of a "task force of senior prosecutors and veteran police" to address the issue of burglaries, citing the recent case of Washington Post writer Marc Fisher's home being burglarized earlier this month.

According to Washington, D.C. crime statistics compiled by the city's Research and Analysis Branch, there were 3,696 burglaries, 3,998 robberies and 18,012 larcenies and thefts in 2009.

fields.heading: Newport Beach family captures thief on home security camera
fields.content:
According to KTLA News, a Newport Beach family released home surveillance footage of a package being stolen from their property to local authorities.

The family told the reporter the theft occurred right after the UPS driver dropped off the package and they believe the suspect follows delivery trucks while dropping off packages.

KTLA reports the family set up the video camera system in their home, like those offered by Protect America, because they feel they've had packages tampered with in the past.

The woman on the footage pulls up to the house in a white car, grabs the package and leaves quickly, according to the story.

In the article, local police said two neighborhoods in Newport Beach have been targeted by thieves looking to steal packages delivered. However, it is not known if there is more than one suspect stealing from homes in the area.

According to the FBI's Uniform Crime Report, there have been 1,142 cases of larceny or theft in Costa Mesa, California, and 1,789 cases in Huntington Beach, California, in the first half of 2010. Both cities are located near Newport Beach.

fields.heading: Four to be charged for burglaries of D.C.-area homes
fields.content:
The Washington Post reports four men will be charged in connection with a string of burglaries in Montgomery County, Maryland, near Washington D.C.

The Post stated among the burglaries allegedly committed by the four men include a break-in at a home in Farmington section of Chevy Chase on October 13

The paper said a video surveillance system caught the thieves using a stolen credit card at a local McDonald's on October 28 in Tenleytown. Police reportedly used that footage to officially connect the crime to the suspects.

Montgomery County Police told the paper they are now reviewing residential burglaries in Montgomery and in Northwest D.C. from the past few months to connect any possible crimes related to these burglaries.

One of the suspects is still at-large, while three of the suspects are being held in a Washington, D.C. jail reportedly.

According to the Governor's Office of Crime Control & Prevention, there were 12,007 robberies and 125,771 larcenies and thefts in Maryland in 2009 - the lowest amount of robberies ever reported in the state, and the lowest amount of reported larcenies and thefts since 1984. In 2009, total property crime was down 8 percent from 2008.

fields.heading: Thousands of dollars worth of art, jewelry stolen from NYC apartment
fields.content:
A thief stole approximately $750,000 worth of Andy Warhol limited-edition prints and other artworks, as well as expensive watches and jewelry from a New York City apartment, the Associated Press reports.

According to the AP, Police say the thief drilled a hole through the wall of a hallway sometime between November 24 and 28. Authorities reportedly believe the apartment in the five-story building was burglarized sometime during Thanksgiving week when the owner was away.

The thief also reportedly removed the home video surveillance system set up at the apartment. The paper reported no video cameras on the block reported capturing the burglary.

According to New York City's official website, from January 1, 2010, through December 19, there have been 18,837 reported robberies in the city - a 5 percent increase through the same point in 2009 - and 17,987 reported burglaries this year, which equates to a 4.1 percent decrease from the same period last year.

fields.heading: Washington man helps put away homicide suspect using home surveillance
fields.content:
By setting up a home surveillance system on a lark, a Washington man helped catch a fugitive homicide suspect, according to KOMO-TV in Seattle.

Tacoma resident Ricky Pruett believed an old friend and co-worker, Robert Tuckson, who is suspected of stabbing a man to death, would visit him at his Washington home.

Pruett told KOMO-TV at 1 a.m. on Tuesday, December 23, Pruett's home cameras alerted him someone walking around his trailer, who turned out to be Tuckson.

According to the report, police, using search dogs, found Tuckson a few hours later, and also questioned him about the unsolved disappearance of his wife five years earlier.

"He needs to get off the streets, because he's going to end up doing it again to someone else," Pruett said in the report. "It was really scary. He was definitely trying to get the door open and he knew we were in here."

According to the Washington Association of Sheriffs & Police Chiefs, there were 244,368 reported property crimes - including burglary, larceny, arson and motor vehicle theft - in 2009, up from 2008's state total of 242,956.

fields.heading: Burglars near Houston targeting vacant, model homes
fields.content:
According to KTRK-TV in Houston, burglars near Pearland, Texas have been targeting homes in the area to steal high-end appliances.

The article states police were tipped by former Pearland resident Jimmy Clapp who moved from his home there six months ago. Clapp left behind a home security camera system which spotted a man entering his now vacant home, according to the report.

Clapp told KTRK-TV the man looked like he was "taking inventory" of what possible expensive possessions Clapp left behind in the house.

Clapp's wife reportedly told him to buy the home security surveillance equipment while living there. "It was her idea to put the cameras in, and it paid off," Clapp told the station.

The Houston Chronicle reported in July Houston's burglary rates jumped 22 percent from 2006 to 2010 with nearly 22,000 victims. The Chronicle added more than 500 houses in the Houston-area were burglarized multiple times in 2009.

The Burglary Prevention Council recommends instituting security measures to prevent burglaries such as creating the illusion of being home when out, securely locking doors and windows and always keeping the home's perimeter well lit.

fields.content:
In order to assure thieves don't lurk around homes in the area, Las Vegas Police are recommending for residents not to leave empty boxes outside their homes, Fox News 5 in Las Vegas reports.

Las Vegas Police are reportedly warning residents to keep broken-down empty boxes in their garage until trash pick-up to avoid attracting possible burglars.

"It's certainly a concern around holidays is anyone putting out trash of large items like [a] big screen TV, or [a] new computer or gaming system," North Las Vegas police spokeswoman Chrissy Coon told the station. "Those are the items that are often times targeted by burglars or vandals at homes."

Coon added that if potential thieves see boxes for Xbox video game systems or TVs then they might be enticed to burglarize the home.

fields.heading: Oregon couple's home surveillance investment pays off
fields.content:
A Eugene, Oregon, couple who recently bought hundreds of dollars worth of home surveillance equipment caught footage of a potential car thief with the help of their new security cameras, according to KEZI News.

The couple told the news outlet they captured footage of a man attempting to break into their vehicles early Christmas Eve morning while the couple, Brad and Kristy Shaddy, was asleep. The man reportedly left after seconds of trying to gain access to the cars.

KEZI reported the Shaddys discovered there was a theft attempt when they looked through the security video the next day. They said they believe the man didn't realize he was being filmed by home security cameras.

Kristy Shaddy gave a message to the almost-thief to the TV station, stating, "You need to know that people are watching you. We may not have caught you this time, but somebody will catch you."

No one living on the same street as the Shaddys was targeted over the weekend.

According to the Eugene Police Department Annual Crime Report for 2009, there were 917 reported car thefts last year, a 31.21 percent drop from 2008's total of 1,333 reported car thefts.

The article states heated outdoor weatherproof cameras ensure a home's surveillance system will work flawlessly and remain unharmed.

Specifically, HomeSecuritySystems.net thinks the best camera for outdoor use is a "swan style weatherproof PTZ" camera, which comes with a heater and fan already attached to the camera, while also allowing for full panning, tilting and zooming.

One of the best qualities a weatherproof surveillance camera has, according to the website, is high resolution and infrared capability to receive the best quality picture.

An article on HomeSecurityInformation.com says the advantage of infrared security cameras is that it enables cameras to capture images in dark areas through the use of infrared light instead of the normal lighting spectrum. fields.heading: Facebook status could lead to home burglaries
fields.content:
Though millions of people worldwide like to update their status on Facebook divulging what they're up to and where they'll be at any given moment, allowing people to know where you are could lead to thievery, Pocket Lint reports.

The website, which specializes in electronics news, claims "an increased risk of burglary is quite possibly a risk you run if you decide to place your whereabouts on social networking services."

Pocket Lint recommends avoiding certain topics when posting on Facebook, including personal information and one's whereabouts and possessions, as well as making sure privacy settings are in place while on the social networking site.

The article states that, due to the holiday season, plenty of people will post where they've left for the holidays, but thinks letting others know such information could hurt them.

WMUR-TV in New Hampshire recently reported an example of Facebook leading to burglary when a Nashua, New Hampshire, man posted on Facebook he was out of his house.

According to the report, police arrested three men attempting to rob the home. WMUR states the burglars discovered the home's resident would be away due to Facebook.

The burglaries are substantially more than the average for any month of the year, San Mateo County Sheriff’s Sergeant Linda Gibbons told the newspaper, stating there are usually only one or two each month.

"Generally there is an escalation of property crimes in the month of December, but it’s not like they were taking Christmas presents or anything," Gibbons told the paper.

The sheriff's office told the Review the majority of the break-ins show the burglars entered the residences through back doors, many of which were reportedly unlocked at their time of entry.

One home burglarized in Moss Beach reportedly had $2,530 worth of jewelry and portable computers stolen.

The man caught on footage reportedly knocked on the resident's door, and when he heard no answer, attempted to enter the home assuming the homeowner wasn't present.

According to KTXL, the Sacramento Police Department believes there are at least two suspected thieves in the area who have been knocking on doors, though they are unsure if the two are working together or separately.

The Hudson Dockett Housing project residents were given the security system by the police department, according to the report, due to the high volume of crime occurring at the complex recently, including a gunmen opening fire on the homes last year.

Cheryl Effinger, the homeowner, told the station she had turned off her home alarm system the day she was robbed, stating she felt safe without it on because she lives near several police officers.

Louisville Metro Police are reportedly still investigating the theft and told Effinger to add more security features to her home.

The LMPD recommends securing all locks on all entrances to a home every day, assuring their structural integrity is strong, as well as installing a home security system. fields.heading: Tips for post-holiday home security
fields.content:
CIO Magazine offers some advice to homeowners to better protect their homes now that the gift-giving holiday season has come to a close.

The magazine states some burglars scope out trash pick-up at many homes to see what kind of expensive products were bought for the holidays. According to the article, many thieves simply knock on doors to see if anyone is present at many homes, or they will simply walk in the back, knowing people are at work.

CIO states some of the top priorities for homeowners to keep their house safe include updating the inventory count for the home, and tearing up boxes of merchandise purchased for the holidays and disposing of those boxes properly.

Many homes leave their shades open all day, even when absent, the magazine states. By closing the shades, potential burglars don't have a line of sight into the home to check for expensive belongings. Home security systems, such as ones made by Protect America, can help deter break-ins, too.

The Washington, D.C. Metropolitan Police Department states homeowners should break-down boxes of expensive holiday gifts, adding, "Burglars know that many households have new, and oftentimes expensive, items in their homes" after the holidays.

fields.heading: Securing a vacant home can help get unoccupied home insurance
fields.content:
HomeownersInsurance.net states it is very difficult, but still possible, for homeowners with vacant properties to acquire unoccupied home insurance.

The website states many insurers will not protect homeowners for homes which have been empty for 30 days or longer due to the increased prospect of vandalism, theft or even squatters at the home. However, by following through with a few key steps, the insurance is still possible to obtain.

One important thing to do, according to the website, is to make the home look occupied, stating there's less of a chance of intruders entering the home if they believe people live there. Also, by keeping the heating and water pressure on low, the chance of freezing, and risk of damage, is reduced, in turn making the home more appealing for companies to insure.

The site states that by having inspectors check out the home on a regular basis and securing all valuables in the home, with protection likes locks and home alarm systems, insurers will feel more comfortable lending out coverage.

fields.content:

Away from his home more than 100 nights per year, Jerry Quintiliani Jr, a regional accounts manager in Illinois, has never had a break-in while away, but always tells police he's leaving so they can monitor his house while gone. He also stops his mail and newspaper delivery while traveling.

Richard Kuethe, who lives in Texas and is gone from his house often, uses four motion-activated security cameras around his home that he monitors online, as well as a safe and locked file cabinets to secure his valuables.

fields.heading: Texas city offering free home security inspections to help lower insurance premiums
fields.content:
According to KFOX-TV, El Paso, Texas, police officers are offering residents a free home security inspection to help lower their insurance premiums by as much as 20 percent.

Officer Curtis Whitener told the news station there are certain things officers will look for in a home while performing an inspection to better protect residents from a home invasion and burglary. He told the station the typical burglar is in and out of a home within about seven minutes, so making sure one's home has a home security system and a secure infrastructure is important.

However, the home security inspections won't guarantee complete protection for a home from a burglar, Whitener told the station, but the police department's recommendations could deter thieves from entering the home.

"We're going to offer some suggestions with psychological barriers, with physical barriers," Whitener told the station, adding homeowners should "get some kind of discount on [their] homeowner's insurance" after the inspection.

The International Association of Certified Home Inspectors says adding a sprinkler system and a fire and burglar alarm system to a home can lower home insurance costs up to 15 to 20 percent.

Authorities told the paper the suspect fled the crime scene when police arrived and immediately ran off, prompting two officers to give chase. The newspaper states the suspect was caught several homes away from the scene of the theft.

"We did composite pictures of the two men in the photos, put them out, and witnesses began to come in," Crump told the Republic.

The elderly couples robbed, who live less than two miles from one another, were reportedly each tied up in their homes while the suspects stole from them. One of the couples died shortly after the home invasion due to complications from strokes each suffered during the incident.

fields.heading: Investigate property to identify safety needs

According to the source, by going to trade shows or stopping by a local home improvement store to ask experts questions about home safety, it will be easy to spot the different areas in which a home lacks security.

Some of the things to inquire of home safety experts include what kind of door and window locks a home should have, as well as the best light bulbs to use when lighting a property at night.

Salem police officer Mark Jantz told the newspaper a method called "CPTED," or "crime prevention through environmental design," is a helpful method when safeguarding a home. The National Crime Prevention Council states the "CPTED" method is an effective home-protection system, and that it is based on four principles - "natural access control, natural surveillance, territoriality and maintenance."

fields.heading: Steps to protect a home from fire
fields.content:
The ARA has listed several ways to prevent fires from occurring in homes, involving easy precautions homeowners can take to ensure their home's complete safety.

First, the source says to check all smoke detectors to make sure their batteries are fresh and that they are working properly. Having at least one detector on every floor of a home is a must, the source states. The ARA says water sprinklers are worth the investment, too.

Knowing who to contact in the case of an emergency is vital, so the organization recommends creating a list of fire, police and medical contact information. Programming their numbers into a cell phone should help considerably during an emergency.

Tree branches and bushes which are too close to a building's entrances and windows should be trimmed, the source says, and flammable liquids should be kept in proper storing.

Finally, the source says to devise an escape plan with the entire family to make sure everyone in a household knows the protocol for emergencies.

In the other case, a burglar forced entry into 13 Manhattan apartments, and stole thousands in wallets and electronics.

Manhattan renters may want to install home alarm systems as soon as possible. The New York City Police Department states there were 18,604 burglaries in the city last year.

fields.heading: D.C. package thief shown on home security camera
fields.content:
After looking at home security camera footage showing a man stealing a package from his front door, Washington, D.C., resident Adam Harper told Fox News he felt violated. However, only a few days after the incident, Harper helped put the thief behind bars.

While in his apartment, Harper reportedly noticed the criminal walking by his front door again - this time, with someone else's package. According to the report, Harper walked around the corner to keep an eye on the burglar and called police, who responded immediately.

He told the station the suspect seemed hesitant about grabbing the package from his home. "The video is of him walking in front of the house, looking over, seeing the package. Debating if he should go get it, looking around, coming into the gate. Going down the stairs, looking around, then leaving with the package," Harper told the source.

Harper also told the source he is glad another criminal is off the streets.

In January, the Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported burglars were arrested for stealing boxes from front porches in Gwinnett County, Georgia.
fields.summary: After looking at home security camera footage showing a man stealing a package from his front door, Washington, D.C., resident ...

fields.heading: Multiple burglary victim installs cameras, uses Facebook to catch suspects
fields.content:
The Enterprise Ledger in Alabama reports a homeowner purchased home security cameras after her house was robbed twice in two months.

Reportedly, the victim caught footage of another person breaking into her home for a third time, though it's unknown if this suspect previously burglarized the house, and posted photos from the surveillance on her Facebook page.

"I purchased a camera security system to help catch whoever was doing this," Donna Crooks, the victim, told the paper. "One man got out of the car, came on the porch and turned the camera around. He didn't suspect that I had cameras all in the house, too."

Crooks told the source that if she posted photos of the burglar and his vehicle on Facebook, someone might recognize him and would provide information to lead to his arrest. According to the paper, though, no suspect has been captured by authorities yet.

Facebook helped lead to the capture of a home and vehicle burglar in Oklahoma last August, KOCO-TV reports. Security cameras belonging to a neighbor of the victim reportedly caught video of the suspect and his car. To identify the criminal, the victim helped police by searching the vehicle owner's name on Facebook, which led to a woman engaged to the suspect.

According to the station, police used the information to catch the suspect.
fields.summary: The Enterprise Ledger in Alabama reports a homeowner purchased home security cameras after her house was robbed twice in two ...

fields.heading: Suspect stole $100,000 in jewelry from South Carolina home
fields.content:
WCSC-TV in South Carolina reports a thief stole $100,000 worth of jewelry from a Kiawah Island home.

Police reportedly responded to a home alarm system the suspect set off, but the burglar was already gone. However, police discovered several traces of evidence, including a small plastic bag containing some jewelry which the burglar left behind.

According to the station, an unlocked residence was broken into shortly after the first burglary. The second home was reportedly burglarized of a $125,000 necklace and $7,000 watch. The station reports authorities are still investigating the crimes.

Despite the fact the suspect made off with the jewelry, another South Carolina home burglary was solved by police. The Sun News reports two men from Conway broke into a home in the city.

Also, police in Evansville caught a serial burglar in January who had eluded police since November, the Courier Press reports. Police officer Doug Daza told the paper the stolen items recovered from the suspect is "one of the larger amounts of items that we've been able to recover" during his time on the police force.

fields.heading: New Jersey family victims of home invasion
fields.content:
A family in Bergenfield, New Jersey had their home invaded by three masked suspects who stole cash and jewelry, reports the Twin-Boro News.

According to the website, police responded to a 911 call from the home immediately following the invasion. The victims reportedly told authorities there were three men who robbed them at gunpoint, while one man stayed with a suspected getaway car.

Though the criminals got away with the crime, a neighbor's security camera reportedly captured video of the men leaving the residence.

In Vineland, New Jersey, another home burglary in which suspects used guns and wore masks during the crime was reported - and three of the suspects involved were arrested, the Courier Post reports. According to the paper, the burglars in this case also used a getaway driver.

The FBI's Uniform Crime Report for the first six months of 2010 show the most property crimes in New Jersey took place in Newark, where there were 3,872. This figure was down from the same period in 2009, when there were 4,269 property crimes reported.
fields.summary: A family in Bergenfield, New Jersey had their home invaded by three masked suspects who stole cash and jewelry, reports the ...

fields.heading: Burglar sneaks into Florida house while homeowner present
fields.content:
While a homeowner was watching TV, a burglar reportedly snuck in through the back door and stole the owner's purse. However, a security camera caught the act and police are currently searching for the suspect spotted on the video.

Evelyn Pignataro, the 61-year-old victim, was only a few feet away from the suspect when the burglary was committed. The surveillance footage shows a man entering Pignataro's backyard, opening her back door and stealing the purse within a matter of minutes.

Broward Sheriff's Office spokesperson Veda Coleman-Wright told WSVN-TV, "That is very scary when you think about it, because if there's any place that we are going to feel safe, it's going to be in our homes."

Howie Worley, a neighbor of the victim, told the station he was surprised how bold the criminal was for stealing from someone who's home. "Somebody can walk up and burglarize someone's home like that, scares me to death," he told the source.

Another older Florida homeowner was the victim of a violent home invasion. Reportedly, three young men forced their way into the home of a 72-year-old Pensacola resident and beat him.
fields.summary: While a homeowner was watching TV, a burglar reportedly snuck in through the back door and stole the owner's purse. ...

fields.heading: Charlotte home thief caught on camera
fields.content:
After returning to her Charlotte apartment from work only to find she had been robbed, resident Mary Mac Stallings told WBTV she was "mortified." However, she may get her belongings back with the help of a cash reward and a neighbor's security camera, which recorded the burglars in her home.

The security footage reportedly shows two men removing a window screen from Stallings' home and tearing apart her furniture and possessions for nearly 30 minutes. Other than wanting her belongings back for financial reasons, the victim told the station things like her computer and camera, which were stolen, have sentimental value to her. Stallings' boss is offering $500 for the return of her items.

WSOC-TV states burglaries in Charlotte have lessened by 50 percent in January from December's totals. Charlotte police officer Bob Cooke told the news station police in the city increased their efforts to deter home thefts after too many in December.

"I think it's significant, because if nothing else, the quality of life has been improved," he told the station.
fields.summary: After returning to her Charlotte apartment from work only to find she had been robbed, resident Mary Mac Stallings told WBTV ...

fields.heading: Sacramento police attempt to ID criminal caught on home camera
fields.content:
When a burglar alarm system went off at a Sacramento, California, residence, police arrived to find the suspected thief gone, but discovered the homeowner caught the incident on video surveillance.

Security camera footage of the would-be criminal reportedly shows a man entering the homeowner's backyard, as he approaches the back door. He then tried to open a window, when the home's alarm system activated, and he immediately fled the scene.

Police released photos and video of the man, as well as his vehicle, in an attempt to get help identifying him. Police told the Sacramento Bee that, in all likelihood, the suspect made off with nothing from the house. A neighbor told ABC News that another home in the neighborhood was robbed by a burglar who entered the residence from the back.

Although the suspect is still on the loose, the amount of burglaries in the city has decreased. According to the Sacramento Police Department, burglaries were down 2.6 percent in December from the same month a year earlier.

fields.heading: Chicago police report crime low to begin 2011
fields.content:
According to a report from the Chicago Police Department, overall crime in the city is down to start the new year, with property crime dipping 10.7 percent and violent crime falling 10.2 percent.

Reportedly, January marks the 25th consecutive month in which overall crime decreased in the city.

Despite most offenses dropping in the city during January, the report shows homicides were up 27.3 percent from December. Police superintendent Jody Weis said in the report the police department "will not rest until the figures for violent crime and homicides are closer to the only acceptable number - zero."

The report states 72 percent of homicides came from the use of guns. Police officers have reportedly confiscated more than 560 firearms since the beginning of the year.

Though murders were up in the month, all other violent crimes dipped by double-digits, and most property crimes decreased, as well. The only property crime to rise during the month was motor vehicle theft, which hiked 21.8 percent from December.

fields.heading: Two burglars suspected of multiple thefts arrested in California
fields.content:
The Merced Sun-Star reports two teenage suspects are in custody for the burglary of a Merced residence, and have now been linked to other home thefts in the area.

After responding to a call stemming from a home alarm system activating at the home, police rushed to the scene and discovered the two suspects had broken into the back of the property, the paper states.

According to the newspaper, once apprehended, the two men admitted to working together on other home burglaries in and around Merced. Police told the news source some of the stolen property has been returned to their owners.

Though the two teenagers admitted they were responsible for several home burglaries, another teen burglar in Washington stole from 28 homes, KOMO-TV reports. Nineteen-year-old Emily Orona was reportedly sentenced to six years in prison for robbing homes in the state of thousands of dollars worth of jewelry.

Scott Hill, one of the victims who testified against Orona, told the station his children still ask if they're safe, even with a home alarm system.

fields.heading: Left behind cell phone helps put D.C.-area home burglar behind bars
fields.content:
Though it's usually technology such as home security cameras and burglar systems that catch home thieves, a burglar who allegedly robbed homes in the Washington, D.C., area was caught with the aid of a cell phone - his own cell phone.

Reportedly, Cody Wilkins was caught by authorities after he left his cell phone charging in an outlet at the home he recently robbed. By calling around on the phone, police were able to determine Wilkins' identity and locate his address. The Washington Post reports he is now being charged with 10 burglaries in Montgomery County.

According to the paper, the son of the homeowner who Wilkins stole from arrived just as the thief was leaving the residence. After unsuccessfully giving chase to Wilkins, the man returned to the home and found the piece of evidence that would help land the criminal in jail.

While Wilkins' crime could be considered foolish and thoughtless, he is not the only criminal to suffer from carelessness. WILX-TV in Michigan reports a suspected thief and drunk driver crashed a rental car in Royal Oaks, called 911 to report the incident and then called a cab to take him home. The station says police called the person the "dumbest" criminal they had ever encountered.

fields.heading: Mississippi city attempts to rid itself of criminals
fields.content:
In an effort to revitalize the community and deter criminal activity, Gautier, Mississippi, mayor Tommy Fortenberry is inviting citizens of the city to a town hall meeting to restart a Neighborhood Watch program, reports WLOX-TV.

The news of the meeting comes days after a 58-year-old woman was tied up in her Gautier home and robbed. Reportedly, Fortenberry told the station that once a city police officer completes a training course to teach crime prevention to city residents, the watch program will begin.

Resident Walter Hammond, whose home has been robbed twice in the last three years, told the station he's doing what he can to protect his home from thieves. "We're having an alarm system installed, me and my wife," Hammond told the source. "We've been talking about it. ... At first we thought we probably didn't need it but now I think we better go on and get it."

Gautier police chief Eddie Williams told the Mississippi Press that the Neighborhood Watch program fell apart in the city shortly after Hurricane Katrina.

fields.heading: Chicago man discovers shovel theft caught on tape
fields.content:
After realizing someone had stolen his shovel from his yard by a neighbor, Chicago resident David Welles decided to exact some revenge on the thief with some help from his snowblower.

Reportedly, Welles posted a video on YouTube showing him using his snowblower to bury the shovel burglar's vehicle in snow. In addition to displaying Welles' burial of his neighbor's car, the security camera footage also shows the neighbor cleaning off her automobile for four hours.

"I got a little, I guess, passive-aggressive," Welles told WGN-TV. "I got a new snowblower, so I was kind of excited to bury her car. It felt good, I'm not going to lie to you." Welles told the station he was upset at the theft mostly because his 2-year-old daughter was going to finish building an igloo with the shovel before it was taken.

While no person was injured during this incident, another Chicago resident reportedly had his snowblower stolen from him when a suspect shot him. Fox News in Chicago reports the 47-year-old resident was assaulted by two men, who stole the snowblower and cash from the man.

fields.heading: GPS tracking helps lock up New York car thief
fields.content:
After threatening fellow employees and customers, a medical transport company worker in New York reportedly stole one of the business' vans. Little did the robber know, however, the vehicle was armed with a GPS tracking device.

The New York District Court charged Kevin Cheeks with theft after he stole a van from his employer, Sigma Transportation, in December 2009. According to reports, Cheeks pretended to have a gun to force his co-workers and customers to the back of the company's store, stole $300 from the cash register and took off in the van.

Despite what he may have thought was an easy getaway, authorities tracked the suspect to a nearby salon with the aid of a GPS tracking device the company installed in the car. Also, the New York Post states the company's security cameras caught footage of Cheeks stealing the van.

"The defendant will have a long time behind bars to ponder how a simple GPS vehicle-tracking device and a few mouse clicks led to his arrest and conviction," district attorney Richard Brown told the newspaper.

Many companies in the U.S. have begun using GPS tracking to monitor company vehicles, as well as their employees. According to KCRG-TV in Iowa, a Wellman city worker was fired when city officials discovered through monitoring the employee's GPS-enabled vehicle that he wasn't working.

fields.heading: Georgia authorities catch home invaders with help from burglar alarm
fields.content:
Three masked intruders broke into an Ashburn, Georgia, home, robbing two female residents, WALB News reports. However, the homeowners set off their burglar alarm once the suspects left the residence, and police later apprehended them.

Victim Nettie Walker told the news station the she and her mother were forced onto the ground by the men and threatened with a knife. She told the source, "I started praying. I said he was going to kill me. So I started praying for him and me and everybody else."

According to the report, Walker immediately set the home security alarm off after the burglars fled the scene, and police caught the suspects at a traffic light near the residence and were able to link them to another home invasion in the area.

Police in Albany, Georgia, were also reportedly able to arrest burglars suspected in a ring of home thefts. An investigation by the Albany Police police department led to a warrant to search homes of six suspected thieves who allegedly robbed several homes in the area.

fields.heading: Surveillance video helps arrest serial burglars in Nevada
fields.content:
With the help of a victim's description of three Nevada home burglars, as well as footage from security cameras which captured the suspects' vehicle, Henderson Police in Nevada were reportedly able to arrest the thieves.

Authorities told sources that the criminals are the main suspects in a crime ring in the area, and one of the burglars has admitted to committing the robberies and home invasions, while implicating the other two suspects. After obtaining a search warrant for one of the suspects' homes, reports say police found jewelry, clothing, televisions, firearms and marijuana.

The victim who aided authorities in the capture of the criminals told the Las Vegas Sun he arrived home to find two of the suspects in his house, claiming they were "just cleaning" and proceeded to leave the home through a broken window.

According to a report, crime in the Las Vegas area has become a problem, as the city ranks eighth on CQ Press' 2010 Metropolitan Crime Rate Rankings.

fields.heading: Security camera in Florida catches attack by sexual predator
fields.content:
A 12-year-old girl in Bradenton, Florida, was assaulted while walking home from school by a suspected sexual predator, though she was able to thwart the attacker with some quick thinking.

Reportedly, while the suspect was trying to sexually assault the young girl, she told him she knew she was being watched, which led the suspect to abandon the attack and run - but not before being caught on surveillance.

A resident's security camera captured footage of the suspect, and police are reportedly using the video to help find and arrest the predator. The resident told WTSP-TV in Tampa Bay he installed nine surveillance cameras around his home in 2004 for extra security, and hopes police apprehend the suspect soon, stating there are a number of children attending schools nearby.

According to reports, this attack isn't the only one in the area recently. There were separate incidents in November and January, when two 15-year-old girls were accosted by predators - one managed to get away from the suspect, while the other was sexually assaulted.

fields.heading: Mississippi city residents blame crime for population decrease
fields.content:
Home alarm systems may become more prevalent in Jackson, Mississippi. According to WAPT-TV, residents in the city are upset with the fall in population over the last decade, and believe the city's increasing crime rate is an important factor in the decline.

Reportedly, many residents blame racism, high taxes and a growing crime rate for people moving out of the city. Jackson Police Department Assistant Chief Lee Vance told the news station he thinks the city can do better to protects its citizens.

"That means law enforcement, that means the courts, that means corrections, [and] that also means the public, because we could have very little success if we didn't have participation from the public," Vance told the news station.

Police told the station that while crime was up in 2010, this year, homicide, armed robberies and business burglaries are down.

According to the FBI's Uniform Crime Report, nearly 300 more burglaries were committed in the first half of 2010 compared with the same period one year earlier.

fields.heading: Burglary rate in Illinois city rose considerably in 2010
fields.content:
A crime report for Moline, Illinois, shows burglaries in the city jumped 25 percent last year, marking the largest increase in the Quad City region.

According to the report, the increase in home thefts increased substantially between September and December, when the number of burglaries nearly doubled from the same period one year earlier.

The Dispatch in Illinois reports detectives are looking into the increase in gang activity as a possible reason for the spike in city crime. Police told the paper most of the items reported stolen include electronics such as DVD and Blu Ray players, gaming systems and computers - most of which is resold on the streets.

Police Chief Kim Hankins said the city will do its best to combat burglaries, but residents should be mindful of the level of crime in their area.

"We can go out and do our checks, drive through neighborhoods and things like that, but the number of incidents is really dependent on if you have a criminal element move into your area and they begin to use burglaries as a means to survive," he told the news source.

fields.heading: Woman charged for breaking into actresses' home
fields.content:
The California home of comedienne Ellen DeGeneres and actress Portia de Rossi was invaded by a 49-year-old woman, who was arrested with the help of the residence's home security system.

Reportedly, Karen Grace Sjoden has been charged with trespassing at the property of the daytime talk show host and TV actress, who weren't home at the time of the incident. In addition to the home alarm system, the couple reportedly also has a 24-hour security team around the home.

According to reports, the intruder was carrying a list of other celebrities' names and addresses when apprehended by authorities.

Home invasions are nothing new for many celebrities. Earlier in February, singer Moby discovered a home intruder at his Los Angeles home, who entered through an unlocked door. The artist wrote on his official website that he has decided to increase the security at his home.

And in January, actor Orland Bloom recently put his home up for rent after the property was burglarized in 2009. Serial burglars reportedly stole from his home, as well as the residences of other celebrities, such as Lindsay Lohan, Rachel Bilson and Paris Hilton.

fields.heading: Indianapolis home invasion caught on camera
fields.content:
Suspecting that someone would try to break into his home last year, Indianapolis resident Kenny Smith installed home security cameras. After learning his home was robbed while away, perhaps now he will install a full home security system.

WTHR-TV reports multiple suspects broke into Smith's residence, where they took many of his tools from his garage, as well as a motorcycle, which can be seen being loaded onto a pickup truck on the security footage.

Smith told the news station that while the criminals may have gotten away, he's glad to have installed the security cameras.

He told the source, "I just looked at it as if somebody did break in" last year when he setup the camera system - that way, he "would have some kind of evidence." He also told the station he thinks the criminals have been casing his house for some time, waiting for him to leave so they could rob the home.

While these burglars escaped authorities, other thieves in the area were recently brought to justice. According to WLWT-TV, Indiana authorities captured burglars accused of stealing from, and setting fire to, homes in the southeastern part of the state.

fields.heading: Dog walker robs former employer's home using burglar alarm code
fields.content:
A recent burglary in Illinois could lead many homeowners with burglar alarms to be more careful who they share the security system's codes with. In Riverside, a dog walker reportedly stole from the residence of her former employer after using a house key and entering the alarm deactivation code.

Riverside police chief Tom Weitzel told news sources that the 35-year-old woman charged with the burglary admitted to remembering how to access the home's security system, along with stealing $150, DVDs and an iPod.

According to reports, the suspect was fired from her job as dog walker when the family reported items missing from the home. Weitzel also stated the former dog walker was following the homeowner's new dog walker to find the appropriate time to break in.

The home theft isn't the only case of a residential employee committing a crime. In New York, a woman employed as a nanny was caught on security cameras giving a baby antihistamine for adults. Reportedly, the woman was charged for endangering the welfare of a child and assault.

fields.heading: St. Louis most dangerous city, report says
fields.content:
St. Louis residents should invest in home security systems, according to a report by Onboard Informatics. Based on 2010 crime statistics released earlier this year by the FBI, the study says the city is the most dangerous in the U.S.

According to the report, published in U.S. News and World Report, St. Louis' crime risk index is 530 - 46 points ahead of the next most dangerous city, Atlanta. The index was created using a compilation of violent and property crimes in every city in the U.S. in the last 7 years.

Kansas City, another Missouri city, is ninth on the index with a crime risk rating of 337. Two cities tied for third place on the list, Birmingham and Orlando, each designated a rating of 380.

"Property crime is far more prevalent than violent crime in all of these cities, as with the rest of the nation, and nearly all of these 11 cities [in the report] have also experienced significant drops in property crime in recent years," the news source states.

fields.heading: Pennsylvania community warned about rash of burglaries
fields.content:
Residents of Northampton Township, Pennsylvania, were warned by officials of an uptick in recent business and home burglaries, ABC News in Philadelphia reports.

Local business owner Vinny Pagano told the station thieves broke into his lawn mower store, and that an auto supply store next to his was robbed later the same day. Detective John Gross of the Northampton Police Department told the source authorities believe it's the same criminals burglarizing town residents and companies.

As police continue to investigate the break-ins and thefts, they reportedly told every home and business in town to turn on their burglar alarms and keep a close eye out for suspicious activity.

"This way, it gives the police a head start down there to find out what's going on," detective George Kelly told the news source. "You have it, you paid for it, put it on."

In another part of the state, officials captured seven suspects who have been charged with burglary. Gant Daily reports Harrisburg authorities caught the criminals after a lengthy investigation. Reportedly, the thieves stole more than $200,000 in at least 10 burglaries last year.

fields.heading: Home security camera records Florida thief in action
fields.content:
In the early morning hours, a Florida burglar was reportedly caught on security camera breaking into two dozen cars by smashing windows and picking locks.

The thefts occurred in one Tarpon Springs neighborhood, according to reports. One of the victims' security camera captured video of the criminal breaking into a vehicle. Despite the footage, the criminal was able to evade police.

Kim Poucher, one of the residents whose vehicle was broken into, told WTSP-TV a GPS system and radio were stolen from her car. She added that many residents in the neighborhood are doing what they can to help authorities track down the suspect, including keeping all porch lights on throughout the night.

While the suspect in these recorded thefts only stole items from the vehicles, security cameras recorded an actual car theft in Colorado. Reportedly, a couple who left their car running in their driveway unattended while in their home for a few minutes was shocked to find the vehicle was stolen when they returned.

The footage from a neighbor's security camera reportedly showed the suspect getting out of a minivan hopped in the car and took off only moments after the couple went inside their house.

fields.heading: Security cameras at governor's mansion in Texas may help arson investigation
fields.content:
Though arsonists burned down part of the governor's mansion in Austin, Texas, in 2008 - and got away with it - authorities told sources that security camera footage from the night of the incident could help investigators catch the criminals responsible.

According to NBC News in Texas, the security footage shows the suspect running toward the 152-year-old mansion and throwing a Molotov cocktail, instantly setting the house on fire. Also, the footage show people in a white Jeep pull up to the mansion four days prior to the fire, taking photos.

Police reportedly found the owner of the vehicle, and were able to ascertain the identities of members in the car at the time. None of them have been arrested, but they remain persons of interest in the ongoing investigation.

Officials told the station they don't believe any harm was intended to Texas Governor Rick Perry, who was actually living in another residence at the time while renovations were conducted at the mansion.

The governor's mansion in Texas is the oldest existing building still in use west of the Mississippi River, and has been designated a National Historic Landmark.

fields.heading: Burglar alarm leads Arizona authorities to suspect
fields.content:

Reportedly, when the Navajo County Sheriff's Office responded to the alarm, they discovered broken windows and heard a disturbance coming from a trailer in front of the residence, which turned out to be the suspected home invader.

"Because the same person to steal a car and rob somebody at gunpoint is the same guy who gets drunk and gets into a fight with his roommate," McElroy said. "Criminals are not specialists." He added that the city has established an example of how to reduce crime in a major city.

"I look at the crime statistics every week, and it seems to have calmed down a little in parts of the island," James Island Mayor Bill Woolsey told the paper. "But we have to stay vigilant."

Anna Fludd, a Honey Hill community organizer, told the newspaper many residents have been encouraged to purchase burglar alarms, which she states have been effective crime deterrents.

"It is a crime of opportunity," Long Beach Township lieutenant Anthony Deely told the paper. "We see copper theft in the winter year after year, and each year we try to educate the public to be on the lookout for anything suspicious."

One vacation home, according to the paper, has a home alarm system installed, which went off during what police believe was an attempted burglary. "Nothing deters a criminal like an observant neighbor - looking out the front window at every slow moving vehicle, recording license plate numbers and actually picking up the telephone to call police about suspicious vehicles," Williams told the paper.

Another member of the HPD, police chief Skip Holbrook, told the news station that getting drugs off the street is typically an effective way to reduce crime.

Boston Police Department superintendent-in-chief Daniel Linskey told the paper the bad economy is likely one major reason for the increase in home thefts. However, he added that residents should do their part to deter home invasions by installing security systems.

"Even if [a home burglary] gets reported to us and we find that property down the road, we can never prove who it belongs to because we can't prove it's stolen property," Linskey told the newspaper. "That's one of the challenges."

fields.heading: Security camera records Louisiana home intruder
fields.content:
After she suspected someone had broken into her home, Shreveport, Louisiana, resident Heather Cagle set up a security camera outside of her home at the suggestion of her uncle. A few days later, she told KSLA-TV she's glad she listened to him, as the camera was able to capture footage of a home invader.

According to the report, the footage shows a man walking around Cagle's home, which she moved into at the start of the year, rummaging through her valuables.

"It was really gut wrenching to see him walking around in my house, with my things, with my dog," Cagle told the news station. "I definitely feel a whole lot safer, I had my uncle come over and he changed the locks, and every window is shut tight."

Police told the station some money and a camera were stolen from Cagle's home.

Other Shreveport residences have been victims of home burglaries this year, according to KTBS-TV. The station reports two men are wanted by police after invading a home, threatening the homeowner with a knife and robbing her.
