fields.heading: Security camera footage reveals violent home invasion in Detroit
fields.content:
Nearly four months after two men forced their way into a Detroit home, shooting and terrorizing the residents, the victims hope to help authorities catch the suspects by posting video surveillance images captured during the incident around the city, reports Fox News in Detroit.

One of the victims told the station she was shot twice by the home invaders, who she states only held her and her family hostage and didn't steal anything.

"All I could think was he was gonna kill my family. I'd rather die than have a bullet go through my sister, then my daughter and then my grandkids," the victim told the news station.

The victims had a home security camera in their front yard which shows the men coming into and leaving the residence, which is now in the hands of the Detroit Police Department, according to the station.

A Detroit police officer was also reportedly the victim of a home invasion after responding to a call. The officer kicked in the front door of a city residence and was immediately shot by the intruder, who was apprehended and is now standing trial.

fields.heading: Home protection encouraged as Las Vegas property crimes up
fields.content:
As more homes become empty in metro Las Vegas, home thefts continue to rise, according to the Las Vegas Sun, and police and residents are working to reduce the crime.

The newspaper reports poor economic conditions, including a substantial jump in unemployment, may be a contributing factor to the increase in burglaries of both vacant and occupied homes in the region.

"People who commit property crimes and break into houses … they rely on operating where there are no witnesses. They feel comfortable operating where nobody's watching or they feel nobody's watching," Christopher Jones, metro captain for the city's Northwest Area Command, told the paper.

Jones and Kathy Perkins, a crime prevention specialist with the NAC, told the paper that neighbors should be vigilant of criminal behavior to deter crime, and should implement home protection measures.

KLAS-TV reports some Las Vegas residents are concerned about the rise in property crimes after an apartment shooting in the downtown part of the city. The property manager of the apartment told the station burglaries and robberies are also an issue in the city.

Though the suspects ran from the home after the burglar alarm went off, authorities were able to catch them shortly after.

Butler County Sheriff’s officer Jeff Riegert told the Cincinnati Enquirer the burglary tandem is an unusual one. "It's not uncommon to have a male-and-female team doing burglaries, but to have two females working together is somewhat out-of-the-ordinary," he told the paper.

The Middletown Journal reports the two women were likely robbing homes to help fund their drug addiction. According to the paper, police found heroin on the women.

"These people are pretty brave," Rock County Sheriff's captain Todd Christiansen told the news source. "In four of the eight cases, someone was home and either heard [the suspects] talking or heard them breaking in. Some of them actually got into the house before they were scared off."

Police told WIFR-TV the majority of the burglaries have taken place during night hours while the owners were home.

fields.heading: Home protection measures suggested by Phoenix police as weather warms
fields.content:
As temperatures start to rise in many parts of the country this spring, so might criminal activity. The Arizona Republic reports the Phoenix Police Department is warning residents to keep an eye out for suspicious people in their neighborhoods, as well as implement various home protection plans.

"When we experience the type of weather we have now, people tend to leave windows and doors open," Phoenix police officer Steve Martos told the newspaper. "At times, residents will forget to lock or close their windows and doors. This targets them as a victim. We would encourage people to always ensure their windows and doors are locked."

Police officials told the paper that an email was sent to residents in nearby Arcadia after a string of home burglaries caused concern among homeowners there.

While home invasions and car thefts have yet to spike in Phoenix, Martos told the paper residents should be mindful of criminal behavior.

One home invasion in Phoenix could have been more violent than it was, according to ABC News in Phoenix. The news station reports two armed men burglarized a house while five residents were home and got away.

Police chief James Batelli told the newspaper, "They are planned out and well-thought-out burglaries," adding that these thieves are not "common criminals."

Batelli told ABC News in New York that though many of the burglarized homes have burglar alarms, some residents left their windows and doors unlocked.

fields.content:
After a violent home invasion in Stamford, Connecticut, in which a 23-year-old was beaten, local authorities have increased the presence of police patrols in the neighborhood to help with home protection, reports the Connecticut Post.

According to the paper, the victim was in his home and heard a noise come from upstairs. Once upstairs, a masked intruder beat the resident with a club, prompting family members, neighbors, community residents and police to question home safety in the city.

"We certainly feel very safe in this district and this certainly upsets your sense of tranquility," city representative Ralph Loglisci told the newspaper. Police Chief Robert Nivakoff told the paper he is concerned, as the neighborhood where the burglary took place is typically calm.

The suspect stole more than $3,700 in electronics, the station says, and police believe the home was the only one targeted.

While Stamford police look for the culprit of this home invasion, the department was able to catch other thieves, reports say, as well as the items they stole. fields.heading: Management strategies by Missouri police help reduce crime
fields.content:
While recommending local residents do their part by installing home security systems and implementing other home protection measures, the Independence Police Department in Independence, Missouri, has reorganized its use of manpower to help cut down on crime in the city, according to Fox News in Kansas City.

Neighborhood leader Donna Pittman told the news station that since the police have put more effort in managing how they use police officers throughout the city, crime has been noticeably down.

"Most of the time, the [police] response time is fairly good," Pittman told the station. "I would like to see it be better, but again, I don't [think] they can help it because there is such a shortage and these officers literally run from one call to another and really have minimal if no time to be proactive in the community, which is something I think the community would really like to see."

She added residents are becoming more conscious in protecting their neighbors by keeping vigilant for crime.

One crime that Independence police and residents were unable to prevent, though, was a home burglary, NBC News in Missouri states. The station reports a 5-year-old girl was abducted after her home was robbed, though she was later found safe after being dropped off at a nearby house.

fields.content:

"I don't have any peace about my home after this happened, I'm finally getting to where I can sleep again at night," Goins told the news station.

Along with the burglary at the Goins' residence, numerous other homes have been victims of home break-ins this year, according to the station.

Officer Jason Selzer, of the Cape Girardeau Police Department, told the news station police recommend using several home protection methods to secure residences from possible home intrusions and robberies.

Selzer told the station some of the most vital steps homeowners can take to secure their homes include leaving lights on outside, knowing and communicating with neighbors, installing a burglar alarm and investing in a safe.

One incident involved a mother walking along the street with her two young sons. The station says a security camera recorded video of a car turning a tight corner at a high speed and hitting a light post near them.

fields.content:

"They seem to like to break in during the day while I'm at work," White told the news station. "I just think that people who do this type of thing prey on other people that work for a living and pay their bills, they're cowards." She added that up until February, she thought her neighborhood was safe.

According to the news station, thieves attempted to break into White's home after she installed the home security system and security cameras, but once the suspects saw the surveillance and home protection measures, they bolted from the scene.

Video footage from the security cameras shows two of the suspects' faces, White told the station.

Columbus police, while still looking for the burglars who hit White's residence, have arrested six people connected with a string of home break-ins in which thousands of dollars worth of electronics and comic books were stolen.

fields.heading: Fewer burglaries being solved in Austin
fields.content:
In Austin, Texas, home protection may be becoming a higher priority for many residents, as the Austin American-Statesman reports the Austin Police Department are solving fewer cases of home burglaries.

In one instance, the paper states Austin resident John Abraham waited for police to arrive to his house for three hours in 2009 after his home was burglarized. According to the newspaper, Abraham filled out a report and never heard back from the police again.

"I just didn't feel like I was a priority," Abraham told the paper. "I can understand because we don't live in a violent crime city, but it's not cool to feel like police don't even care."

Thousands of other home break-ins occur each year in Austin, the paper states, and only about 5 percent of them results in an arrest and the victim getting their possessions back - 5 percent below the national average.

According to KVUE-TV, the APD has implemented a daytime curfew for kids during school hours to help deter home invasions, as many of them have been orchestrated by teens.

In the county, property crimes - including home burglaries, robberies, larceny and car thefts - were down from 1,811 in 2009 to 1,800 last year.

"Property crimes are our biggest crimes reported," Warren County sheriff Larry Sims told the paper. However, he added that he believes the county is one of the safest in Ohio and doesn't attribute a worsening economy to an increase in crime.

Authorities told the paper the majority of property crimes are committed by drug users who are looking for quick cash grabs to feed their habit.

NBC News in Grand Rapids reports Rifenberg arrested the suspect before he could enter the home, and a neighbor found a knife nearby which has been linked to the would-be intruder.

"I feel real bad for the kid," Tito Fernandez, the resident whose home surveillance captured the incident, told the news station. "I wish someone had stopped and showed a heart. I hope that driver turns himself in."

Rios told the station that he hopes the injury doesn't derail his ambition of someday joining the Army.

fields.heading: Los Angeles police report double-digit decline in crime

According to the department's statistics, there were 4,579 violent crimes between January and March, which is 12.5 percent fewer than the same quarter last year. Homicides dropped from 72 in the first quarter of 2010 to 63 during the same period this year. The total number of murders in L.A. at the current rate would mark the lowest total of homicides in a year in more than four decades, the paper states.

Similarly, the number of property crimes during the first three months of the year - 19,642 - dropped 11.8 percent from a year earlier.

While violent crime in L.A. is at one of its lowest levels in nearly a half-century, property crimes remain a nagging problem. Harris County deputy Lennon Evans told the news station that to prevent home invasions and burglaries, homeowners have to think as burglars do. For example, he told the station a dog bowl can be an effective deterrent.

"Even if you don't like dogs or own a dog, put a dog bowl in the yard," he told the station. "Don't just put a little doggie bowl, put a big dog bowl, because mind concept says large dog bowl, large dog. Now the bad guy has to worry about where is the large dog and how vicious is this dog."

Additionally, the deputy stated putting a home security alarm company sign in front yards can prevent criminals from attempting to break into a home, even if homeowners don't own a burglar alarm. Also, he told the station residents should invest in heavy duty locks for their doors and windows.

fields.heading: Las Vegas police determined to maintain low level of car thefts

However, with a recent increase in the statistic, officials in Sin City are determined to bring the number of thefts back down again.

Metro Las Vegas detective Darren Paul told KLAS-TV that the police force is using bait cars fit with GPS tracking systems and alarms to catch car thieves.

Regarding the routine of expert auto burglars, Paul told the source that thieves are "about making things quick and getting things done very quickly. So if there's something that's going to slow them down or deter them, they're going to move on to the next car."

One of the new trends in stolen cars in the Las Vegas area, Paul told the station, is chop shops - which is where some car thieves take stolen vehicles so they can sell the parts for money - being run out of city homes, and that local police are doing what they can to take down these shops.

Speaking to the Las Vegas Sun, Paul stated that with warmer weather on the way throughout much of the country, more car thieves will be looking to steal vehicles than during the colder months.

The most recent burglary occurred at the home of a 66-year-old Kings Point homeowner, who returned home from a grocery store and was robbed of her wedding ring, the station says. She told authorities the burglars were waiting for her to return home in a parked car near her house.

The theft comes one week after a similar incident involving a 38-year-old woman coming home to her residence in Great Neck who was robbed by two men, according to the station.

Local police responded to the alarm around 2:30 in the morning, where they found Greenwood walking to her car. They held her in custody until the Delaware State Police showed up to further investigate the attempted robbery. Greenwood's break-in attempt caused about $1,000 of damage, according to Delaware Online.

Corporal Bruce Harris, spokesman for the state police, said that Greenwood is being charged with possession of burglary tools, criminal mischief under $1,000 and attempted third-degree burglary, which is when a person enters a building unlawfully with the intent to commit a crime. 

When she was arrested, police also found that she had an outstanding warrant from Kent County Court for charges of theft and probation violation. Greenwood is currently behind bars because she could not post bail, which was set at $1,250.

"Years ago, it was easier to solve burglaries because they were typically committed by people in the local community," Kevin Nulty, the Orangetown chief of police, told the news source. "Today, people are more portable."

fields.heading: James Bond Gang rumored to be burglarizing North Jersey and New York

It is known for targeting wealthy neighborhoods and stealing anywhere from $50,000 to $100,000 worth of valuables, such as jewels and cash. The burglars, wearing ski masks so they cannot be identified by security cameras, can complete a robbery in the few minutes between activating a security alarm and the arrival of the police.

The James Bond gang is suspected in connection with upwards of 40 burglaries that have been committed in the New York /New Jersey area since 2009. fields.heading: Considerations when purchasing outdoor security cameras
fields.content:
If homeowners or business are planning to install outdoor security cameras, they should consider the level of security necessary for their neighborhood. Cameras can be installed with the intention of being obviously visible to deter potential burglars. However, vandal-proof cameras are typically smaller and less noticeable and may be more effective at catching bold burglars who might attempt to destroy more obtrusive cameras.

Some security cameras are specifically designed to withstand the elements of the outdoors, but environmental housings can be installed to protect other cameras from harsher weather.

Home Security Advice states that homes that have no security measures are 10 times more likely to be targeted by burglars. Installing fake security cameras can be an alternative to using functioning cameras, because no additional security monitoring equipment is required. Burglars may think twice about approaching a home or business with cameras, although only real cameras will be any use in the event of an actual break-in.

Replica cameras can also be used in conjunction with functioning cameras to make an establishment appear more secure without spending as much money. Functioning cameras with 3.6mm lenses can capture a wider image than an inexpensive, 6mm lens. The extra cost of a lens with a better scope of vision can be counteracted by installing fewer real cameras and adding in a few fakes.

The Jefferson County Sheriff's Department received a call from a Pleasant Grove local, who witnessed the men removing property from one of the victim's homes, according to the Birmingham News.

Jefferson and Baldwin county deputies found stolen property from the victims' homes along with copper wire and other materials being used by Alabama Power to repair power lines damaged by the tornadoes.

The burglars were charges with third-degree burglary, possession of burglary tools and theft of property in the second degree. One of the men, Anthony Haislip, was also charged with possession of a controlled substance. Police found Oxycontin on his person when they made the arrests.

The Alabama National Guard, along with other authorities have been assigned to protect Pleasant Grove and other neighborhoods that were damaged by tornadoes, reported WKRG-TV. The authorities have set up checkpoints and curfews to provide additional home security for the disaster victims.

In Beaverton, Oregon, a man was caught after attempting to burglarize a local residence. The homeowner managed to scare off 40 year old Stephan Pool, but Pool did not run far, according to KPTV. When police arrived on the scene, they found him on a nearby rooftop.

"Police tried to talk Pool into coming down off the roof, but he remained uncooperative, later revealing he had been using drugs earlier in the evening, possibly methamphetamine," detective Pam Yazzolino, Beaverton police spokeswoman, told the Beaverton Valley Times.

The Hostage Negotiation Team arrived with a ladder, but Pool still refused to come down, yelling obscenities at the officers. Authorities told the residents to remain inside their home until the situation was under control.

After more than four hours of negotiating, police were forced to use tasers to bring the burglar into custody. He was arrested and charged with disorderly conduct, resisting arrest, two counts of criminal trespassing and interfering with police officers.

fields.heading: Pawn shop burglar caught on security cameras
fields.content:
A pawn shop in Virginia Beach, Virginia, was robbed by a burglar who backed his truck into the storefront to get inside. Gold Mine Pawn shop has 20 security cameras, which caught the burglary from start to finish, according to WTKR-TV.

The burglar ransacked display cases, stealing jewelry that the owner of the shop, Steve Kruth, told news sources were mainly "samples that weren't even real."

The cameras also captured footage of a man matching the burglar's description a few weeks before the break-in. The man lurked outside the store front before attempting to smash in a window with a sledge hammer. The store's security alarm rang and sent the man running.

WVEC-TV reports that police found the truck used by the suspect a few blocks from the scene of the crime. They have determined that the vehicle was stolen the night before the burglary.

The damages to the shop are estimated at around $1,000.

fields.heading: Concern for home security leads to rising safe sales
fields.content:
Many people are installing safes in their homes, in the wake of economic and natural disasters. Residential safe manufacturers have been reporting that their sales numbers are increasing, according to the New York Times. Liberty Safe sales have increased more than 40 percent in two years and Brown Safe Manufacturing reports a rise in sales of 30 percent.

"We're hearing a lot of people say they are closing their safety deposit boxes and bringing their valuables and important papers closer to home," James Skousen, a Liberty Safe spokesman, told the news source.

"You can't just pick up that thing and walk away with it," one New Jersey woman explains about the safe she recently had bolted into her closet. She explained that the safe gives her additional peace of mind, even though her home is already equipped with an alarm system.

Brown Safe Manufacturing's website states that the increase in safe sales could be due, in part, to criminals learning advanced burglary techniques on the internet.

Paul Cromwell, a criminology professor at the University of South Florida, explains that safes can be an effective deterrent for burglars because they generally want to get in and out of a home before authorities arrive.

fields.heading: Accidental call to 911 leads to the arrest of burglar family
fields.content:
While it's certainly not a factor to rely on, sometimes stupidity can be just as effective as a home security system in capturing burglars.

A "pocket dial" to the Onondaga County 911 Center turned into an accidental confession. The Syracuse Post Standard reported that dispatchers listened in as the caller and his cousins discussing the string of burglaries they planned to commit as they drove through Clay, New York. 

They also talked about their surroundings, which allowed authorities to pinpoint their location, according to WSYR-TV. Officers were already in the area, responding to a call about a suspicious person, when the criminals' call came in. 

USA Today stated that the dispatcher heard one of the burglars point out a police vehicle and relayed the information to the deputies in the area, who stopped the car immediately.

When the suspects were stopped, the dispatcher could hear the officer ask the driver for his license and registration. 

Authorities found tools in their car that had been taken from Northline Utility vehicles. The stolen property and the accidental phone call that revealed all to police led to the immediate arrests of Ronald, Allen and Thomas Euson. The Syracuse cousins were charged with grand larceny and criminal possession of stolen property.

fields.content:
The Vancouver Sun suggests that a home should be physically designed to ward off intruders, even if a home alarm system is in place. Motion-sensor lights and unobstructed views of the property from the home can eliminate hiding places for potential burglars.

"Questions about security don't usually come up in the design of a home," Keith Baker, a Canadian home designer, told the news source. "But having a design that discourages crime is just part of good old common sense."

Wireless technology makes installing a home security system much easier and can also be less conspicuous without wires running all over the home.

One Denver home designer is integrating home automation with the iPad, which allows the homeowner to control everything from the TV to the pool to the lights right from an iPad app, according to the Denver Post. Home automation is not new, but technological advances are lowering the cost of installing such systems.

Leaving lights and other electronics on, regardless of whether anyone is home, can make burglars hesitant to enter a residence.

Velazquez allegedly attempted to burglarize a home 10 minutes after being discharged from the Mendocino County jail, the Ukiah Daily Journal reported. Police re-arrested the suspect on suspicion of burglary and he was on his way back to jail.

fields.heading: Suspected burglar of 52 homes arrested in Nashville
fields.content:
A man suspected of committing 52 residential burglaries in the Nashville area within the past year was arrested recently. WSMV-TV reports that Jerry Phifer told authorities that he committed the crimes to support his drug habit.

Their stay in these areas will continue for the next 90 days. The remaining 100 cops will be distributed to five police areas that have suffered from "flare-ups" - a term Emanuel used to describe regions with even further heightened crime.

Emanuel has drawn criticism for his plan, with unions claiming that it is merely repositioning cops and not hiring more to increase neighborhood and home security.

"To say this is 500 more officers on the street - no, it's not. Don’t mislead the public," said Fraternal Order of Police president Mike Shields. "There are no more police officers today than there were yesterday. They're taking 500 officers as if they were never on the street and putting them into beat cars. They're acting as if they were assigned to some desk duty."

While parts of Chicago has suffered from increased criminal activity, Michigan's level was worse, as the top two cities in terms of crime per capita were from the state.

The data was found while Mike Males, an employee at the Center on Juvenile and Criminal Justice in San Francisco, was conducting a report regarding the state's three-strike policy. Under this policy, anyone convicted of a felony for a third time receives a life sentence in prison.

Males blames the new trend on the increased use of drugs. During the last three decades, the number of criminals over the age of 40 has quadrupled. In 1980, 24,200 felony arrests were made for those older than 40. In 2009, the figure grew to 110,700. For juveniles, arrests fell from 97,000 to 58,600 during the same time period.

"We now see a dramatic reversal in the aging of the crime population," Males told the news source. "It baffles me."

The state's three-strike policy has been hotly debated since its inception in 1994. Opponents of the rule claim that the sentence is too great for those committing minor penalties and costs the government too much. Males has suggested that the rule be changed so that the last strike must be a violent crime.

California's per capita rate for homicides is also down 15 percent from 2000.

While the news comes as a positive for police forces and state residents, many officers and criminologists are unable to pin point the reason for the declines. Some state that better policing has improved the rate, while others believe more law-abiding citizens now exist. The state's Attorney General, Kamala Harris, believes the former is the reason.

"The decline in homicides and other violent crimes reflects the tireless efforts of our peace officers," said Harris. "My office is committed to supporting their brave, relentless and selfless work in protecting the people of California from hardened criminals."

In addition to violent crime decreasing, property crime was also down by 2.2 percent. In addition, burglary fell 0.9 percent, motor vehicle theft by 7.2 percent, arson by 15 percent and larceny worth less than $400 by 4.9 percent. Larceny for more than $400 actually rose, growing 0.7 percent.

fields.heading: Crimes rates decreasing faster in Milwaukee's metro areas than suburbs
fields.content:
According to a recent report conducted by the Brookings Institution, crime rates for Milwaukee's metro areas are on the decline, while rates in the region's suburbs continue to hold steady. The figures highlight the need for greater home security throughout the area.

The report revealed that the violent crime rate per 100,000 residents living in metropolitan Milwaukee areas declined by 23.7 percent from 1990 through 2008. These crimes include homicides, assaults and robberies.

However, during the same time period, the violent crime rate for the region's suburbs fell by only 3.9 percent. While crime in the suburbs might not be high to begin with, the report's findings reveal that the city is doing a better job of cutting out criminal activity, making it safer for residents and tourists alike.

"The drops were fastest and most dramatic in larger cities, in denser suburbs, in places that generally have been relatively more poor and minority. And they experienced the biggest benefits over these years of declining crime," said Elizabeth Kneebone, co-author of the report. "As those city rates fell, and the suburb rates fell as well but more slowly, the gap between cities and the suburbs narrowed."

According to recent data released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, crime rates were down nationally, falling by 5.3 percent during 2010.

During two days in the past Memorial Day weekend, local police officers responded to a stabbing, a shooting, an incident involving a shotgun and five separate accounts of armed robberies. Furthermore, because of the holiday weekend, an increased number of criminal complaints and traffic violations occurred as well.

"Policing this event has always come with huge challenges. Unfortunately, criminal activity is often associated with large events, which is why we have deployed additional officers to allow us to respond to this increase in activity," Captain David Knipes told the news source. Many of the robberies involved cash being stolen, while a few citizens had their jewelry taken as well.

fields.content:

For instance, the number of murders in the Northeast region grew by 8.3 percent last year. In addition, forcible and aggravated assaults both rose in the section, growing by 1.4 percent and 0.7 percent, respectively.

While no direct correlation exists to explain the increase in crime, a report from 2009 attempted to link poverty with illegal activity. The Police Executive Research Forum polled more than 200 law enforcement agencies in 2009 and discovered a significant link between low income and crime. According to an article from The Root, a prolonged recession could have possibly increased crime as a result.

"We are not saying there is going to be a crime wave, but we are saying this is a wake-up call and we anticipate the situation will continue to deteriorate," said PERF executive director Chuck Wexler, after the agency's report was revealed.

Among the most dangerous cities in the country in terms of crimes per capita were St. Louis, New Haven, Connecticut, and Memphis.

fields.heading: Home security tips for vacationers
fields.content:
A recent article in the Pocono Record relayed several home security tips for those going on vacation during the summer.

According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, 65.8 percent of all burglaries occur in a residential area and happen within 12 minutes. Furthermore, a majority of these instances involve homes whose owners are on vacation.

To combat these happenings, the article advises homeowners to never indicate that they are going on vacation. Thus, updating an answering machine, Facebook and other items is not helpful. Also, homeowners should reduce their ringer's volume, as unanswered telephone calls are red flags for burglars.

Homeowners should also survey their home for easy entry points and ensure that these areas are locked and double guarded. Investing in stronger locks is helpful, the article relays.

Finally, many thieves are aware of the common places homeowners hide their valuables - dressers, closets, freezers - so purchasing a safe is often an effective move to thwart their efforts.

In addition to all of these steps, having an effective and active alarm system is also advised to ease the peace of mind of those going on vacation.

fields.heading: GPS tracking systems prove effective
fields.content:
A recent article in the Boston Herald analyzed the role of GPS tracking systems and discussed their usefulness in certain situations.

While many consumers are used to using GPS systems to help navigate in unknown territory, tracking systems can work similarly, finding objects instead of locations.

The article's author, for instance, tested a system to track the woman that walks her dogs. Through the tracking system, she was able to determine that the dog walker showed up at the correct time and took her dog along the agreed-upon path.

While this instance was just a test, those who place tracking systems in their cars or on other valuables can easily trace them if they were ever to be stolen.

For many tracking systems, the battery life is lengthy, meaning a user won't be turned off a trail soon after a theft occurs. The only downside to the systems are that they are not as effective when an individual is indoors.

A recent report from the National Insurance Crime Bureau found an increase in vehicle theft recently. With more GPS tracking systems being used, these burglaries could decline soon.

The FBI's Uniform Crime Report, which analyzes statistics from cities with at least 100,000 people, discovered that Fairfield County had 502 violent crimes from January to December last year. The area's overall figure increased by 65 instances during the year, which has many local police officers and home security enthusiasts upset.

"I would find it very disturbing, and certainly something our police department takes very seriously," Fairfield Mayor Harry Price told the Reported. "Any time a statistic comes out that identifies an increase in any type of crime, that's cause for concern."

Nationwide, violent crime rates decreased by 5.5 percent, putting Fairfield County well above the country's trend.

Overall, the county experienced two more homicides, 76 more aggravated assaults and nearly 150 additional crimes involving property thefts throughout 2010 compared to the previous year. Burglaries decreased, however, totaling 22 fewer. However, seventy-nine more vehicle thefts took place.

Officials say there are now at least 12 officers assigned to the area overnight each evening, which has helped allay some residents' fears about the frequent assaults and thefts that have occurred in the area.

"We had to basically go down there and clean up the area and make sure it was a friendly place not only for people who live down there but also for people who visit the city and young adults who would go out downtown," Sergeant Peter Sheldon, who heads the Chinatown initiative, told the Post.

The paper says police statistics show the increased enforcements has led to a 7 percent drop in overall crime within a 1,000-foot radius of the center of the district. However, more than 300 incidents were still reported and some crimes actually rose last year within a 1,500-foot radius.

As more families vacation or stay out later during the summer, more robberies often take place. The article relays that households suffering break-ins lose just above $2,000 per instance. Thus, homeowners need to effectively secure their properties.

"Summer is a peak season for break-ins because homeowners often spend more time away from their homes for family vacations or local activities," security expert Clint Briscoe told the news source.

Installing effective alarm systems and using bright exterior lights are two methods to thwart robbery attempts, experts have relayed.

For those going on vacation, homeowners are advised to make their properties look populated. Having neighbors collect mail or landscapers cut lawns or bushes can create the illusion that a family is home.

Despite the decrease, criminal activity is often noticed more during the summer months, especially in Salisbury, Delaware, according to the article.

Overall, crime in Salisbury has increased the last several years. In 2009, the region recorded four homicides, which then grew to seven last year.

"Every single homicide takes something out of this community; it lessens the sensitivity of community members and it brings a host of other issues," Salisbury police chief Barbara Duncan told the news source.

fields.content:

Both towns are hiring more officers and taking additional steps to ensure the safety of their citizens, as well as to continue the declining crime rates experienced nationwide. According to a recent FBI report, criminal activity was down 5.5 percent during 2010.

In Newark, the police department will begin utilizing a helicopter soon, as well as mounted patrol officers. Furthermore, police members will also begin riding on local buses to monitor neighborhoods. In addition, the region will be enforcing a curfew for teens between the hours of 11 p.m. and 4 a.m. Those who are caught breaking it will be brought to churches and houses of worship before being returned home.

"We are going to enforce the curfew this summer with a vigor that has not been seen in a long, long time," said Mayor Cory Booker.

Jersey City, meanwhile, has implemented its Summer Shield program that will use several agencies to track down any violent offenders.

Reducing crime during the summer months has become a goal for many cities' police forces. The police department in Salisbury, Delaware recently announced that additional officers from Maryland will join their force to help reduce criminal activity in the area.

Any information pertaining to unsolved crimes, fugitives or general illegal activity within their county limits is helpful, the group relays. Residents can text CRIMES with the keyword "Reward," which notates to Crime Stoppers that the tip wishes to remain anonymous.

Furthermore, those who text tips to the group are eligible to receive cash rewards.

While some residents might be hesitant to report illegal activity, Crime Stoppers has ensured the safety of the process.

"If the cameras are there it's going to deter crime just by the presence of the cameras," Vallejo police sergeant Jeff Bassett told KGO-TV, an ABC affiliate in San Francisco.

NRF's survey of close to 130 retailers revealed that 94.5 percent have been affected by criminals during the last 12 months. Furthermore, 84.8 percent relayed that this problem has become worse during the last three years.

While more criminals are sent to jail, the state's taxpayers must pony up more funds to support the prison costs. Instead, investing this money into effective programs is a better option, the article concludes.

fields.heading: GPS tracking system locates missing 84-year-old woman
fields.content:
While GPS systems are typically used for drivers to navigate unknown territories, they have also proven effective for locating people and stolen items.

According to a recent report in the Princeton Packet, a GPS tracking system helped located an 84-year-old woman, who had been missing for several hours. The woman reportedly left her house on Friday, June 3, and her family could not locate her. However, the woman had been recently enrolled in the region's Project Lifesaver program, which uses advanced tracking technology to help locate individuals.

fields.heading: Poverty not sole factor in violent crime
fields.content:

Experts have championed that poverty is not solely responsible for violent crime. A recent report from the Federal Bureau of Investigation revealed a drop in overall violent crime, which fell by 5.5 percent to reach its lowest level since the 1960s.

To draw further conclusions, experts have stated that more research is necessary.

"There is no single satisfying answer to what causes changes in our crime rate, just like there is no single cause of weather," said Catherine Gallagher, a criminologist at Virginia's George Mason University.

Gallagher relayed that losing a job and cause anger and depression, which many then figure leads to violent crime. However, the criminologist further explained that losing a job can also result in more time spent with family, as well as being home during the day, meaning fewer burglaries could take place.

Experts have stated that better policing, record incarcerations and the advent of cell phone have effectively reduced the number of violent crimes taking place during the last several decades.

The FBI had adopted an aggressive campaign to find the reported mobster, purchasing advertising space to promote pictures and details of Greig, hoping people would recognize her and provide information.

During his time eluding capture, Bulger was believed to have traveled the U.S., Europe, Canada and Latin America. His last credible sighting was in London in 2002.

A recent report regarding the neighborhood and home security in and around Los Angeles showed an increase in criminal activity during the week ending August 12.

Overall, crime reports were up significantly in 14 L.A. neighborhoods during the period, according to data compiled by the Los Angeles Times' L.A. database.

Eleven of the neighborhoods had an increase in violent crime. The Fairfax neighborhood had five reports during the week, which is much higher than its average of one in the previous three months.

Vermont Vista was the most active during the period in terms of property crimes, as 22 were reported. This total is above its average of 13.8 between May and July.

Home security experts have advised property owners to invest in new and effective alarm systems to thwart the efforts of criminals. Using cameras, extra locks and keypad systems, homeowners may effectively drive down the number of property crimes in their neighborhood.

New security efforts may have helped the nation's crime rate descend by 5.5 percent between 2009 and 2010, which the Federal Bureau of Investigation recently reported.

fields.heading: Crime levels declining in Durham
fields.content:
According a recently released police report, neighborhood and home security levels in Durham, North Carolina, appear to be increasing.

The region's police department revealed that the crime rate in the area dropped close to 3.5 percent during the year's first six months compared to last year.

Violent crime, which includes homicides, robberies and aggravated assaults, was up, though, rising slightly by 1.9 percent. This trend began in 2010, when the crimes increased 1.6 percent.

The region's overall crime figures were down due to a drastic reduction in property crimes, including burglaries, larcenies and motor vehicle thefts. Overall, 4.2 percent fewer property crimes were committed during the year's first half than all of 2010.

Durham police chief Jose Lopez told reporters that his crew has targeted property crime in many ways, including cracking down on organized shoplifting. Town Mayor Bill Bell also stated that the region's police officers need to step up their efforts and solve cases.

"We can't be satisfied," Bell told Lopez. "I'm not satisfied. If there's something we need to be doing on this council [to help], we need to pitch in. But these crimes need to be solved at a higher rate."

fields.heading: Chicago crime levels continue to decline
fields.content:
For the 31st straight month, Chicago has recorded an improved crime scene, much to the appreciation of local neighborhood and home security enthusiasts.

A recent report released by the city's police department revealed both violent and property crimes decreased during July, with the area's overall crime level declining by 2.9 percent. Violent crimes fell by 7.5 percent, while 1.7 fewer property crimes were committed compared to last year.

Furthermore, every category of violent crime was lower during the month, including homicides, robberies and aggravated assaults. Overall, 25 murders took place during the month, which is close to a 9 percent decrease from the previous month.

In terms of property crimes, the number of thefts declined the most, falling by 6.9 percent. The total number of arsons committed in July was also down after increasing in each of the previous three months. Burglaries increased by 1 percent, however, while motor thefts were up 16.8 percent.

"Successful crime trends and arrests are not enough to abate the concerns of victims, community members and others who are affected by crimes in our city," police superintendent, Garry McCarthy said. "We must have strong partnerships with engaged community members who are committed to working together to address crime at its root."

fields.heading: South Florida experiencing increased number of guns
fields.content:
In a trend sure to affect the mindset of local neighborhood residents in terms of home security, NBC Miami reports the amount of gun violence has risen in South Florida this summer.

Law enforcement officials in the area agree with the report, noting that gun violence has become a disturbing trend.

"We are seeing that people are able to get their hands on more high-powered weaponry," said Delrish Moss, spokesman for the City of Miami Police Department.

However, despite the increased number of guns circulating, the state's crime level hasn't grown, nor has it risen in the region specifically. In fact, the local areas' crime rates have fallen in recent years.

During 2009, Miami-Dade County recorded 19,797 violent crimes, however, the figure was down to 18,507 the next year. In Broward, a similar trend occurred. In 2009, 9,562 violent crimes were committed, which then declined to 8,597 in 2010.

While this has been a positive trend, the region hasn't been able to retrain a large number of its law enforcement officials due to budgetary concerns. Thus, the efforts of locals have been relied upon to help maintain safe neighborhoods.

fields.heading: New prison processes in California condemned, may lead to more crime
fields.content:
A recent report from the Los Angeles Times relayed that L.A. County supervisors have condemned the decision by state officials to keep prisoners in local lockups and for parolees to supervise parolees. While the new plans hope to cut costs, other officials believe it will lead to a rise in crime, much to the chagrin of local home security enthusiasts.

Supervisor Michael Antonovich believes, under the new plan, jails will run out of space quickly if they continue to hold 7,000 low-level felons that courts would normally sentence to state prisons. Furthermore, the region's plan would increase the number of probationers the departments must oversee.

"It's a system that's meant to fail, and who is it going to fail," Antonovich said. "Every neighborhood, every community where these people are going to be running around … It's a Pandora's box. It's the bar scene - a violent bar scene that you saw in Star Wars - except they're all crazy and nuts."

Another supervisor, Zev Yaroslavsky, explained the problem began when state legislators began "to dump their financial woes on [them]." He felt the new development will adversely impact local crime in communities "without a doubt."

Phil Kasten, a spokesperson for the county, explained that property crime is still a major issue in the region, as two-thirds of the area's crime involves theft of valuables or automobiles.

"Together with residents we can reduce the opportunity for criminals to victimize our residents," said Kasten. "By locking up our cars, homes, garages and sheds we're moving and securing our valuables in sight."

Statewide, the total number of crimes committed in Maryland during 2010 was down 5.1 percent. This trend follows the national rate, as the Federal Bureau of Investigation revealed 5.5 percent fewer crimes were recorded during 2010 than in 2009.

fields.heading: Gun crimes down at Virginia bars, study finds
fields.content:
According to a study conducted by the Virginia State Police, the state's number of gun crimes declined recently when compared to previous years. The report may have an impact on the region's crime rate and local neighborhood and home security.

The discovery is relevant as this is the first year of the state's new law that allowed patrons to bring concealed guns into places that serve alcohol. The Richmond Times-Dispatch reports 145 gun crimes were reported during the 2010-2011 fiscal year, which was 5.2 percent fewer than the previous 12-month period.

Furthermore, the report revealed that many of gun crimes recorded during the most recent fiscal year were minor, with some involving concealed-carry permits.

"The numbers basically just confirm what we’ve said would happen if the General Assembly changed the law," Phillip Van Cleave, president of the pro-gun Virginia Citizens Defense League, told the news source. "Keep in mind what the other side was saying - that this was going to be a blood bath, that restaurants will be dangerous and people will stop going. But there was nothing to base the fear-mongering on."

Van Cleave's group was strongly for the new law, which made Virginia one of 43 states that allow concealed guns into restaurants and bars that serve alcohol.

fields.heading: Maryland crime declines to record low during 2010
fields.content:

Overall, the state's crime rate was down 6.3 percent from the previous year, which was a new low for the area's per-capita incidence of violent and property offenses. The figures submitted to the FBI showed the lowest total of modern crimes on record since 1975, when the department first began tracking statistics.

During the previous 14 years, the state has continued to reach record lows in terms of crime, despite nearby states experiencing more rapid declines. However, regardless of this trend, the state has remained one of the nation's most violent.

"This economic downturn has not been associated with a crime increase," Gary LaFree, a criminologist at the University of Maryland, told The Baltimore Sun. "No one knows for sure why."

Local law enforcement officials, however, believe the combination of newer technology and information sharing can help reduce the region's crime rate even further.

fields.heading: Survey: Happy teenagers more likely to avoid crime
fields.content:
A recent study may provide some relief for those worried about neighborhood and home security.

The study, conducted by researchers at the University of California, Davis, revealed that happier teenagers are less likely to commit a crime.

The researchers analyzed the data of nearly 15,000 students between grades 7 and 9 to conduct their report. Of these students, 29 percent admitted to have committed one criminal offense, while 18 percent claimed they had used at least one illegal drug. However, when the researchers looked at data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health, they discovered that teenagers who were happier were less likely to commit crimes or use drugs.

The report also showed that teens suffering from even minor depression were more likely to engage in illegal activity.

The researchers concluded that the benefits of being happy, such connecting with others, feeling good about oneself and having good social skills, can help children make decisions that are "informed by positive emotions."

The researchers hope to influence more teens with their report, while continuing to lower the nation's crime rate.

fields.heading: Crime numbers continue to decline nationwide
fields.content:
A recent article in The Guardian analyzed the declining crime figures in the U.S. and attempted to discover the cause for improved neighborhood and home security.

According to recent figures from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the total number of murders, robberies and other serious crimes has fallen to a 48-year low nationwide.

In Washington, D.C., the fewest number of murders in the last 50 years took place last year. In fact, two decades ago, the total was nearly four times as high. New York City recorded a similar decline in murders during 2009, fallen to its low level since FBI records began in 1963. Twenty years ago, the nation's murder rate was 9.8 per 100,000 people, whereas the rate is now half that today.

Robberies have also fallen, declining 10 percent in 2010 and 8 percent in 2009.

Experts point to better medical treatment as a solution for the falling murder rate. However, this doesn't explain the drop in violent crime.

Anti-gun activists point to the strict gun control laws in New York and Washington as a reason for the lower crime rate. However, Houston, where guns are prevalent, has also recorded a drop in crime.

Some experts believe stiffer prison sentences are causing fewer crimes, as criminals are staying incarcerated and off the streets for longer periods of time.

fields.heading: Illinois residents urged to take action against criminals

While the crime rate in the county, according to the article, is relatively low compared to other towns, a recent rash of burglaries has created a stir among residents.

To help prevent more burglaries from taking place, McHenry County sheriff Andrew Zinke provided several tips for homeowners to use.

First, people should check and ensure all doors, houses, outbuildings and vehicles are locked. Using heavy-duty locks, such as dead bolts, can be effective. While these efforts may not make your house less attractive to criminals on the outside, they should make it more difficult for criminals to break in.

Next, owners are advised to install motion sensor lights, and to trim any trees or bushes near their residences. Eliminating any areas where criminals can hide is key.

Finally, homeowners should always make their property look occupied, as criminals are often attracted to residences that look empty and abandoned.

A significant number of burglaries occurred between Chetek and the Coulee region, which prompted residents to contact local home security companies to help install better devices to protect their residences.

"In the crime wave that has been going on for a few months now, that always seems to create and uptick of alarmed customers," Chris Lokken, a customer service manager for a local security company, told the news source. "They want to protect their family, their possessions in their homes. A good way to do that is with a security system."

Among the most popular devices being used by locals are monitored alarm systems as well as video cameras.

In addition, security companies have placed their signs on the lawns of customers to deter any potential criminals.

"Our first line of defense is our signage. A great many would-be criminals would be threatened by that and wouldn’t want to break in," Lokken told WEAU 13 News.

Overall, 1,794 offenses have been reported, including homicides, robberies, aggravated assaults, burglaries, larcenies and vehicle thefts. Redding police chief Peter Hansen relayed that the total number of offenses committed in 2010 was low compared to the previous five year's data, meaning this year's are falling even lower.

"I hope that is because people are more willing to report [crimes]," Hansen stated publicly.

While fewer arrests have been made this year, Hansen believes the trend might be a result of fewer cops on the street, stemming from budgetary cuts.

Vehicle thefts have actually increased so far in 2011, rising from 110 last year to 143 in 2011, which is a 30 percent jump.

fields.heading: Baltimore FOP: More cops not the answer to crime
fields.content:
Recently, Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake relayed that the region would be adding more police officers to deal with crime and increase local neighborhood and home security. However, this news has been met with opposition from many.

While a recent poll in The Baltimore Sun revealed crime as the biggest concern of local respondents, the region's police union president stated that hiring more officers is not the best course of action.

"To come out and tell the voters that hiring 300 new cops and putting them in the neighborhood, that's not necessarily going to reduce crime," Fraternal Order of Police president Bob Cherry said, WBAL-TV reports.

Instead, Cherry believes the mayor should be analyzing how current officers are being deployed and find a better way to utilize them. He explained that the officers in the force now are adequately trained and have experience, but if more are added to the department, a greater number might leave without enough pay to go around.

During the last decade, the region has recorded a lower crime rate. However, the population has also dwindled during this period. To help bring more citizens to the region, improving the crime rate has become a priority of the mayor's.

The Berkeley Police Department revealed that between January and June, 4 percent fewer part one violent crimes, including homicides, aggravated assaults and robberies, took place in the region, compared to the previous year. Furthermore, the total volume of part one property crimes, which include burglaries, theft and arson, was down 16 percent during the same period.

Since 2010, 3 percent fewer robberies have taken place, 12 percent fewer aggravated assaults have been committed. Thefts, meanwhile, have dropped 23 percent and 50 percent fewer murders have been recorded.

A local spokesperson for the Berkeley Police Department stated that attributing the declines to one factor is impossible. However, different police tactics may be the cause.

"One theory is that we have been doing a lot more focused work and analyzing where theft is happening and when and doing a lot of special projects and arresting habitual offenders," Sergeant Mary Kusmiss explained to the public recently.

Not all categories improved, however. Compared to 2010, 8 percent more auto thefts took place, while 50 percent more arsons were committed.

According to a New York Times article, a region of New York City has experienced an increase in crime recently, threatening the neighborhood and home security of those in its boundaries.

The region encompasses parts of Washington Heights and Inwood. The report relays that the area has gone through violent phases in the past. In fact, two decades ago, the number of killings and shootings in the region had locals calling it a "mini-Vietnam."

In recent weeks, local residents have experienced or witnessed an increase in thefts, break-ins and other types of crime. However, despite the trend, some citizens aren't scared.

The importance of having a home security system was underscored recently in Lexington, Kentucky, where a woman was assaulted after her house was broken into.

The Lexington Herald-Leader reports the home of the victim, a 60-year-old woman, was broken into by two assailants who smashed her door with a sledgehammer. The homeowner was assaulted and her home was ransacked, but nothing was reported missing.

"According to the victim, they were ransacking the house as if they had something specific in mind, but never took anything," Lexington police spokeswoman Sherelle Roberts told the news source.

While the victim was accosted, the paper states her injuries aren't serious. Police recovered a sledgehammer and other items near the home.

Though a number of crime figures for Lexington have declined in recent years, one statistics which has risen steadily is burglaries. The city of Lexington's official website indicates there were 2,427 burglaries in 2009 - more than 160 higher than the year before.

fields.heading: Gun crime in Tennessee among nation's worst
fields.content:
Recent data released by the Federal Bureau of Investigation may be enough for property owners in Tennessee to upgrade their home security systems.

According to the report, the number of gun crimes committed in the state is the second worst in the nation, trailing only Washington, D.C. During 2010, 356 people were killed by guns in Tennessee.

"Everywhere you look, someone is getting gunned down," one widower, whose husband was shot and killed last year, told The Tennessean. "Senseless crime. It's just sad."

Law enforcement officials in the state have yet to comment on the report, as they were not the ones collecting the data. However, other authorities are unable to explain the high rate.

Don Green, executive director of the University of Tennessee's Law Enforcement Innovation Center, told the news source that the rate can be attributed to several factors. Among these are better police reporting, an increasing number of gang and drug-related crimes and the state's high rate of gun ownership.

As a result, citizens are advised to be more careful in their neighborhoods. Upgrading security systems may also prove effective.

fields.heading: New crime initiative proving effective in Prince George's county
fields.content:
Home security enthusiasts in Prince George's county in Maryland should be proud of the latest crime-fighting initiative undertaken by local residents. 

In the region's five neighborhoods targeted by the county's police, which have adopted the new anti-violence initiative, crime levels have fallen significantly. The new program required violent criminals to attend face-to-face meetings with law enforcement officials and community activists to ensure the police and locals are watching them closely.

As a result, none of the 67 criminals forced to attend the meetings have been arrested since. Police refer to the five neighborhoods as their "focus areas" to ensure the initiative is proving effective and crime levels are staying down.

"I'm sure it had some impact," Prince George police chief Mark Magaw told reporters after a recent news conference. "I know some took advantage of the services."

One of the regions, Glassmanor, recorded a crime decrease of 12 percent between May 22 and September 1 compared to the same period the year before. In Suitland, crime was down 9.7 percent, while the amount of illegal activity in Hillcrest Heights was down 23.3 percent.

fields.heading: Crime rate in Providence rising
fields.content:
Much to the chagrin of local home security enthusiasts, the crime rate in Providence increased during 2010.

Between 2009 and 2010, the number of illegal activities committed in the state's capital increased in almost every category. The Federal Bureau of Investigation's Uniform Crime Report showed that of the 10 major crime categories, 2010's levels were up in all but two - larceny-theft and arson.

One more murder was committed between 2009 and 2010, as well as 12 more rapes, 31 more robberies, 101 more property crimes and 187 additional burglaries. To compare local regions, crime in New Haven and Hartford, Connecticut, as well Worcester, Massachusetts, was down in nearly every major category.

“The publication of the 2010 national crime statistics reminds us that national security is as much about keeping our streets safe from crime as it is about protecting the United States from terrorism," said FBI director Robert Mueller.

Thus, law enforcement officials and homeowners in Providence need to address these trends and improve their neighborhood and home security to thwart the efforts of criminals.

fields.heading: New Jersey city records better crime figures during 2010
fields.content:
According to the New Jersey Uniform Crime Report, the number of illegal offenses taking place in East Brunswick declined between 2009 and 2010, much to the delight of local home security enthusiasts.

The report showed that just 44 incidents of violent crime occurred in the region throughout 2010, down from 52 in 2009. By comparison, 237 offenses were recorded during 2008. Diving further into the numbers, in 2010, no murders were committed, while 15 robberies took place and 25 aggravated assaults were waged.

Property crime figures, while still high, declined in almost every category. Overall, 89 burglaries took place, while 721 reports of larceny or theft were filed and 23 motor vehicles were stolen. These figures are down from 125, 793 and 27, respectively, from the year before.

"The department continues to work to ensure the number of officers assigned to uniform patrol remains the same to ensure a constant, visible police presence and a quick response to calls for assistance," said detective sergeant Kevin Zebro.

He also attributed the declining crime figures to community outreach programs that have helped both students and adults.

fields.heading: Utah's crime rates continue to decline
fields.content:

Overall, Utah's violent crime rate dropped 2 percent, while 4.2 percent fewer property crimes were committed between 2009 and 2010. While these trends come as good news for locals, the report also showed that cities with at least 100,000 residents, including Salt Lake City, West Valley City and West Jordan, experienced an uptick in violent crime despite lower property offenses.

Despite these increases, local residents and police officers have remained tough on crime.

Police captain Kevin Thacker in Sandy, Utah, relayed that several troops of officers have been cracking down on high-crime regions.

"They’ll go out and just stop every car that moves for a few nights," Thacker said.

In addition, local residents have been volunteering to watch after homes of neighbors going on vacation, as well as businesses that have been burglarized in the past.

Despite the report's recent findings, Utah's crime rates have been decreasing since the late 1990s.

fields.heading: Tough Times, Strange Thefts
fields.content:
Now is a good time to invest in security monitoring systems, as the tough economy is likely to blame for increasingly strange thefts occurring nationwide, Time magazine and Houston-area news source KPRC recently reported.

Houston police have noted an uptick in burglaries of hair extension and human hair businesses, according to KPRC. The source also reported copper theft has increased in the Houston area, with some crooks climbing buildings to steal copper from air conditioners.

Both hair and metal theft made Time magazine's recent list of weird things people are currently stealing. The magazine reported that hair can be quite lucrative for thieves, as in the instance of a robbery of hair valued at $70,000 to $90,000 from a Chicago beauty supply store..

Time singled out brass rather than copper as the current metal of choice for thieves, and reported that criminals have been removing brass rings from inside fire hydrants in Chicago, rendering the hydrants inoperable and posing a risk to residents.

Animal theft is also on the rise, according to both the magazine and KPRC. Citing American Kennel Club statistics that dog-napping has increased 49 percent in the last year, Time said criminals will often take dogs then return them for a reward, or else sell them via the internet. Around Houston, livestock and other farm animals are being stolen, including a recent heist of 6,000 lambs from a feed lot, according to KPRC.

While the number of burglaries and aggravated assaults dropped significantly, the region's total amount of homicides remains high, much to the discomfort of residents. So far this year, 26 murders have been recorded, which is the highest the total has been since 1994.

"The number of homicides is what concerns people most," Mayor John DeStefano told reporters. "We can't have it be normal that the homicide rate is so high."

DeStefano admitted that 70 percent of the region's crime comes from its re-entry population, which often have easy access to firearms and narcotics.

fields.heading: Increased number of cops reducing crime rate in Maryland region
fields.content:
A recent report in the Washington Examiner explained that crime in Silver Spring, Maryland, has been dropping since the region added more police officers.

In July, the Montgomery County Police Department doubled the number of officers on patrol, especially during the hours that the region's youth curfew begins. The curfew had been put in place in July and restricts teenagers from being out after 11 p.m. Sunday through Thursday or after midnight at Friday and Saturday.

During the two months since the region's crime prevention efforts increased, the number of illegal offenses have decreased, which has led some to question whether the curfew is even needed.

"It undermines the argument of the executive branch that a curfew is needed to address levels of crime in Silver Spring," said councilman Phil Andrews, a Democrat from the Rockville/Gaithersburg region and chairman of the Public Safety Committee. "Targeting resources to where they're needed is sufficient ... and is a proven method."

Homeowners in the region still skeptical about the crime level are advised to upgrade their home security systems, install more locks and keep their doors and garages closed.

"As we patrol the parking lots at the theaters, for instance, walking these parking lots it's amazing to see how many valuables, laptop computers, purses, are left in plain view on dashboards or seats," Layton Police Lt. Quinn Moyes, who heads the department’s patrol division, said to the Standard-Examiner.

fields.heading: Violent crime down in Fresno, California
fields.content:
Violent crimes in Fresno, California, have decreased significantly while property crimes are on the rise, according to recent statistics released by the Fresno police.

Violent crimes, including homicides, rapes, robberies and aggravated assaults, are down nearly 6 percent compared to last year, while property crimes, including auto theft, have risen 6.5 percent.

"We know we're going in the right direction,” Police Chief Jerry Dyer told KPGE News, a CBS affiliate in Fresno. “It's just gonna take us a while to get where we used to be."

Fresno police are working on arresting criminals who are involved in more serious crimes as opposed to minor offenses, which Dyer said the city no longer has the capacity to handle.

"It used to be the philosophy of law enforcement that you would arrest everyone that's involved in a crime and put them in jail,” he said to KPGE. “Unfortunately, we don't have a criminal justice system that will support that any longer."

fields.heading: Topeka, Kansas home invasion numbers double
fields.content:
Home invasions in Topeka, Kansas, have nearly doubled over the past year. According to the Topeka Capital-Journal, the crimes are being committed by children as young as 12 and 13.

The Topeka Police Department revealed crime statistics in its third quarter crime strategy meeting recently, the Capital-Journal reported. Statistics showed property crimes and violent crimes are both higher than they were at the same point last year.

At the third quarter crime strategy meeting, Police Chief Ron Miller said he is concerned about the number of home invasions that have occurred, according to the Capital-Journal. “It’s a group of young people running together committing these crimes,” Miller said of the home invasions. “Crime is an issue in the community. Public safety needs to be a priority for all of us.”

Miller believes the home invasions are a direct reflection of a gang problem in the area, which he alleged isn’t the traditional gang scenario, according to the news source. Instead, he claimed rival gangs band together to commit these crimes.

Topeka’s overall property crimes, including burglary, automobile theft, shoplifting and arson were up 3.18 percent from the same time last year, according to the FBI’s 2010 crime statistics. The U.S. Census Bureau reported Topeka’s population grew to more than 127,000 residents in 2010.

fields.content:

The men entered the 44-year-old woman's home at around 9 a.m., with at least one carrying a gun. The victim was struck several times before the suspects left, and she was treated at Provena Medical Mercy Center in Aurora afterwards for non-life-threatening injuries.

The woman managed to free herself enough to make her way out of her home after the burglars left.

According to police, they were informed by a passerby that a woman had just been attacked, and when they arrived at the scene, the resident was still bound by tape.

The suspects took a gold necklace from around the victim's neck before fleeing the scene.

Despite this crime, Aurora's crime rates are at an all-time low when compared to previous years, according to the Aurora mayor's office.

There have been 10 burglaries along the border of Falls Church and Arlington. Eight of the burglaries occurred in Falls Church, while two occurred in Arlington.

Falls Church Deputy Police Chief Mary Gavin told local radio station WTOP, the burglar strikes between 6 p.m. and 3 a.m., targeting expensive electronics such as laptops, iPads and expensive jewelry and weapons.

In Merrill, where 10 burglaries have also been reported, police are seeking a suspect who’s committed robberies during the day. The suspicious person was described as a man who knocks on doors and asks residents for directions or jumper cables.

fields.heading: Police investigating Ocoee home invasion
fields.content:
Police are investigating a home invasion in Ocoee, Florida, that left the resident of the home with multiple injuries.

The victim of the crime reportedly stumbled nude into his neighbor's home to seek help after his house was broken into, and he was beaten and stripped of his clothing by the intruders.

Paramedics responded after the attack, which reportedly happened around 2 a.m., and found the man bleeding with serious head injuries. He was immediately transported to a nearby hospital.

The victim was later able to tell the police that he was pistol whipped and couldn't remember the exact number of attackers, according to the Orlando Sentinel.

Ocoee Police Detective James Berish told the Sentinel the victim remembered the attackers took his wallet. Berish believes the intruders were startled by something, which resulted in them leaving a television by the door.

Police are still looking for suspects in the attack.

Ocoee's population is more than 32,000, and it is 10 miles from Orlando, which reported 2,574 violent crimes in 2010, according to FBI crime statistics.

fields.heading: Santa Maria suspect accused of home robbery
fields.content:

23-year-old Silas Kanady will be charged in the home invasion that resulted in one man being pistol-whipped and two other men being left bound in their Nipoma home.

Kanady will be charged with kidnap to commit robbery, first-degree robbery, assault with a deadly weapon, burglary, dissuading a victim and false imprisonment, according to the San Luis Obispo County Sheriff's Department.

Kanady is also a suspect in another case similar to the Nipoma home invasion. He was arrested in connection with a Santa Maria home invasion and is currently being held at Santa Barbara County Jail.

Officials report Kanady is scheduled to appear in court simultaneously for both crimes.

In addition to the other charges, Kanady is being charged with dissuading the victims, for telling them that he knew where their mother was in an attempt to discourage the victims from notifying the police about the crime.

One other suspect was linked to the incident, but no further arrests have been made.

According to FBI statistics, Santa Maria, California, experienced 505 burglaries in 2010.

The victim heard the two intruders trying to force their way into her house soon after midnight and hid in the bathroom, calling police before they could get to her.

The police arrived, and the two suspects fled the scene through neighboring yards.

One of the suspects, Abraham Simmers of Glenpool, was caught just blocks away from the scene of the crime and was arrested. Police said Simmers was intoxicated and they later booked him at a Tulsa County Jail for complaints of first-degree burglary, public intoxication and interfering with an emergency call.

This was the second home invasion occurring in Tulsa in a week. fields.heading: MMA fighters still scarred by home invasion
fields.content:

Irvin woke up October 4, 2008, to find two armed men had broken into his suburban Maryland home where his wife, son and Brandon Vera, who was training for a fight, were staying. The intruders instructed the entire group to get up and all sit together.

One of the men held Vera and the rest of the Irving family at gunpoint while the other went through the house with Lloyd Irving. Irvin took this as an opportunity to disarm the man, which led to the two intruders leaving the house.

"My son is still traumatized to this day," Irvin said to MMA Fighting. "We just got him back sleeping in his own room about four or five months ago. About two years ago we got him back in his room for about 30 days, and then one incident where these deer set off the alarm outside the house, after that it went downhill again."

Irvin said that the incident traumatized him also, completely changing his state of mind and preventing him from being as successful in MMA, or mixed martial arts, fighting.

Irvin's account of the home invasion magnifies the importance of having reliable home security alarms.

fields.heading: Juveniles arrested for home invasion
fields.content:
Four teenagers and one 11-year-old believed to have been involved in a Grovetown, Georgia, home invasion were denied bond by a juvenile court judge recently.

All of the suspects were charged with armed robbery for a Grovetown home invasion that resulted in one of the victims having a gun drawn on her.

The incident began with one of the teens ringing the doorbell repeatedly until the victim answered the door. She opened the door and one of the suspects asked if "Bill" was home. When she informed them that there was no Bill who lived in the home, another one of the suspects, who had been hiding, aimed a gun at her, ordered her in the house and made her lie down on the floor.

The victim informed the suspects that her boyfriend was upstairs sleeping, and once the boyfriend heard the commotion, he came downstairs, at which point the juveniles fled the house.

Shortly after, police spotted three of the suspects running away from the home and arrested them. After interrogating the three, authorities were led to the other two suspects.

Georgia is revamping its juvenile justice code, with sweeping reforms related to how minor offenders are processed through the state's justice system, according to RightOnCrime.com.
