fields.heading: Chicago home intruder threatens to kill for beer
fields.content:
A Chicago man was charged with a recent home invasion in the Wicker Park neighborhood, in which he allegedly broke into two apartments demanding beer from the residents.

Authorities contend 36-year-old Timothy Snyder broke into the two homes at about 4 a.m., telling residents to give him beer and threatening to harm them if they didn't.

Snyder broke into the first apartment and searched through the refrigerator for beer before leaving and going to the next apartment on his hunt, Assistant Cook County State's Attorney Aileen Bhandari told news sources.

Once Snyder broke into the second home, he was met by the resident, who he engaged in a physical altercation. Snyder allegedly stabbed the victim in the back with a wine key or corkscrew, which required the resident to receive 22 stitches.

Once police arrived at the scene, they arrested Snyder. Snyder allegedly spat on one of the officers after being arrested and told them they couldn't keep him locked up forever.

The intruder was charged with two counts of home invasion, aggravated battery causing great bodily harm and aggravated battery to a police officer. A Cook County judge set Snyder's bond at $250,000, the Chicago Tribune reported.

fields.heading: Three men being held on bond for home invasion
fields.content:
A Farmington, Maine, home invasion has landed three men in jail, where they are awaiting their hearings on multiple charges.

The three men allegedly held a couple at gunpoint on Halloween night after breaking into the victims' Farmington home.

One of the suspects held the couple at gunpoint while the other two raided the house for valuables, leaving with more than $1,600 in cash, jewelry and prescription pain killers.

The three intruders demanded that the male victim take them to an ATM to get money from his account. After driving to two banks at gunpoint, the male victim withdrew $600 from one bank and $100 from another.

After taking the money, the criminals fled the scene, but were caught and charged for the home invasion, as well as several other crimes that had been recently committed.

The men in custody are 27-year-old Kevin Crandall and 26-year-old Marcus A. Thompson. After detaining Crandall and Thompson and conducting further investigation, police arrested 20-year-old Michael Kidd in connection with the crimes.

fields.heading: Holiday safety on the minds of Americans
fields.content:
The holidays are quickly approaching, causing some individuals to be more cautious about their belongings and home security.

Thefts and home invasions occur at an increasing rate around holiday time, and security companies are trying to boost awareness of holiday hazards. Master Lock recently offered safety tips for consumers who want to protect their valuables during the holiday season.

"The holidays are a fun but busy time, and the flurry of activity can often cause important considerations, such as safety and security, to go overlooked," said Rebecca Smith, vice president of marketing for Master Lock.

When traveling during the holiday season, Master Lock encourages Americans to make sure car safety is taken into account by ensuring the tire pressure is what it should be and stocking a safety kit in the vehicle.

In addition to car safety, Master Lock encourages Americans to make sure their homes are secure when they leave for the holiday season. While many safety-conscious homeowners might already have a home security system installed, Master Lock urges everyone to inform trusted neighbors how long they'll be traveling and to ask them to watch the house.

Burglary numbers usually are the highest in the summer months, but increase around November and December when home intruders know homes are left unattended by the owners, according to the CrimeInAmerica website.

fields.heading: Burglary and theft plaguing Houston community
fields.content:
October statistics compiled by the Houston Police Department revealed an increase in theft and burglary in the community.

Authorities believe the increase in crime is tied to the struggling economy and financial woes hovering around families in the area, as well as the entire country, the Houston Herald reported.

"Over the past few months, with the economy still hard and some people still not working, we have seen a significant increase in shoplifting and burglary," said Houston Police Chief Jim McNiell to the Herald. "We're seeing a lot of vehicles being entered and a lot of homes being burglarized, and I can't emphasize enough to people to safeguard their homes and their vehicles."

According to the Herald, McNiell added that residents of the community should protect themselves from being victims by being more aware of their surroundings.

"Don't leave wallets and purses in plain view in your vehicle, and make sure to lock your doors," said McNiell to the source. "Also make sure you lock the doors when you leave home and leave a light on at night."

Houston police encourage residents to be careful during the upcoming holiday season because thieves will look at it as a perfect time to strike.

Heidi Antilla was in her University Place apartment, which she shares with her daughter and three grandchildren, when an intruder posing as a delivery man knocked on her door. When Antilla opened the door, the man allegedly punched her in the face, knocking her off of her feet and leaving her face bruised and bloody.

"I just really couldn't believe that somebody could be that heartless and evil," she told the Seattle Post Intelligencer. "I didn't understand."

After she was knocked to the ground, a second suspect entered the home and tied Antilla up while holding an object to her neck, telling her it was a gun.

fields.heading: Durham police release safety tips for the holidays
fields.content:
The police department of Durham, North Carolina, recently released tips for residents to consider when preparing for safety during the holiday season.

The holidays are usually a time burglars look to invade homes, being aware that families often are out of town visiting relatives and valuables are found in residences during this time of giving.

The police department urged residents to utilize a good dead bolt lock that deters burglars from entering the home, and be diligent about locking it. The authorities also discouraged residents from keeping Christmas gifts where they can be seen from outside. Breaking down boxes that presents came in and discretely disposing of them will keep burglars from knowing exactly what might be in the home, police stated.

For residents of Durham who are staying home for the holidays, police said that if they hear someone breaking into the home, they should leave the residence as quickly as possible or call the police.

Using a timer to turn lights on and off when leaving a home is also a security tip that is thought to be imperative to fend off intruders. Leaving on a television or radio is also a method to deterring burglars from breaking into homes.

Police released these tips after a number of home invasions in the area, which have resulted in casualties, including one in October resulting in a death, according to the Durham County News Observer.

According to Newsday, the thief is still on the run, and police have noticed an increase in the number of doorstep thefts this holiday season. Many delivery companies in previous years required a resident of the home to sign for deliveries, but in recent years, they have become accustomed to leaving packages in an inconspicuous place near the door.

fields.heading: Social media compromising home security
fields.content:
Americans leaving their homes for the holidays are vulnerable to burglaries, which occur the most around November and December, according to the FBI. But, another threat is becoming a compromising factor in home security.

Social media has become an easy way for burglars to stake out a home during the holidays. Homeowners who are active on social networks often update their whereabouts daily on Twitter and Facebook, which burglars look at to determine a prime opportunity to break into a residence.

“Social media is definitely a factor in many of today’s burglaries. Instead of watching for mail to accumulate outside your residence, burglars can case your home by simply scanning your Twitter feed and monitoring your Facebook status for any signs you’re away,” said Joanna Moore, Mercury Insurance chief claims officer. “And it’s only getting easier with new features like Facebook Places, which allows users to divulge their exact location by simply checking in.”

According to FBI statistics reported by Los Angeles news source The Weekly, there are close to 400,000 burglaries nationwide in November and December, which signals Americans should be more cautious when securing their homes during the holidays.

Moore encouraged homeowners to use social media to their advantage by giving the impression that there is still someone in their home, uploading photos of a vacation after they've returned and shutting off computers to prevent hackers from easily accessing files.

According to Mashable, two-thirds of U.S. adults who access the internet regularly are using social media.

fields.heading: Keeping businesses safe over the holidays

fields.heading: Facebook snaps pic of burglary suspects

fields.heading: Ohio police crack down on crime with technology
fields.content:
Police in Lorain, Ohio, are beginning to crack down on crime by improving their use of advanced technology to catch criminals.

A new system will show the most crime-stricken areas of the city in order for patrol officers to dispatch to those areas at different times throughout the day. The determination of where officers will be dispatched will come from statistics based on police reports compiled from previous incidents.

“The police department’s going to intelligence-led policing,” police spokesperson Michael Failing told local news source the Chronicle Telegram. “We do hot-spot mapping to determine what areas in the city we’re going to direct our patrol units to.”

Officers will handle routine calls during their usual 12-hour shifts, but the focus of their day will range from traffic control to burglaries and quality of life issues, the source reported. The department's shift to crime analysis is spurred by its membership in the Northern Ohio Violent Crime Consortium, which is a group paid for by taxpayers to train police in computerized crime analysis.

The city previously used very little computerized crime analysis, but has made huge strides in increasing its technology, Kent State University professor Eric Jefferis told the source.

With Ohio reporting more than 11 million violent crimes in 2010, according to FBI statistics, the state is looking towards making communities safer for residents.

fields.heading: Home invasion turns deadly, for criminal
fields.content:
Three Ohio men broke into a home January 7, and two are now facing murder charges after one of the suspects was killed by a stab wound at the hand of one of the residents.

Local ABC affiliate WEWS reported 18-year-old Patrick Cooper and 19-year-old Brandan Meeley broke into the Canton, Ohio, home while 19-year-old Johnny Johnson was the lookout.

The two intruders demanded money from the residents, which included a man, his wife, three teenage sons and a 7-year-old, the source reported. When Meeley allegedly pulled out a shotgun and backed the father into a corner, the man grabbed the rifle and it fired. No one was hit by the gunfire, but a fight broke out between the suspects and residents, who wrestled the rifle from Meeley.

One of the residents then stabbed Cooper, who also had a gun. After being stabbed and having the rifle wrestled from them, the three suspects fled the scene of the crime, according to WEWS.

Police followed a trail of blood from the house and found Cooper, dead from his injury. Police found Meeley and Johnson shortly after and both are now facing burglary and murder charges. fields.heading: Intruder caught on camera roaming home
fields.content:
A security camera at a home in Willoughby, Ohio, recently caught an intruder roaming around only a few hours after the resident had left for vacation.

According to police, a video from December 17 revealed the intruder breaking through a window in the rear of the home before making his way inside. Mizner told the source he thinks the intruder saw something, perhaps bank account information, that led him to target the Euclid residence. He also said that while the burglar didn't take any valuables from the home, he did rip out and take the copper from the air conditioning line.

The intruder wandered around Mizner's home aimlessly, passing all the valuables before looking through a lockbox that was unlocked.

The intruder left the scene of the crime and covered his footprints in the snow before proceeding to the next home 48 hours later. No arrests have been made in the break-in.

fields.heading: Ohio University dorms getting security cameras

According to the Athens News, the 17 security cameras were installed in the Voigt residence hall in an effort to increase security on the campus of the university in Athens, Ohio.

fields.heading: Security cameras catch campus arsonist
fields.content:
Cameras in the campus library of the University of Missouri captured footage that led to the detainment of a suspected arsonist.

Pat Jones, director of library security at Ellis Library, told the Columbia Daily Tribune the library doesn't have cameras on the upper floors, which is where the arson took place. fields.content:
A recent burglary in Cedar Grove, New Jersey, resulted in jewelry being taken from the victim's home.

There has been a rash of burglaries recently in the towns surrounding Cedar Grove, which continued with a burglar breaking into a residence January 16 and stealing an unspecified amount of jewelry, according to the Verona-Cedar Grove Times.

fields.heading: New tech adds functions to alarm systems
fields.content:
With wireless alarms and traditional alarm systems becoming more popular because of the extra peace of mind they provide, Americans are beginning to invest more in their safety.

Ann Hoke, a columnist for Tennessee newspaper the Murfreesboro Post, spoke to Henry Horton, a security expert who said that home alarm systems are among the most easily installed and cost-efficient forms of protection out there, often lowering insurance premiums. New technology in home security systems provide a range of options to be sure homeowners are always one step ahead of burglars.

Horton said that alarm systems can be hard-wired or wireless and can be connected with a round-the-clock monitoring center. He also pointed out that many alarm systems double as fire and carbon monoxide detectors.

Horton's points were echoed by Ken Mara, a security expert based in New York.

“New technology found in alarm systems can perform more than just alerts of a security breach or fire," said Mara. "Systems come with basic to advanced features to monitor the dwelling's environment, including temperature changes indicating the heat is off or a flood, control lighting and much more."

Horton and Mara pointed out that home security technology is multi-purpose, but new innovations could take this aspect of security systems to new levels. At the recent Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, a company demonstrated how consumers can monitor and control home security - doing everything from unlocking doors to programming lights - via a system synced to a smartphone, reported The New York Times.

fields.heading: Home safes vs. safe deposit boxes
fields.content:
Many Americans spring for a safe deposit box to keep their cash and other valuables safe in banks, but experts suggest using a fireproof safe at home as opposed to deposit boxes, which usually aren't insured.

Banks are thought to be safe since they provide 24-hour security, but cash and other personal items usually kept in safety deposit boxes are not covered under FDIC insurance. FDIC insurance only protects the deposits in accounts held in banks and not safety deposit boxes.

MoneyWatch recently released a list of 12 things to keep in a safe at home and not in a bank.

The source suggested keeping property insurance polices, agent contact information, passports, original birth certificates and a list of family doctors, prescription medication and contact information for all pharmacies the homeowner uses in a home safe. In addition, digital family photos, safe deposit box keys, original Social Security cards, spare keys, valuables and copies of wills are also encouraged to be included in a fireproof safe.

With all of the valuables encouraged to be left at home, a dependable wireless alarm system or traditional security system are great ways to take extra precaution to keep crucial documents and personal mementos safe. According to the Metropolitan Burglar and Fire Alarm Association of New York, a burglary is committed every 10 seconds in America, which might concern homeowners and encourage them to explore home security systems.

fields.heading: Firebomb attack pushes rabbi to install alarm system
fields.content:
Vandals recently torched an Orthodox synagogue in Rutherford, New Jersey, which now has Rabbi Nosson Schuman installing surveillance cameras and alarm systems to prevent another attack from occurring.

Congregation Beth El was set on fire after suspects threw firebombs at Schuman's home on the second floor of the synagogue at around 4:30 a.m. on January 11. The attack was just one in a string of violent anti-Semitic attacks on synagogues in Bergen County. Another wave of attacks has occurred nearby, in the New York boroughs of Manhattan and Brooklyn, as well as on Long Island.

“Every place they attacked was some place that didn’t have a surveillance system,” Rabbi Schuman pointed out to news source The Jewish Week. “I assume if you have one - unless they start becoming braver and taking more risks - they are going to stay away.”

Schuman told the Week that the neighborhood has raised more than $2,000 towards purchasing and installing security cameras and extra lighting with motion sensors around the place of worship.

According to the Jewish Daily Forward, the attacks began on December 10, when a synagogue was spray-painted with swastikas and the words "Jews did 9/11." Authorities are investigating one suspect who was arrested for making threatening calls to Jewish residents in the area.

fields.heading: Importance of a home security system
fields.content:
With property crime a persistent problem in the United States, the website EQuickNews recently explained the importance of purchasing a home security system to protect valuables and loved ones.

According to the source, burglars typically avoid homes that are armed with a burglar alarm for fear of getting arrested by law enforcement. When a sign is visible outside of home signaling that the house is protected by alarm systems, those thinking about burglarizing the residence might think twice.

Installing a house alarm is also beneficial to homeowner's pockets in more ways than one. fields.heading: Arizona tops list of safest places to live
fields.content:
When it comes to safety and security, no other state is quite as secure as Arizona, according to a new breakdown of the 10 safest places to live in the country.

The study, from InsuranceProviders.com, analyzed three different safety factors: an area's rate of automobile accidents, the likelihood of a natural disaster and, perhaps most importantly, crime rates. Interestingly, however, an area's crime rate was not necessarily a factor in it being a particularly safe place to live. It was, however, a key factor in being an unsafe place to live. Study authors pointed to the example of New York, which has a fairly low crime rate - 0.55 percent per 100,000 people, according to FBI statistics used in compiling the report - but is still not a very safe place to live. The Big Apple ranked 43 out of 73 cities.

Topping the list was Mesa, Arizona, where residents rarely get in car accidents, there is virtually zero risk of natural disaster, and the crime rate is a scant 0.39 percent. Two other Arizona cities, Tucson (No. 3) and Phoenix (No. 7) made the top 10 list. Other cities to make the list were: Colorado Springs, Colorado; St. Paul, Minnesota; Fort Wayne, Indiana; Henderson, Nevada; El Paso, Texas; Aurora, Colorado; and Anaheim, California.

Homeowners in any part of the country can reduce their risk of being victimized in a crime. Home security systems are an effective way to lower the risk of a burglary or other type of home invasion.

Residents of a Chicago suburb were put on alert following a series of five seemingly related break-ins that occurred over the course of 10 hours on January 27.

All five of the robberies in the city of Skokie involved broken outside windows or door windows, and in all five cases the home owners were not at home. Only one of the residences was equipped with a home security system, which sounded when the burglars attempted to force their way through a patio door. A neighbor responded to the alarm, according to local news source the Pioneer Press.

Among the items taken from the houses were flat-screen televisions, computers, cash, gaming consoles and jewelry. Local police warn that doors containing windows are more prone to break-in, and remind residents that the local department provides free home security assessments.

These robberies occurred shortly after Skokie authorities announced crime decreased by 4 percent between 2010 and 2011. Police Chief Anthony Scarpelli pointed to a successful Neighborhood Watch program as contributing to the decline.

fields.heading: Son robs parents' house

Just weeks after being kicked out of his parents' house, 22-year-old Joshua Conrad, along with his 22-year-old friend Dennis Healion, decided to return home and cause some damage. The pair entered the house and destroyed the home security system before stealing four television sets, according to a local report from the Delaware County Daily Times.

Conrad was kicked out of his parents' house because of his drug addiction, police told the local news. The two men are being charged with burglary, theft, conspiracy, criminal mischief and criminal trespass.

Recent information from the National Institute on Drug Abuse shows that a decline in illicit drug use among teens has leveled off in recent years, and marijuana use is on the rise. Roughly 21.4 percent of high school seniors reported using marijuana at least once over a 30-day period.

fields.heading: Man arrested in connection with 79 storage unit thefts
fields.content:
Daniel Stimpson's crime spree is at an end. Police in Revere, Massachusetts, recently arrested the 40-year-old man who they say committed as many as 79 thefts.

Stimpson is alleged to have used an access code to gain entry into the Extra Space Storage facility where, over a period of 10 days, he picked locks and used bolt cutters to break into storage units. Security camera footage captured images of Stimpson as he committed the crimes, often posing as a storage unit owner and simply wheeling his ill-gotten goods out the front door, according to local ABC affiliate WCVB.

The charges against Stimpson include trespassing, breaking and entering and larceny over $250 for the TVs and other valuable items. But despite being connected by police to 79 storage unit thefts, he has only been charged in eight thefts.

Many storage facilities use a combination of visible and hidden security cameras to protect their facilities, according to selfstorageblog.com. In addition to cameras, storage unit renters should make sure a facility has proper fencing and a security-controlled access gate, the blog suggests.

The alleged bandits, 17-year-old Robert Billings and 20-year-old Marquis Johnson, placed a phone call to Quitman County, Georgia, police shortly before midnight on February 7, reporting a fake shooting. They then burglarized a pawn shop mere minutes from the police station, making off with a number of video games, according to local ABC affiliate WTVM.

Security camera footage captured images of the pair, who are facing felony theft charges after turning themselves in to authorities on February 8. They were identified by members of the community, according to the news report.

A recent FBI survey showed that theft of video game consoles rose sharply at the end of the last decade, rising 285 percent between 2007 and 2009. The trend is due largely to the high re-sale value and portability of electronics, according to a USA Today analysis of the study.

fields.heading: Thieves enter convenience store through ceiling to avoid alarms
fields.content:
Criminals hoping to evade security alarms cut through the roof at a New Hampshire convenience store, but they failed to take into account the store's security cameras.

Police in Allenstown were able to arrest three men after local news aired footage of the unusual robbery, according to local CNN affiliate WMUR. The video shows the men removing a ceiling tile and then dropping into the Suncook River convenience store through the hole. Once inside the store, they loaded up pizza delivery bags with cigarettes and made their escape before police could respond to the burglar alarm.

After police released the footage, anonymous tips led to the arrests of 23-year-old Timothy Downing, 23-year-old Richard Fortier and 27-year-old Brandon Lanum. Lanum had been the chief suspect in a recent bank robbery. The three men could face hefty sentences, as all of them were on probation at the time of the burglary, according to the news source.

An April 2011 study from the Pew Center on the States regarding recidivism rates - criminals returning to jail after being released from prison - found that there has been little change over the last dozen years. Recidivism rates were 45.4 percent between 1999 and 2002, and 43.3 percent between 2004 and 2007.

fields.heading: Failed kidnapping caught on store cameras
fields.content:
Security cameras at a suburban Atlanta Walmart captured startling images of a botched kidnapping on February 8.

Seven-year-old Brittney Baxter was approached by a man in the toy aisle of the local megastore, the security footage shows. After a brief conversation, the man, later identified as 25-year-old Thomas Woods, picked up the young girl and attempted to carry her out of the store. Baxter began flailing wildly and shouting, eventually forcing Woods to release her and flee the scene.

In an interview with HLN, Baxter said that she was simply doing what she had been taught to do by her parents and teachers: "Punch, kick and scream as hard as you can, and then tell somebody that you trust."

Using the store security camera footage, police tracked down Woods, who had been released from prison in October 2011. Woods had been convicted of voluntary manslaughter, and served 4.5 years of a seven-year sentence.

Roughly 2,000 children are kidnapped every day in the United States, according to kidnapping prevention group Fighting Chance. Only 18 percent of kidnappings are committed by non-family members.

fields.heading: Orlando Police: Home security cameras would lower crime rate
fields.content:
If every homeowner purchased and installed a security camera system, crime would fall 10 percent, Orlando Police Chief Paul Rooney recently told the local media.

Speaking with Orlando CBS affiliate WKMG, Rooney said home security systems including security cameras would help police solve burglaries faster and reduce the number of break-ins. A new unit in the Orlando Police Department is taking advantage of new crime fighting technology to more expeditiously put wrongdoers behind bars. Cops still work on cases the old fashioned way, but cases without video are more difficult to solve, Rooney said.

Security cameras have helped solve a number of cases in Orlando recently, according to the news source, including a recent string of burglaries in the Delaney Park area.

"Because of videotape, we got a tag number and identified the suspects," Rooney told WKMG.

Orlando was ranked third on a 2011 U.S. News and World Report breakdown of the top 11 most dangerous cities in the country. While violent crime rates were lower than other comparably ranked cities, Orlando does have a higher rate of larceny and theft, according to the breakdown.

fields.heading: Utah governor assassination plot foiled
fields.content:
A plot to assassinate Utah Governor Gary Herbert was foiled recently when police apprehended the would-be assailant.

Brian Biff Baker, 52, allegedly bragged to a friend via text message of his plans to murder the governor, according to an Associated Press report. Baker had been scouting out the governor's mansion in Salt Lake City, and reportedly also made threats against a police officer who drove by the scene numerous times during the stake out. Baker's friend immediately reported the threats to the police.

Police arrested Baker February 10 at a nearby gas station after using his friend, the text message recipient, to lure him there, the AP reported. Once in custody, police found fireworks, explosives, a large knife and small bags of methamphetamine in Baker's car. Security camera footage from the governor's mansion showed Baker conducting his reconnaissance.

William Goebel of Kentucky remains the only serving governor to be assassinated in the history of the United States. He was shot one day before his inauguration in 1900, and died three days into his first term, according to the National Governor's Association.

fields.heading: Dog thieves arrested in South Carolina
fields.content:
Police in Columbia, South Carolina, have arrested two youths accused of committing a string of dog thefts in the area.

On three separate occasions beginning January 29, unknown persons broke into the Columbia Animal Shelter, making off with 17 pit bulls. After the first two incidents, security cameras were set up to record images of the thieves. During the third break-in, the cameras captured footage of a tall, lanky individual wearing dark gloves and a hooded jacket, according to reports from local news source The State.

Following the arrests, police and animal control workers located the missing pit bulls at the suspects' home in Blackville. They are still searching for two more suspects, 25-year-old Desmond Jamar Jones and an unnamed 13-year-old, according to the source. Police suspect the dogs were to be used for illegal dog fighting.

The shelter consulted an expert in security camera installation, according to the news source. The expert was also involved in the installation of cameras that led to the arrest of a suspect in an assault against a teenager in June.

Dog fighting is a felony in all 50 states, according to the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. Between 2003 and 2008 there were 1,000 arrests for dog fighting in the U.S.United States.

fields.heading: Warm weather linked to higher murder rate, Chicago officials indicate
fields.content:
New crime data from the Windy City shows that the murder rate has risen significantly compared with the same period in 2011, and Chicago's top cops have a few ideas as to the reasons why.

During January 2011, there were 26 reported homicides in Chicago, which was roughly average for that time of year, according to local NBC reports. This year, however, there have already been 40 homicides - an increase of more than 50 percent.

Former police chief Jody Wies, who now heads the Chicago Crime Commission, has been critical of the tactics implemented by his successor, Garry McCarthy, NBC reports. McCarthy has taken officers from special divisions and put them on the streets, a move supported by Mayor Rahm Emanuel.

Still, officials suggest another explanation could account for the rise in murders - the unseasonably warm weather. Colder weather typically keeps people inside, but the spate of 30- and 40-plus degree days in Chicago this January has made it more comfortable for people - including criminals - to get out and about.

The theory that weather and crime patterns are related has been supported by research. In 2010, researchers from Kent State University and the Terra Nova Real Estate Group found that the correlation between outdoor temperature and aggressive crime in Cleveland, Ohio, was greatest during the midday and early night hours.

fields.heading: Home security robots? Not in this lifetime
fields.content:
Home security systems have taken a number of forms over the years, from high tech wireless security cameras and advanced alarm systems, to impressively large dogs. But a new survey suggests that some people would be open to a new kind of security system: robots.

The survey, from Persuadable Research Corporation, found that 68 percent of respondents would like to have a domestic robot to help out around the house. The top two reasons? Lifting heavy things (55 percent) and home security (54 percent). Other possible uses for the futuristic domestic helpers include washing dishes, caring for the elderly or babysitting children.

But while the survey found that some people (13 percent) would be willing to pay more than $15,000 for such a robot, researchers point out that these devices do not exist, and likely will not exist for quite some time. More standard home security systems are typically much less expensive, and are currently available to buy. According to a report from a Temple University researcher, a home security alarm decreases the chance of burglary by more than 66 percent when used in conjunction with at least two other preventive measures, such as dead bolt locks and motion sensor exterior lights.

fields.heading: New York man arrested for late-night theft of beer, cigarettes
fields.content:
Police in Lockport, New York, were able to arrest a man for burglary after being summoned to the scene of his crime by an in-store burglar alarm.

The crime took place around 4 a.m. on February 15. Officers from both the Niagara County Sheriff's office and the state police arrived at a local convenience store to discover a smashed window, according to local reports from the Buffalo News. Though the burglar had already fled, a witness directed police to a nearby wood where police eventually caught up with the suspect.

Thirty-one-year-old David Tomporowski was discovered exiting the woods with small lacerations on his nose and face, according to the News. He was treated by officers before being placed under arrest for the crime. Security camera footage provided by the store owner clearly showed Tomporowski leaving the store with his ill-gotten goods - an 18-pack of beer and four packs of cigarettes - which were recovered from the woods that morning. Tomporowski has been charged with third-degree burglary, third-degree criminal trespass and petit larceny.

Petit larceny, which includes shoplifting, is one of the most prevalent crimes in the Buffalo area, according to the region's Better Business Bureau. The crime can carry a one-year prison sentence, a $1,000 fine and/or a criminal record.

Fifty-year-old Ken Barrows recently received a 3 a.m. phone call from this home security company informing him that the burglar alarm in his detached garage had been tripped. A man had broken into the garage through a window, according to regional CNN affiliate KTVZ.

Barrows confronted the man in his garage, holding him at gunpoint for several minutes before the suspect opened the garage door and fled on foot. "I think I would have waited for the police," he told KTVZ. "I should have just called the police first."

fields.heading: Ex-con divulges tricks of the trade
fields.content:
Folks worried about home security might do well to heed the advice of a hardened criminal when it comes to burglary-proofing one's abode.

Houston-based NBC affiliate KPRC recently sat down with ex-con Bob Portenier, a retired criminal who said he burglarized more than 100 homes before serving an eight-year prison sentence in the 1980s. Portenier gave his opinion on the best ways to beef up home security.

Homeowners should keep checks and credit cards in a safe bolted to the floor or wall, rather than in a desk, he suggested, admitting that he routinely took a single checkbook from homes, knowing that homeowners would be less likely to notice its disappearance. He also noted that many homeowners typically hide valuable items in similar places, such as under a mattress or in a bedroom closet. Storing those valuables in a less likely place may foil some criminals, he told KPRC.

Homeowners could also install security cameras as part of a home security system. Recently, Orlando Police Chief Paul Rooney told the local media that crime rates would drop by 10 percent if every homeowner installed a security camera.

fields.heading: New infrared technology could bolster home security systems
fields.content:
Home security systems could soon become much more sophisticated thanks to new research into nanomaterials from Arizona State University.

Researchers at ASU layered ultra-thin nanomaterials to create crystal-producing "super lattices," according to a letter published recently in the journal Applied Physics Letters. The crystals in these lattices are capable of acting as highly sensitive photodetectors, which can be easily manipulated to detect varying wavelengths of light and convert them into electric signals.

By manipulating the super lattices, researchers can change the sensitivity to pick up highly accurate infrared images. The applications for this technology are broad and varied, ranging from advanced weapons systems and medical diagnostic technology, to night-vision capabilities for law enforcement officers and effective home security systems for average consumers.

Approaches to infrared technology research are as varied as its potential uses. Researchers at General Electric have developed a new infrared heat sensor that is made by coating the wings of the Morpho butterfly with single-walled carbon nanotubes, according to a recent MedGadget.com article.

fields.heading: Security cameras, increased security lead to uptick in shoplifting arrests
fields.content:
A concerted effort on the part of local businesses to increase security has led to a significant increase in the number of shop-lifting arrests in Granite City, Illinois.

City-wide shoplifting arrests hit 204 during 2011, more than a 50 percent increase over 2010, when there were 133 such arrests, according to the St. Louis Post-Dispatch. The main reason behind the surge in arrests is increased security at area businesses, local police say.

Area big-box retailers Walmart and K-mart have each increased the number of security cameras in their stores. At K-mart, arrests rose from 34 in 2010 to 45 last year. The numbers at Walmart were even more dramatic, nearly doubling from 49 to 93 over the same time period, according to the news source.

Smaller area stores have also been adding video surveillance equipment to their store security systems.

Granite City is a close suburb of St. Louis, which can routinely be found on the list of top 10 most dangerous cities in America as determined by FBI statistics. During 2011, St. Louis slid to fourth place, down from its No. 1 spot in 2010.

fields.content:
A Houston area housing development will be getting some much needed security cameras after receiving a federal grant to beef up security for residents.

Kelly Village, one of the Houston Public Housing Authority's older properties, has been plagued with shootings, burglaries and other crimes over the last few years, despite increased beautification efforts, according to local ABC affiliate KTRK. While landscapes have been updated and maintained, crime is still a problem.

The grants from the Department of Housing and Urban Development will go entirely toward the cost of improved security, according to KTRK. Roughly $250,000 will be spent on security cameras to record illicit behavior - live-monitored cameras are still too expensive for the housing community.

"We'll be able to put cameras in a number of different locations throughout the property to basically eliminate hot spots of where people want to congregate and do not nice things," Houston Housing Authority CEO Tory Gunsolley told the news source.

The Houston Housing Authority manages roughly 19,000 units of affordable, low-income housing for more than 55,000 Houston residents. The largest public housing authority in the country is in New York City, which serves 633,177 residents, according to the NYCHA website.

fields.heading: ATM assailant still at large
fields.content:
Most people get fed up with outrageous ATM fees, but one Florida man seems to have had enough. Security camera footage captured images of the unknown man bashing several ATMs at area banks with a sledgehammer.

Police released the security camera footage in the hopes that residents in the Ocoee area will come forward with information about the perpetrator. The man, described by police as being in his 20s or 30s and wearing a black leather jacket, sunglasses and dark pants in the video footage, smashed at least three ATMs between February 16 and February 20. The damage totals roughly $20,000, according to reports the Orlando Sentinel.

Theft does not appear to be the motive behind the crimes, according to local police. Security videos show the man approaching the ATMs, hitting them repeatedly with a sledgehammer and then driving away without attempting to steal the cash from inside. The crimes occurred at the SunTrust Bank and a Bank of America.

According to the most recent FBI data, there were 2,088 bank robberies in the first half of 2011, resulting in more than $15.3 million in stolen loot.

fields.heading: Mesa council to vote on new guidelines for false alarm calls
fields.content:
The city of Mesa, Arizona, is looking to change a rule that unfairly affects law-abiding citizens with permits for home security systems.

Last year, Mesa police responded to more than 11,000 burglar alarm calls, 98 percent of which were false alarms. According to department statistics, reducing false alarms between 2001-2010 saved the city about $500,000. Citizens are required to have a permit for home security systems in Mesa, but so far, thousands of systems have gone unregistered.

Due to a city ordinance, police are only able to issue false alarm fines to homeowners who have registered their alarms, according to local news source KTAR. The city council is expected to vote soon to change that law and allow fines to be handed out for unregistered alarms.

"It almost seems unfair that the only people that can be held accountable, up to this point, are the ones who are being responsible in the first place," Mesa Police Sergeant Ed Wessing told KTAR.

Despite the costs associated with false alarms, home security systems do help reduce crime rates. Recently, Orlando Police Chief Paul Rooney told local CBS affiliate WKMG that crime would fall by 10 percent if every homeowner installed security cameras.

fields.heading: Brazen jewelry store robbery caught on tape
fields.content:
On February 10, two individuals rushed into a Miami Beach, Florida, jewelry store and made off with roughly $250,000 in jewelry and precious stones, according to local reports.

Security cameras recorded the daring daytime robbery. The suspects wore motorcycle helmets and black clothing as they charged into the store. One individual held an employee at gun point while the other smashed display cases and gathered up the goods, reports local Fox affiliate WSVN.

While police do not currently have any suspects, they are searching for a person of interest, according to WSVN. Shortly before the crime, a man entered the store and requested to see a specific chain from a display case that was later targeted by the criminals. He is only wanted for questioning at this time.

The state of Florida has very strict laws concerning the use of firearms during a crime, according to the state's Department of Corrections. Dubbed "10-20-LIFE," the law mandates a minimum 10-year sentence for certain felonies committed while the perpetrator possesses a gun, a minimum 20-year sentence if the gun is discharged during the crime, and a 25-year-to-life sentence if a person is injured or killed during the crime.

fields.heading: Security cameras could soon watch over America's oldest trees
fields.content:
Following the collapse of one of the world's oldest cypress tree, officials in Seminole County, Florida,  are considering installing security cameras and fences to help protect another ancient conifer.

The Senator, a 3,500-year-old cypress located at Big Tree Park in Florida, collapsed on January 16 as the result of a fire. While investigators are still uncertain how the fire began, arson has been ruled out as a cause.

Now, park and county officials want to encircle the remaining stump with a decorative fence, and set up additional security measures across the park. This would include two or three security cameras near the site of The Senator's stump, and near another cypress, the 2,000-year-old Lady Liberty tree, according to The Orlando Sentinel.

Officials have also proposed installing a six-foot chain link fence around the perimeter of the park. The security cameras and the fencing would cost roughly $63,000, according to the Sentinel.

Another ancient cypress is alive and well and living in Iran. The 4,000-year-old Sarv-e-Abarkooh, also known as the Zoroastrian Sarv, carries strong religious connotations for many Iranians, according to Environmental Graffiti.

fields.heading: Female bank robber sought in Southern California
fields.content:
Federal agents are asking the public for help in identifying a woman who robbed a Southern California bank, according to local news.

On February 23, the FBI released an image of the woman taken from bank security cameras. She is described as Latina, roughly 5-foot-9 with black wavy hair and brown eyes, reports the San Diego Union Tribune. The crime took place February 21 at a Bank of America located inside an Albertsons Supermarket in Spring Valley.

According to the report, the woman passed the bank teller a note before flashing a gun tucked inside the waist of her jeans. She then left the store with an undisclosed amount of money.

By the age of 24, Bonnie Parker, of Bonnie and Clyde fame, had become the most notorious female bank robber in the nation before being gunned down by Louisiana police in 1934. Currently, very few bank heists are perpetrated by women. Roughly 7 percent were committed by women during the first part of 2011, according to FBI statistics.

fields.heading: California man demands police action after car theft caught on tape
fields.content:
Ron Hernandez has security camera footage of the man who stole his Honda Civic, and now he wants police to find him, according to local news reports.

Hernandez installed security cameras at his home in Bakersfield, California, shortly after his son's car was broken into last November. A subsequent December break-in yielded no arrests. But now, Hernandez says he has clear footage of the thief who stole the car on February 18, and wants police to move fast to catch the man, according to local NBC affiliate KGET.

Hernandez says he went to police on February 18, but was told he wouldn't be able to submit the video until February 21, according to KGET. That's when an officer was assigned to the case.

"The crime rate for these Hondas is the greatest in Bakersfield right now," an irate Hernandez told KGET. "And, the police are basically sitting on their hands instead of getting the video and looking at it."

In 2009, the Honda Accord inched past the Honda Civic to become the No. 1 most stolen car in America, according to the most recent data available from the National Insurance Crime Bureau.

fields.content:
Shots were fired during a recent home invasion in Hagerstown, Maryland, according to local reports.

The incident occurred during the early morning hours of February 26 when multiple suspects pushed their way inside a home in Hagerstown's West End, according to local news source The Herald-Mail. The victim received minor scraps and bruises during the ensuing struggle. An undisclosed number of shots were fired by one of the burglars, but no one was injured by the gunfire.

Police arrested one individual, 17-year-old Curtis Eugene Evans, who is being charged as an adult with first-degree burglary, first- and second-degree assault and reckless endangerment. Local residents were shaken by the home invasion, even suggesting the neighborhood install security cameras to help capture criminals, according to the news source.

There were 31,605 reports of violent crime in Maryland during 2010, the last year for which data is available. That represents the lowest number of violent crime reports since 1978, according to the Governor's Office of Crime Control and Prevention.

fields.heading: Skate park to receive security cameras through federal grant
fields.content:
Police and local school officials in Danvers, Massachusetts, will use grant money from the Department of Justice to install security cameras at a local skate park.

Police have made 33 visits to the park behind the Holton Richmond Middle School for vandalism, drug use and fighting, according to the Boston Globe. The Justice Department grant totals $93,500, but is eligible for matching funds. Local officials say the money will be spent on new cameras for the skate park, as well as beefing up existing security inside the middle school.

“We hope cameras will deter some of the nuisance behavior that sometimes happen when people feel like not they are not being supervised,” police spokesman Sergeant Robert Bettencourt told the Globe.

A skate park in Conneaut, Ohio, may also be getting the security camera treatment. Police in that town have been receiving an increased amount of complaints regarding youths congregating at the park at odd hours of the night, according to a report from the local Star-Beacon.

fields.heading: Burglar alarm doubles as fire alarm at Louisiana convenience store
fields.content:
Deputies with the Lafayette, Louisiana, Sheriff's Department expected to find a criminal when they responded to a burglar alarm call at the local convenience store. Instead, they found a fire.

The motion-activated burglar alarm inside a Texaco Food Mart was set off by the flames, according to local news source The Advertiser. Though officials are still investigating the cause of the fire, preliminary reports indicate it originated near a sandwich cooler. The Texaco sustained heavy smoke and fire damage. Two adjacent businesses, a doughnut shop and a pay-day loan agency, remained open for business after the blaze, having received minor smoke damage.

Meanwhile, police in Covington, Louisiana, wrapped up a three-week investigation into a series of area burglaries. Authorities arrested 28-year-old John McGrath and 31-year-old Priscilla McGrath after a witness account led to the discovery of stolen cameras, laptops and other valuables at one of the alleged perpetrator's homes, according to the St. Tammany News.

fields.heading: Home invasion suspect shoots elderly homeowner in leg
fields.content:
An elderly man in Severn, Maryland, is recovering after being shot during a recent home invasion, allegedly with his own gun, according to local reports.

The home invasion occurred in the early morning hours of February 29. The 82-year-old man, whose name was not available at press time, went to investigate a strange noise in his kitchen around 4:20 a.m. He allegedly struggled with the suspect before being shot in the leg by a shotgun that police believe was his own, according to local ABC affiliate WJLA.

Police believe the suspect, who was described as a white male in his late teens or early 20s, wearing black pants and a black hooded sweat shirt, fled in a darkly colored four-door Chevy truck, according to the report.

Preliminary statistics from the FBI indicate a 6.4 percent drop in reported violent crime nationwide in 2011. The number of property crimes committed during the first half of the year fell by 3.7 percent.

fields.heading: Ann Arbor police reiterate need for precautions during crime wave
fields.content:
As a rash of home invasions continues in Ann Arbor, Michigan, local law enforcement officials are once again urging residents to pay attention to their home security.

Nearly 150 area residents were in attendance at a meeting hosted by the Ann Arbor Police Department on February 28, according to local news source AnnArbor.com. There, officers urged locals to take basic precautions to protect themselves: lock doors and windows, make it appear as though someone is home at all times, get to know neighbors, and invest in a home security system.

“People are utilizing our goodness and the fact some don’t lock doors and windows to take advantage of all of us," said Police Chief Barnett Jones.

Ann Arbor police received 82 reports of home invasions between January 1 and February 18, according to the news source. This is up from 49 during the same period in both 2011 and 2010.

Police had previously speculated that Michigan's higher than average unemployment rate could be contributing to the crime wave. Recent data from the Michigan Department of Technology, Management and Budget put the unemployment rate in the Wolverine State at 9.3 percent in December 2011, compared with a current national average of 8.3 percent.

fields.heading: No charges for boy who killed burglar
fields.content:
A 15-year-old Georgia boy who killed one burglar during a recent home invasion will not face any criminal charges, according to local news reports.

The incident occurred around 7:30 p.m. on February 29, reports local ABC affiliate WJBF. Two men broke into a Columbia County apartment and began struggling with a man inside - a husband, wife and son were home at the time. At some point during the struggle, the boy grabbed a rifle and fired two shots at the burglars, killing one.

The dead suspect has been identified as 19-year-old Justin Stephens of Grovetown - the second suspect is still at large. Police have no intention of filing charges against the boy, the WJBF reports.

A Michigan man who also shot a burglar is not so lucky. Despite claims of self defense, Robert Goupill is being charged with manslaughter in the death of a man who broke into his house. Goupill gave chase to the suspect, killing him two blocks from his home, according to the Monroe News. He is also being charged with manufacturing marijuana.

fields.heading: Man "changed" by recent home invasion
fields.content:
A North Carolina man is more concerned with his safety at home after surviving a brutal home invasion and assault recently.

On February 27, Dennis Tomlinson was at his home when two men charged through his front door, according to local news source the Gaston Gazette. One of the attackers, 31-year-old David Lee Weeks, was a former co-worker of Tomlinson's. Weeks and his 26-year-old brother Daniel beat Tomlinson intermittently for 10 minutes before eventually stealing $25 cash and leaving.

Local authorities later arrested the Weeks brothers, both of whom face charges of first-degree burglary and larceny after breaking/entering charges, according to the Gazette. Tomlinson has since taken to keeping his guns nearby while at home.

“This has changed me," he told the local news. "You have the right to protect yourself."

Recently, a Maryland man was also injured during a home invasion. The 82-year-old was shot, allegedly with his own gun, during a struggle with a burglar in the early morning hours of February 29, according to the Baltimore Sun.

fields.heading: Man arrested after selling stolen goods on Craigslist
fields.content:
An Oregon man was arrested recently after his robbery victims located ads for their missing property on Craigslist.

Stephen Thomas Orchard of Molalla was arrested February 29 on two counts of second degree burglary. He was caught after one of the families he robbed found his ads on Craigslist. The Naylor family of Mulino found a chainsaw for sale on the website that matched the description of one that had recently been stolen from their home.

The Naylors contacted the seller and arranged to meet with him to purchase the chainsaw, according to the Molalla Pioneer. Instead, they contacted the local police, who were waiting to apprehend Orchard upon his arrival. The Naylors and other victims are expected to recover most of their goods. Jimmy Naylor says he will follow the advice of local police and improve his home security system.

Police in Portland, Oregon, receive a lot of calls from people who say they find their stolen goods on Craigslist, according to an ABC News report. During the first part of 2011, police helped more than 100 people recover stolen goods from the website.

fields.heading: Sporting goods store spelunker nabbed by cops
fields.content:
Police is Baytown, Texas, recently caught a burglar red-handed as he made a daring attempt to rob a local sporting goods store.

The would-be thief, 29-year-old John Clements, employed some daring acrobatics in his ambitious but unsuccessful robbery attempt, according to local CBS affiliate KHOU. Using a homemade grappling hook fashioned from rope and heavy-gauge nails, Clements scaled the side of the building, cracked open the store's skylight and lowered himself into the store.

Fortunately, the Academy Sports store was equipped with a motion detecting burglar alarm, which sounded as Clements made his descent. After hoisting himself back to the roof, Clements leaped onto a semi-truck parked near the store, only to be immediately apprehended by local law enforcement.

Thieves in Allenstown, New Hampshire, recently tried a similar approach, cutting their way through the roof of a local convenience store in hopes of avoiding the alarm system. Security cameras captured video of the three men lowering themselves through the ceiling before the burglar alarm sounded anyway, according to CNN affiliate WMUR.

fields.heading: Parents shot, one killed during Philadelphia home invasion
fields.content:
One man was killed and his wife seriously injured as a recent home invasion robbery in Philadelphia turned deadly.

The incident occurred around 3:30 a.m. on March 5 in the Strawberry Mansion area of Philadelphia. Also home were the couple's young children, according to The Associated Press. Authorities believe that, following a brief struggle, the suspect or suspects fired multiple gunshots, killing the man and injuring his wife. She is reported to be in critical condition at nearby Temple University Hospital.

Police are searching area hospitals for signs of the assailant, who they believe may also have been injured or shot during the altercation, according to the AP.

Also on March 5, sheriff's officers in Allegan County, Michigan, successfully apprehended two suspects in a series of car and home break-ins. After being called to the scene of one of the crimes, authorities were able to follow the suspects' footprints in the freshly-fallen snow, according to the Holland Sentinel.

fields.heading: Cameras catch arsonist in the act
fields.content:
Police in Lake Villa, Illinois, are on the hunt for a man caught on security camera footage setting fire to an area home.

The unidentified man is seen walking along the back deck of a two-story family home in the Chicago suburb. Later, the footage shows the man setting fire to the exterior wall of the home using an accelerant and a road flare before fleeing the scene on foot. No one was injured during the blaze, though the house suffered extensive damage.

The man, described as a white male in his 20s with a medium build, is also believed to have set fire to a second area home. Police are asking for local assistance in identifying the suspect. In the meantime, authorities are taking extra precautions in securing the area.

Recently, police in nearby Bolingbrook, Illinois, arrested two young men after they hurled a lit Molotov cocktail at a house occupied by two women, according to the Chicago Tribune. The intended victim, a male in his 20s, was not home at the time. There were no injuries and only minor damage to the house.
